I hope they made enough money to make a Dead State 2 becasue my guess is what they learned making this game would give them an opportunity to make a very special game.

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												This is the zombie apocalypse game that I always wished existed.  I LOVE "anyone can die" type games.  And for the first two weeks or so, anyone could and DID die.  The country bumpkin deputy fell first...the trucker mom and I had to abandon him as we ran for our lives from a hardware store.Then the IT nerd and the trucker mom's daughter were killed at the national park when we tried to split up to survive a horde.Then the trucker mom and the tough cop got caught in the middle of a shootout between rival gangs.  Between the gunfire and the zombies that were attracted to it, it became a blood bath.  In addition to the trucker mom and the tough cop dying, the flight attendant with PTSD got bit.  She killed herself that night.Then the televangelist got jumped...there was no way for us to get to him in time.  Finally, there was nobody left except myself and a young naive farmer girl.  We were doomed.Until we stumbled onto the scene of a car wreck, where a gay former Army Ranger agreed to join our group.  That was the turning point.  Once he was on my team, things got much easier.  We still lost the occasional member from time to time, including one of my survivors murdering another one, but all in all we grew to about 30-40 survivors - each with a unique skill set, backstory, All along the way, I was making hard decisions that affected the rest of the group.   I did eventually lead the team to safety, and it definitely felt earned.I will make one complaint, and it's one you don't hear a lot:  This game takes FOREVER to beat.  A ridiculously long time.  I'd say the first 50% was a real nail-biter where I was loving every second of it.  Then the next 20% I was starting to feel a little OP, but still liking the game.  Then the last 30% becomes "JESUS CHRIST WHEN DOES THIS GAME END???"It gets very repetitive in the last 20-30 hours or so, and every single battle...regardless of whether it's zombie hordes or major human "bosses", becomes a cakewalk.  But even with that pacing complaint, this is still a phenomenal game and I highly recommend it for anyone who likes the feeling of the lives and deaths of dozens and dozens of characters depending on you for survival.

number of helpful: 36 of 62 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
er 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Considering turn based games have been around for decades, it's hard to explain why this one stuffs it all up so horribly. On the surface this has a lot to recommend it; recource gathering, base building, missions and more besides, and no doubt that make might for a fun game. But the combat system is so irredeemably awful it makes getting into the game a tricky notion.The typical action point system only comes into play once you're in combat so you're free to run around until then, but once you enter combat, good Lord does the game go south. For a start, you can't attack on a diagonal, which makes precisely no sense. Square on fighting is the order of the day. Secondly, there's no way to bring up a list of key commands so if you need to change view for instance, there are no on-screen icons to do it (a staple of these kind of games surely), you're kind of stuck. The whole game lacks that kind of simple clarity. Thirdly, it's too easy to batter someone on your team (why does the game allow this without at least a simple 'are you sure?' check?). As a result, once you enter combat it turns into a farce of repeated misses with whatever weapon you have equipped (early in the game you equip a weapon which doesn't show on your character who then gets advised to equip a weapon by everyone he meets before going outside - top work!), shuffling your characters around to try and get to the right square to attack and then using all your action points hitting your own team. It's just rubbish from top to bottom.It might get better and I'm certainly going to persist playing it as it seems to have genuine depth, but it's frustrating and counter-intuitive to play. I was hoping for State of Decay meets X-Com but this falls far short of that lofty aspiration.Ho hum.

												In the modern zombie apocalypse, you take shelter with several other survivors in abandoned school to fend off zombies and not-so-altruistic survivors.The zombie-infested modern world is depicted very nicely albeit brutal, where you can see how humanity quickly goes back to being medieval.Will you stay humane in this maddness to people around you, or become one of the predators yourself, preying on the weak and abusing everyone around you just to survive that another day?You can do all that and more in this very unique RPG game with turn based combat, strategic and planning elements and lots anf lots of dialogues.It is really hard to compare this unique game to anything, except that it has been heavily influenced by older RPG titles like Fallout.All in all, this time spent reading about the game is better be spent playing the game yourself, have fun!

content:
y 24, 2015
												If you like turn-based RPG's, I highly recommend this one. I played Suikoden back in the day until they stopped making it for the European market, and the replay value of Dead State is kind of like that of Suikoden: You play through, then you play through again to get things perfect. Then you set it asside and pick it up one day when you remember what a fun game it was. I love collecting the characters, interacting with them, and scavenging. Killing the zombies is fairly easy, but battling the gun-wielding humans can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ (but that's part of the fun). I like improving my headquarters and the crafting. I like how my decision making and interactions have consequences, and I like following along with people's stories. I also have to give the developers special props for not deciding for me that the main character is hetero. That was a pleasant surprise.

content:
ry 23, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm only posting this out here due to the mass amount of trolls attacking this game for no reason as I would not recommend anyone to purchase a game that is in Early Access as there is no reason to unless you want to help the developers out with testing and feedback. 1. This is not a timed demo. The game does not expire after 7 days. The initial build is called The First Seven days because it only features content from the first seven in game days. 2. This is not a paid demo. This build is an evolution of the 3 day demo that was shown at PAX. It is a way for Kickstarter backers to get a progress report to see how far the game has come along If this was released in the condition it was in, it would be commercial suicide. It's buggy, it's crash prone, and it lacks many features. Unlike actual demos that exist for finished games, this is not a demonstration of the final product.You can either save a measly $5 to pre-order a game that isn't done and get access to content that is not even in beta form yet, or you can wait 3-5 months for the game to be actually finished and try out the public demo that will be available to everyone for free while reading reviews and make the decision for yourself. If the word "demo" was absent and it was simply called The First Seven days, then I guarantee you there would be no public backlash as the content featured here is the same as the initial Early Access builds of Wasteland 2, Blackguards, etc. As for the actual game itself, it's a very promising and ambitious computer RPG that feels and plays like one from the late 90s.For an indepth look at the game, check out my video:


YouTube™ Video: An Early Access look at Dead State 

			Views: 348		

			Dead State is an upcoming turn based RPG set during the zombie apocalypse. It is being developed by Doublebear Productions, a studio run by Brian Mitsoda of Troika fame.

												Just no.This game honestly feels like they had a beta version, went  out to lunch, and an intern accidentally released it as a full game.The combat system is mediocre, and the AI is rough. There's almost no tatical options, with the only real strategy being " beat them on the head until dead, or run away if they're stronger than you."The basebuilding aspect, which I was most excited for, ended up being extremly boring, with no customization. You always have the same upgrades, that do the same thing, and your base always looks the same.The writing, which they touted as a strong point, was okay at best. NPC interaction is trivial, and it feels like they had huge plans for it, but decided not to implement it at all for some reason.It was a huge buggy mess on release, and as they had an early access period to work through that, that was pretty unacceptable. They did gradually fix some of the worst bugs, but it took a long time and was a gradual process. Overall it was honestly a really disappointing game. It had promise, but failed to deliver on almost every aspect, and ended up being a pain to play.

1, 2015
												Overall the game is worth buying if you like a slow pace zombie game focused on group story survival. Cons:Combat mode just doesn't fit. It would work if battles were more group focused. Example if zombies fought in groups together so that on a map you would have maybe 3 or 4 major fights which you can fully enjoy the tactical control of the combat system. Currently, you will quickly grow bored killing sometimes one zombie at a time.. some maps have probably 50+ zombies; very mind numbing. Story: Whoever wrote this games story needs to get some real life experience. Don't get me wrong, the direction of the story is awesome but as soon as one part starts to get interesting the epic idiocy comes out in full.Examples without give out too much details:The group members do not respond as if the world just ended by a horde of zombies. They will try to take 'time off' for insane things like headaches, diarrhea, etc. You wouldn't tell your captain you had a stomach bug in the middle of a battle nor would you 'take the day off' if zombies could at any moment run the shelter over. For that matter, they all are pretty blah about the experience. Personally it feels like the designer got their sixteen year old emo kid to write the story.Despite the short falls it's still worth getting.

content:
er 25, 2014
												WARNING: This game starts off slow and easy but the learning curve is pretty steep. Yes, killing a single zombie is a cakewalk. Yes, the shelter occupants you start with are a pretty good bunch. Yes, it seems like once you get a chain link fence up all your troubles are over.They are NOT.The game will actually let you fall pretty far behind the curve - and then murder you. It will certainly monkey wrench your plans and will make running your shelter difficult. If you are not careful people, including you, will die in one, two rounds of combat. Don't let the simplicity of the graphics or the basics of combat fool you.Play at your own risk. :)I knew I was going to spend some time with ths game when I found myself zooming in on the map so I could see the details, read the spraypainted graffiti on the wall, and try to figure out just what story was being told with the scenery in a house that was no more important to the storyline than holding three zombies to fight and a little bit of random loot.I like strategic games, I like building games, I like RPG's, and I really liked the Fallout series of games. Any game that is going to give me a dog companion (a perk available in the game) to face the post-apocalyptic future, zombie-filled or otherwise, is going to get my attention. A shelter filled with unique occupants with interesting backstories, single player combat that I have to worry about more than my current health to survive, and wanting to see what new thing happens tomorrow is going to keep my attention for a while.IF you prefer FPS/realtime over turn based games, cannot stand bugs in games, or want the latest and greatest in game graphics think twice before buying this game.IF you like games where you go back to earlier saves to try something different, unexpected "monkey wrench" challenges to your plans, and games that tell a story I think you'll like this one.It is a travel around an area map in search of locations for encounters kind of game that has base management, personalitiy conflicts you must settle, and a humor to it.Combat, which is turn based, isn't deep but its' different. Worrying about allies panicing, how much noise is being made, and if a combatant you thought dispatched and done with will get up again to attack you as a zombie are things I haven't had to deal with in combat before. It IS a zombie game full of zombies. Slow, simple, easy to kill one. Trying to balance noise that attracts more of them against the noise made killing them isn't as easy. Neither are the human enemies you come up against, some of which can be quite challenging the first time you meet them - especially if you are underarmed or underarmored. The variety of weapons is pretty extensive. I have three hundred hours in it and I have not tried them all with their different kinds of attacks.This is a game I have enjoyed coming back to and seeing what was improved on in every patch and update. I am willing to put up with bugs to play a good Alpha or Beta game. Why anyone would want to go back to waiting months for a patch that tries to fix everything instead of an incremental improvement/feedback loop I will probably never understand. As often as this game has been updated to fix the remaining bugs and incoroprate player suggestions I'm sure I will be playing it off and on for some time to come.Think you'll enjoy it. I did.(edited for grammar/punctuation/clarity - which yes, probably all still suck and need another patch of their own.)

content:
5, 2016
 Dead State Reanimated  This is a turn-based game with RPG elements and the strategic and economic. The main character of the game is the person that we create and we can even give our own photo to the display our face during the dialogues. The action is happening in the state of Texas in the small town of Splendid and the surrounding area. The story begins shortly after the tragic plane crash in which we are one of the surviving passengers rescued by a police officer. After the introduction main story begins and we will try to survive in a world overrun by zombies. Our goal is to take care of the morale, respect and mood of our members. They provide the attitude of people towards our character, the lower atmosphere, the greater chance that they can leave the shelter. After some time, the game will introduce to us a critical moments and we will have to decide which choice is best for the group. We as the main leader we need to take care of everything, upgrading shelter, recruiting new people, trips for supplies and assigning tasks on the board. The game has a very nice atmosphere, but turn-based battle system destroys it a bit. The mechanism of combat system is underdeveloped and is too simple. Personally, I approached this game with a safe distance because I do not like turn-based games but after a few hours I learned to play and it was fine. Sound system is good but there is no voice acting. In the game you move around the map, and just as we get to the place that we want to enter the map changes in the 3D location and we can start to explore. Also, sometimes on the way we can discover the place of ambush, destroyed camps or places where you can collect the fruits and vegetables. You can travel on foot but after some time you will find horses and make a car. As for me, the game was very good, 8 out of 10, however, would prefer to make that game FPS it would have more potential. However, it is still small studio that made this game and I must admit that I spent a lot of time playing this game and I did not complain of boredom while playing, at the beginning is difficult but after few hours it gets easier because of the large amount of accumulated resources.

content:
ry 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Even in it's simple state, Dead State is the zombie game i've been waiting for. What State of Decay should've been: A zombie survival game that places emphasis on "Survival". An XCOM-State of Decay hybrid, I'd recommend this game to anyone whose a fan of strategy and/or survival games. This game oozes originality and fun gameplay, you'll be immersed very quickly into a tense atmosphere where one wrong step can land you knee deep into a horde of Zombies. The only downside is it lacks a character creation, an element that would help bolster the RPG aspect of the game. Other then that, a solid game. Can't wait for it's release.***EDIT***Since the game has come into beta, I've pumped a bunch more hours into the game and have only scratched the surface of the game's depth and content. However, one issue that I was unaware of was the travelling system; whilst the game is better then a lot of triple A games nowadays, if you go beyond 12PM whilst travelling back to camp, you die. Now, that seems quite harsh, especially with the games lack of an autosave feature, relying on you to spam that F5 every few minutes. The character creation has been implemented, but it's relatively bare right now, a lot of the features being locked and still being worked on. I imagine we'll be seeing more updates to it within the next few updates.That being said, the game oozes style and creativity, and whilst state of decay was a poor comparison with this game, it's a breed on it's own; a XCOM and Walking Dead lovechild. If you love strategy, and you love RPG's that you can make your own story to, then this is the game for you.Can't wait for more updates and more content.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
												Dead State I would say is now in my top 5 best zombie games around, even though it is still in the early stages. First would say while the game is out of Early Access, there are still quite a bit of bugs and glitches but I have not come across any game-breaking ones and the game does have an ending. But the game is still being cared for by the developers and still getting big patches and fixes every other month or so.Now that's out of the way let's start on the game. Dead State is a survival focus RPG where you play as a created character who survives a plane crash and later wakes up in a school with other survivors. The school is your main base and so the main focus is to help build it up while also going out to find supplies and other survivors to join you. It is cool that your base does change when you build upgrades and the March patch now let's survivors roam around, giving it more life-like. The only thing I do wish is more stuff you can do in the base or also the look changes based on the survivors you recruit (mainly them bringing in personal items to decorate).The gameplay outside the base is similar to games like Xcom or any squad based RPG. You go out with a max of four people and when you arrive at locations, you mostly just look for supplies while fighting off the undead and hostile living. A nice thing is you will have to use different tactics when fighting zombies then living, since the undead aren't as smart and can be dispatch faster. However the good thing is they keep it bit realistic in the sense that taking on one undead or two is easy, but taking on a big group can be deadly. The equipment in the game while plenty, sadly they are not random in stats like Diablo. Also many survivors you recruit will have different skills that can be useful both on and off the field.Speaking of survivors, Dead State is one of very few zombie games that actually get this right. By right meaning every survivors you recruit is a "person", a unique personality that can change on how you treat them. You will also get events involving them that also give them more of a background. Course another nice thing is nobody is safe, since the game does have permadeath on party members (though if your main character dies it's game over) that does affect morale. However if you have somebody that does get on your nerves, you can easily take them out on scavenging, kill them, and come back claiming they got eaten by undead. Also by them not being safe, they can also get infected if you're not careful. Luckily getting infected doesn't automaticly mean death in this game, as long as you have antibotics you can fight off the infection. So in a sense unlike other zombie games where other survivors are either as lifeless as the undead or there fates are already sealed, this game does them justice by actually making them people trying to survive with you.Good:-Plenty of survivors that join you, each with thier own look and personality-Lots of areas to explore-Realistic equipment-Good amount of content and lengthBad:-Still good amount of bugs-Combat can drag on little too long-Interface and menus could use some work on

												okay, i am going to try and give as good a review i can on this.first of all i believe people should give this game more of a try. ORIGONALY i was VERY on the fence about this game. after hearing of massive bugs and the event that went down during the steam winter sale. i was hesitant to buy this game, but then it went on sale and i thought, why not? so i shall give my reasons why i support this game and what ive seen, bugs and all.#1 the bugsYES there are many!!!! BUT, most are small annoyences that can easily be fixed OR avoided.1 corpses tend have there body model one place, but acctually be somewhere else. so if you try to attack a zombie and are confused as to why your charecter is wandering off a different direction, you know why. this bug is a little common, but it useually doesint cause a major problemb or major frustration.2 be CAUTIOUS around 2 or more floored buildings!! these tend to have lag and are very glitchy/ wonkey!! ESSPECIALLY ON THE STAIR CASES!!! SO try to avoid saveing in these areas and go slow. you can eaither take your chances or avoid them. second storys are useually rare or far away from your base. so you wont reach them till your far in game.3 charecter AI i dont find that bad. they tend to do stupid things, but i feel as long as your not running far ahead and stay close to your team they tend to navigate fine. running ahead too far makes the navigation a little confused. this does not mean you have to stick close to them like babys. you have to assume they will go straight for you or take the shortest route to you. if you run around the zombie hoard while your far ahead and your teams just now catching up, guess whats going to happen. so always keep that in mind and that your team can lag behind a little.4 random crashes. i have only had 2 (knock on wood) so far. but the game auto saves everytime you enter a area. there is also the quick save button F5 and a quick load button F9. so when the crashes do happen, they happen very quick and you can just quickly reload the game.5 so far no major lag. lag tends to only happen when a lot of zombies are suddenly aware of you or appere suddenly all together. and agian as mentioned above, in 2 or more floored buildings. it rarely happens.6 mutiple bodys on a single tile in the same position. mainly zombie bodys. useually you have to glide the mouse slowly over the stack to select the different bodys becuase they merge/ cover each other. happens as often as you let it. zombies useually tend to stay seperate unless you funnel them down a hall or something.7 dead state is not very happy with windows 8. you CAN play it on win 8, i am proof of that. but in order to play it on win 8 you have to go to the games main file and set it on "windows 7 compatability".these are just some of the most main and common bugs that ive seen mutiple times.#2now that the bugs are out of the way, time to start talking about the main parts.1 i love the charecters. everyones different, acts different, love/ hates different things. and some will ask you for help or advice and you may have to solve fights between two charecters who dont like each other.some charecters you mite even personally hate becuase of their attitude or opinions.and beware, not all charecters have good intentions when entering your group!! so choose wisely!!! or face some charecters dieing from your mistakes.2 i love the loot and moral system. there is a major morale system that you must make sure stays good or there WILL be consequences!! so you must be sure to bring back not only food but luxerys as well. toilet paper, tooth paste, books, shampoo etc.3 recruiting. unlike other games where you have all the time in the world to gather others. this one has lives on the clock. take too long to find someone and itll be too late for them. (useually the clock starts running out around day 30-40)4 leveling. when you first start you have a certain amount of skill levels to spend. chooseing between melee, ranged, leadership, negotiation, medical, science, survival, and mechanical. each time you reach a certain point in a skill, you'll get a perk. chooseing between two.there are also stats that can help things such as your health, carry weight. chooseing between strength, agility, vigor and perception.5 events. each new moring some charecters want to speak with you. asking for more supplys, to take the day off, or advice. asking if they can come with you on the next run. to tell you of a near by location. or just to whine and compain about something. some can be very major and lead to disaster, so be careful on some choices and watch how charecters act. the most major ones will require you to have a meeting and decide between a few choices. not all of your group will agree on the choices made at the meetings.while traveling you will also come accross random events. some can give you new survivors, others can lead you into a gun fight with zombies and looters. reading the event description useually gives you a hint of what will happen.-------------------------------------------------------------------------SO there you have it. the most common bugs ive seen and what i like about the game.is the game worth $30?HELL NO!! i suggest buying it when its on sale. i bought it on sale for only $20. i suggest getting it lower then $20 if you can.if your still on the fence about the game. try the demo. its basically the same, bugs and all.

content:
ry 4
												I bought this game a couple years ago, and I'm finally getting around to actually playing it. It feels like it could be a great game, it should be a great game.  Imagine my suprise when I discover that even though the game is finished, and has been for long enough that it will probably never get another update, it still lacks some very basic, and necessary features. What is it lacking? Facing mechanics.  The same reason I stopped playing 2 years ago. This is a tactial turn-based combat game. Enemies behind you are harder to detect, yet you don't have the ability to control which direction your characters are facing. Seriously? How much work can it be to add a mechanic to choose which way a  character is facing? The developer says they ran out of funds. They had enough to 'finish' the game, and Have even updated it to dead state reanimated, yet couldn't spend the time to add a facing mechanic?Don't get me wrong, I'm very much enjoying the game so far. It's just that such a simple feature being lacking after the game has been 'finished' for this long, really makes it feel like a money-grab. Adding the reanimated update, but not finishing basic features (which were initially planned) is inexcusable in my book. If I had just purchased the game, I would be getting a steam refund, but I've owned the game too long for that. I will not, however, be purchasing any other games from doublebear/iron tower.

												I know there is a lot of negative reviews about the bugs and i wasn't sure if i was going to get this game but i read some of the positive reviews and i decided to go with it.  It's a very fun game and i'm really enjoying.  It's nice to play a single player version of a survival game.  I played h1z1 and dayz and while those games are fun its really hard to enjoy the game when you get killed on sight and lose all your stuff.  I'm not in to writing a big a review of the game.  Most people have already gave a good review of it.  I'll just tell you a little story.  I was on a run and on the way back, i found a camp.  So we go check it out and start taking stuff.  Well there was people there telling me not to take there stuff.  Well i ignored them and they starting attack us.  So i killed them all and took there stuff.  Well first i beat them down and knocked them out and than did a final blow to them.  I go back to the shelter and one of the guys at the shelter told me that i shouldn't do that.  Just kill random people and take there stuff.  I told him i won't do that again but i still do it.  Another time, i got a random encounter on the road where there was a car crash.  There was a guy standing next to a dead body next to his wrecked car.  He wasn't saying anything so i wasn't sure what to do, so i just killed him.  No consequences on that though.  I think it was suppose to let me recruit him but i think it was a bug because he wasn't saying anything.  The bugs in the game aren't that bad.  Every now and than, the game will crash but it takes a long time for that to happen.  The game autosaves a lot so its not really a big deal if the game crashes.  A little annoying but whatever.  It's still worth playing and i hope there will be dlcs for the game.  If you are wondering if $29  is worth it, i would say yes.  You could wait for a sale but i didn't and i'm enjoying the game a lot.  As i get further in the game.  I'll add to my review. Overall, this game is addicting to play.

number of helpful: 12 of 18 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
22, 2015
												I have held off buying Dead State after seeing some people upset over what they felt was the game leaving Early Access too soon to benefit from the Winter Steam Sale.  I have been watching the game for a long time but decided to wait until it went on sale to pick it up.  It seems like Doublebear has been doing steady patching, while maybe not to the level some people want, updating none the less, so when it went on sale I went ahead and decided to pick it up.   I love turn-based games and RPGs and Zombie stuff so it I figured I would roll the dice and drop $20 on it and see what I got.   So far with a couple hours under my belt I am really enjoying it and I haven't ran into any bugs.  The UI is a bit frustrating at times and a couple of times I wasn't sure what I needed to do for stuff like swapping inventory.  A quick glance at the manual resolved those issues.  The game can be counter-intutive at times but counter-intutive isn't the same thing as game breaking bugs.  During my play (I admit I haven't spent a lot of time yet) I have enjoyed the game play.   It does feel like XCOM with Zombies instead of Aliens.   Yes the misses will frustrate you sometimes, but that is the genre.  The game isn't "easy" but it isn't "unfair" either.  People can fuss over if Doublebear released the game too soon as a greedy move or not.  I don't know what the game state was back in December when it launched, but currently the game is very fun.  Games can always spend some more time in the oven to enchance them, but then again at some point the game has to leave Early Access (though I have a few that I seriously doubt ever will).  But at the end of the day, is the game fun?  Yes it is.  Is it a AAA title, no.  Is the price fair?  Once again that is subjective.  From my couple hours of game time, I can tell you that I wish I had picked the game up eariler, regardless of the sale.  The normal asking price of $30 is a bit high for a indie title, but I believe it is mostly worth the price from what I have seen so far.  I have gotten less enjoyment for double the money.Game prices are all over the place these days for Indie titles so I honestly don't know what a good price point is for games anymore.  That said I based on what I have seen so far and what I have read the game should last at least 30-40 hours, so I think it is a fair value.  So in closing is the game great?  Time will tell.  Has it been fun so far?  Yes it has.  Have I seen any bugs yet?  None that I can tell, un-intitive user interface design, yes, but bugs not really.   Of course I have just begun the game so that can drastically change along the way.  If it does I will be sure to update my review.  But at this time I can say that I would pay the full asking price for the game, much less on sale.   I think the game is good.  It isn't super, but it is fun and fair.With 2.5 hours under my belt so far I would give the game a solid 80/100.

Early Access Review
								While this game is certainly in an early state, it seems impressive so far. The game is fairly simple for now, but there are a lot of features not currently implemented that will make the game much more complex. For example, there are many structures to build that show up as not being available in this demo that look like they will really expand on the gameplay. The combat is fun, and even in this early build the zombies do a good job of responding to noise in a way that doesn't make them seem either deaf or too aware of small noises. In short, if you like State of Decay, you'll probably like this game as well.

number of helpful: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
y 5, 2015
												I've just finished my first playthrough of Dead State and I definitely plan on replaying it at some point in the future. In short, I'd say that it's definitely in my top games for 2014.The game is a bit of a curious mix of survival games (think resource gathering in something like This War of Mine) set within a framework of a RPG playing quite like Fallout 1 and 2. After a brief intro sequence you are soon aware that the zombie apocalypse is happening and you are soon put in charge of a shelter in a Texas town called Splendid. It's your job to make sure any survivors (you will find many who you can invite into the Shelter) living there can, well, continue to survive. You talk to people, solve conflicts, assign jobs. And then you wander out into the world seeking resources.The game is viewed from a top-down perspective with a camera you can spin around.Gameplay:There are a few different gameplay actions you do during the game. As described above, the Shelter is your base which you need to improve. This is done via a Job Board where you can assign tasks to your fellow survivors such as building things, be a doctor, or come with you out into the field to get supplies.This is all dependant on the game's RPG system where you can invest points into various skills such as Ranged Combat, Leadership, Medical skill etc. All survivors you meet have their own set of skills (which you don't have any control over, but will continue to grow over the course of the game) which make them suitable for different tasks.There is a base management aspect of the Shelter. You need to keep it stocked with food, gas for the generator, luxury items and medical items. There is a morale stat for the Shelter depending on how well you do.The survivors also hang around the Shelter where you can talk to them and get (fairly brief) bits of their stories. You can also ask them if there's anything special they'd want from the scavenging hunts. Someone may favour whiskey, someone else a cigar. This will raise their mood. If a survivor's mood goes down, they may end up leaving you.Also, each morning there are little interactions, situations that arise in the Shelter. People may be arguing, someone may need to talk to you about something etc. Sometimes there are Crisis Events which is regarding bigger decisions in the Shelter. The characters involved will agree or disagree depending on your choices.The writing for the characters is very good most of the time. It's down to earth and believable most of the time. There are a few exceptions but mostly the writing gives the game a real human feel which is exactly what a game like this needs. You can also find "data items" which can be found in the world and decrypted so you can read them. These items vary from the Dead State equivalent of Twitter messages, medical reports, personal letters, message board discussions etc, mostly about the outbreak of the zombie virus. These are *fantastic* and present a real nice backdrop to everything that's happening.I also have to give the developers kudos for including characters with a form of mental illness. Too often in games do they treat mental illness as just being CRAZY! But Dead State does it seriously even while it may not dive too deeply into the subject either.During the day, you're most likely out scavenging with your party (total of 4 members including yourself). This is done via a worldmap travel system (again fairly similar to the older Fallouts). There are many locations to find in the game, all with varying resources, allies to recruit and enemies.The combat system is very much like Fallout. It's turnbased and may feel rather slow and clunky to some players. The combat system feels at its best when fighting against humans, it can get pretty exciting. Most of the time, the zombies are a non-threat. Individual zombies are weak and easily taken care of. Any danger that they pose comes from the being in groups. There is a noise-level system in the game, and the zombies are attracted to noise which creates a very interesting dynamic. If you get into a firefight with some humans, you can soon count on the fact that zombies will start to move towards the location of the gunshots. This creates a great an additional layer to think about during combat. You can also use this to your advantage, luring groups of zombies into a bunch of human enemies by throwing firecrackers for example.VisualsDead State is not a AAA game by any means, and it may look really crude at first. The character models in particular look fairly boring. However, when actually playing, one notices that locations in particular are quite well done. It's not high end graphics by any means but all locations manage to convey a sense of place really well. Whether it's a shopping mall, a neighbourhood of houses, a resort. They work really well actually. Animations are also pretty well done though it feels like it could've needed a few more.AudioNothing special here. The music works well and does its job. It sounds relaxing at the Shelter (except when conflicts arise) and creepy when exploring. Given how much combat there is in the game, the combat music quicky wears out its welcome unfortunately and starts to grate after a while. Sound effects feel pretty "stock", nothing particularly exciting.Other stuffMuch drama has been made about the buginess of Dead State and, indeed, I did run into a fair amount of bugs and polish issues. Mostly it seems to be certain story events and such happening out of sequence at times. There are many small annoyances also such as difficulty traversing stairs at times. It feels a bit janky at times, moreso the longer into the game you get. At least that was my personal experience.I had about 5 crashes throughout my nearly 50 hours with the game, I'd say that's pretty good actually.It also has some pacing problems. The game is pretty slow to get going, mostly due to there being few followers at the start and not much to "do with them" so to speak. It feels a bit empty. The game shines during the middle when the Shelter starts filling up, people start talking to each other and things start happening. And then the energy goes away again toward the end of the game where you've collected all the stuff you need basically. It feels more like a waiting game then for the end-game to set in. I think the game would've done well to be "condensed" a bit, especially at the end it can actually get a bit boring unfortunately.SummaryAll in all, I *highly* recommend Dead State if you know you like the types of gameplay it offers, It is extremely addictive, I found it very easy to play through just "one more in-game day". The writing is mostly great and give it all a nice sense of purpose. Like I said above, this is one of my top games for 2014, no question.However, the bugs may annoy you depending on how sensitive you are to games feeling a bit broken and janky. The devs are gonna be actively patching the game so you may want to wait a bit before taking the plunge yourself.All in all, highly recommended!

Early Access Review
								Instead of a UBER lengthy written review, I did a 16 minute video review:  


YouTube™ Video: Dead State - Early Access Beta Demo - First Impressions and Gameplay Review 

			Views: 6,587		

			This is my first impressions of Dead State demo which is available on Steam Early Access. ★★ Subscribe if you enjoy my videos!		

In it's current state, the game is lacking a story.  There is no tutorial to explain how to go about doing certain things that aren't so intutive. Battle mechanics are sub-par and don't feel like a traditional RPG (IE: wasteland 2, XCom, Banner Saga.. etc)In the end my hour spent in my first go through of the game was filled with frustration and ended with a slap in my face "Thank you for finishing the game" message when I had clearly lost.  I do not recommend you get this game now, and I would wait after final release until there is gameplay to see if it's worth it then.

content:
17, 2015
												I've decided to write a review for this game to try to curb down the negativity around this game. I've read many reviews that claim this game is awful, unplayable, so full of bugs that it's not enjoyable and after playing 75 hours of it, I will have to disagree. I'm not saying it's a perfect game or doesn't need more work and polishing but it is still a pretty damn fine game on it's own.Now as far as bugs go, I've encontered a few but not nearly as much as other people claim there are. There was one instance of a zombie disapearing and being unattackable while still existing on the map and attacking you on it's turn and every once in a while the game crashed. But other than that I've been pretty much bug free. What I enjoy about this game? An intresting story/setup where being the leader of your group of survivor of a zombie apocalypse isn't just about mowing through wave after wave of zombies and calling it a day. Taking care of your shelter and your people can be just as fascinating. The combat while not super deep has some interesting layers with positioning, noise making and panic mixed in the simple but effective turn based combat. There are some nice RPG elements added that give some replay value and I absolutely love how you can influence certain events/characters simply by the way you treat them. I also enjoy looking at the shelter evolve with time both from upgrading it but also from smaller things (food in the pantry for example) and wish there was even more of that in the game.My biggest complaint with the game as it stands is how unbalanced it is. Maybe I've just played that type of game too often or maybe I'm too "efficient" for what the devs intended but after only 30 days in game all shelter upgrades were built. At day 45 I've discovered what looked like most of the locations. And because of the perks I took I had enough fuel and food to not have to care about it for another 3 months, I had enough antibiotics to be able to shower my people with them, my fence was nearly indestructible and I had enough weapons and armor to have everyone equipped, even characters I knew full well I would never take in the field and even then I was throwing weapons and armor in the recycler despite not really needing any more parts. My overall morale was so high that I think people were happier than before the zombie apocalypse. And now I had to just pass each day until sopmething else happened. And it became a bit boring at that. So I decided to make another game where I would put myself restrictions on how much and how fast I would do things. Every day I would only go on one outing for one location only. Doesn't matter that my inventory is not even half full, doesn't matter that I'm still at full health. It sure made the game go at a slower pace and makes it longer before I'm done with everything but I find it disapointing that I have to put myself these restrictions instead of the game making me take hard decisions on what I need now and what will have to wait later. (think X-Com for instance)I also have other small issues with some desing decisions (like the inability to advance to clock until after everybody is done working) but again overall it is an enjoyable game with a good concept that I hope the devs will keep polishing and making better with time.Oh and for replay value I hope one day they come up with different maps so that people who played the game don't already know where everybody is or where important things are.

content:

												I barely ever get a chance to play video games anymore, but the new wave of truly classic RPGs are too tempting. Dead State is no exception, and did not disappoint. number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2015
												Dead State is clunky, buggy and slow near the end. It's also one of the best indie games I've played this year. A post-apocalyptic zombie game where fighting zombies is the least of your troubles, your task is to keep a shelter of ragtag survivors afloat. This means keeping it secure by building/maintaining your wall and posting guards. Keeping your food and water supply going by looting abandoned buildings (or unabandoned ones), building a well and gardens, and raising chickens. Trying to keep your food refrigerated (and stop your survivors from rioting) by keeping a steady supply of fuel for the generator. Dealing with the other surviving factions, either through "diplomacy" or force. And so on... There is a fair bit of combat, but for most battles, it's a matter of chugging through and killing everything so you can loot the map. In most cases, either your party is properly-equipped for a combat scenario (in which case you will eventually win) or it's not (in which case you will lose, probably quickly). This is a big reason the game feels slow nearing the end: you know you can kill everything, so now you need to chug through and do it. This is especially true for the zombie maps, since a "hard" zombie map is just one with a lot of zombies on it. Human enemies will wipe the floor with you in the early days, but by the end game, there are only a few encounters in the game that will give you any real difficulty. Even some of the scariest-looking ones are actually quite easy with decent equipment. So it's the shelter management aspect where the game shines.In Dead State, you have a great deal of control over all aspects of the shelter's management. You're not only responsible for meeting those basic needs (food/safety/electricity/morale) and assigning work duties, but also internal and external diplomacy. You choose which survivors to recruit, how to deal with other groups of survivors, how to deal with the various cliques in your shelter, and what to do about criminals and other crises. There are a lot of different ethical choices to make that don't boil down simply to "plus karma" or "minus karma" like many other games. Is it more wrong to turn away a survivor that you know is useless, knowing they will die, or to let them in and risk starving everyone in the end due to lack of food? What about attacking other camps for fuel to keep your shelter from falling apart? Does it matter if they are "bad guys"? What counts as a "bad guy" and are you sure you aren't one? :)Anyway, despite the bugs I thought it was worth every penny. There is a free demo available, which is the full version of the game with a limited number of days, and if you like the demo, you can carry your save over, so if you're curious there's no reason not to try it out.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
26, 2015
												I recommend this game with a few reservations.First, it's not for everyone.  The game can be very repetitive.  Managing a group of survivors and locating resources to build and feed everyone sounds fun, but what it amounts to is little more than going from one area to another, clubbing everything to death, and putting all their food/fuel/ammo in your inventory.  Then doing it over and over again.Second, the combat is not very good.  I found it poorly paced.  There is a very basic early game, middle game, and late game, but the jumps between them seem don't transition well.  It's all based on armor, really.  Having better armor suddenly makes you immune to so much damage.  Combat pretty much boils down to doing the same thing over and over again, with very few interesting mechanics.Third, the game is not paced well.  This goes hand-in-hand with repetitive.  There are very interesting storylines and elements, but there are large bouts of nothing followed by sudden bursts of activities, particularly close to the end where there bouts of nothing become longer and longer.  The game could use a BIT more activity/story.With all that said, this game is interesting, fun, and contributes to the genre in a much needed way.  The devs are actually patching/making improvements, so I consider that a strong plus as well.  Some bugs remain, but they're definitely working on it, and I didn't run into any major issues (although a few annoying bugs were present).  I enjoyed leading my group through some tough situations and exploring post-apocalyptic Texas, meeting new people, and exploring a variety of environments.  There is some difficulty in building morale/food stores in the beginning, but this is actually fun and contributes to the difficulty of the game (something that is lacking at a certain point).One final word.  The game has some political (ridiculous conservative/Texan stereotypes) elements to it.  If you're sensitive, you probably won't enjoy this game.  It was  bit heavy handed at times, to be honest.  Still, I enjoyed this game overall and would recommend IF you have a high tolerance for reading text, doing repetitive tasks, and some amount of "roleplaying".  You should also, of course, really enjoy the genre as well!

content:
2, 2015
												Bought Dead State on sale.  Wanted to get it based on the demo and that it is squad based.  However, given the comments didnt want to pay too much.  Even in the Demo saw how annoying bugs could be.  Overall, I have to say a resounding thumbs up for the game though.  It is exactly what I wanted and hence however many hours in I am through the game I felt it fair to let others know who like me have been on the fence.  I like squad based tactics and so I am really most interested in the scenarios for getting supplies.  I like the combat and even enjoy just turning up while I fight is already going on and watching two looter groups fighting it out with each other, attracting a load of dead guys and then being overrun by them.  I then clean up and take all the loot!  Excellent fun!  I also enjoy the tricky encounters, usually where better armed looters/militia control an area and arent interested in parlaying.  Surprisingly I have also enjoyed running the shelter and developing my character in order to do that.  Admittedly the shelter begins to run itself after a time and you get so much food and luxuries that you could hold out until armageddon but it is a nice touch.  Havent got the lab yet but everything else is done.So why wait until on sale?  It is still bugged.  It is a little annoying to see your guys walk through a locked door!  Or right through a car.  Also frustrating to not be able to get to loot which has been placed in a position that is inaccessible (rare though).  Early on (possibly demo) it was real annoying to have killed a guy taken some excellent loot only to get back to the shelter and it had gone missing and no I didnt forget to pick it up.  I think the worst faults, so far at least have been in the hotel  in Austin.  Great idea, real enjoyable combat, difficult and demanding.  But moving between floors is a real pain.  Could it not have been made a bit easier?  You will find it almost impossible to move up or down unless your players are in the right position but you cant move your players to get into that position.  Having one person in the right place should be enough then an automatic move.  If you enjoy squad based tactics (old school xcom not the new) and you woul like to try something different then this game is worth getting, you just need to work out what price you are willing to pay for it.  I got it at £14.99 and that was fine for me, under a £10 get it no questions asked.

y 13, 2015
												Honestly, the game is very disappointing. The amount of bugs are ridiculous. First off, this company should never have taken it out of "Early Access." Even at this point, major bugs still exist, some even game-breaking.The combat is relatively fun; although, extremely simple. You might get bored at the lack of options or variability in combat. It gets old quick once you hit the 100th zombie with a sledgehammer. Late in game, the armor you acquire pretty much puts the game in "God Mode." You can take 10 bullet wounds from a sniper rifle and only get a modest amount of endurance/health points removed. "The Shelter" was a well thought out concept, but executed poorly. You get very little, if at all, dialogue changes from allies. Allies in "The Shelter" are pretty much just nice looking statues. The situations that arise in "The Shelter" are so few and far between. At some point in the game, it becomes a literal waiting game whereby you just pass up days because every location has been scavenged, all the upgrades built, and no new shelter crises arise.This game honestly feels half-finished, so much so that there is a major quest line that an ally gives you that is impossible to complete.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												Dead State has so much gristle and fat and not much protein. If I were more willing to save time, I would have wrote a review condemning the game's length and amount of Monty Haul gameplay - because you have to scavenge SO MUCH in this game. Of course, this means going around to all the various places in Central Texas, dodging every zombie and murdering every looter to fill up your backpacks with as many ramen noodles and luxury items as you can carry. TIMES INFINITY. I wouldn't mind if there was more to interact with in the world (and there really needs to be more stuff to do to break up the monotony of scavenging all the time), because having to loot gets so damn boring after a while. I ended up skipping entire days towards the end of my playthrough because I was really sick and tired of having to go out and ♥♥♥♥ing pick up the groceries. And I hated not being able to delegate this task to the two or three people sitting around in the shelter once all the improvements were built. This mechanic, while it fits in really well with the world falling apart and even adds an 'Earth Abides'-style flavor to the proceedings, drove me up the ♥♥♥♥ing wall and onto the ceiling, down the wall on the other side of the room, and back. Like a really angry hamster determined to get out of his cage.So why didn't I just quit the game and play something else? Here's why - this game has some very, very interesting storytelling. When people talk about this game being a spiritual successor to games like Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines and Arcanum, they're talking about the solid storytelling. Brian Mitsoda (he worked on Bloodlines and Arcanum) and two other people made this game, and Brian did such a damn good job with the writing that I kept going despite hating what was going on with the game. And that storytelling is what held my interest throughout the entire game - I nearly could forgive all the monotonous scavenging if it meant more lovingly written, well-researched bits about how the world fell to the zombies, about astronauts losing their ♥♥♥♥ on the ISS, interactions between survivors, between militia groups, between the outside world and the little emotional ecosystem going on in the shelter. Those moments were beautiful and fun to experience.I really had to fight to finish the game, both inside the game and outside. The scavenging took such a mental toll on me, but the storytelling kept me coming back for more. I don't doubt that this is going to be a cult classic among RPG enthusiasts, easily joining the ranks of the great RPG games that don't work all that great but have such wonders to show anyway.You know what? To hell with it. I recommend this game, but  only if you bring several audiobooks or your backlog of podcasts to go along with it. If you don't, the monotony will drive you crazy (unless you're one of those mutants who runs around in a field to beat up slimes so you can grind your way to one-shotting Sephiroth at the end, in which case there is no hope for you). It starts out strong and ends strong, but everything in-between moves so damn slowly I nearly quit several times. You've been warned.

												I'm a really big fan of these "scavange, fight, build you base, and prosper onwards" games. Thats why I got Dead State after a few days of it's release. It had a lot of bugs. HAD. Because the developers cared for their game, like  mother for their child. They got rid of the bugs, listened for feedback, and added a lot of content. It's not an Uncharted 4, or a Battlefield 1 graphically but if you were looking for something like that, you actullay wouldn't be here. This is and Indie game, but has a better story, with more replayability then most AAA games I've played so far. You can aproach sitations always in at least 2 ways, but usually more. There are no class restrictions. You can switch your weapons and playstyle anytime you want throughout the game. There is resource managment, making sure your allies have everything they need, and the story can really twist your head around, and make you look foolish for thinking something way differently am hour ago.If you play 5 hours, you will eventually play a houndred. So please, go, buy it, and eventually, it may become a cult game. Then we'll get a sequal :3

content:
3, 2015
												EDIT: Review was initially negative (no "Mixed" rating) and, although it is annoying as **** at times, its taken me over 125 hours to start getting bored of it and its the only game i've played for the past 3 weeks or so. So...yeah.Get it only if, like me, you're really into zombie-survival based games. If you're just on the fence about it I suggest you don't.I'm not criticising the turn/AP-based gameplay - that worked fine in Fallout 2 and such but somehow falls flat when zombies are introduced.-You will ALWAYS be ambushed by a zombie hiding around a corner as you walk into a room-You will ALWAYS be ambushed by a zombie hiding just out of view inside a house as you walk in since you can't see into buildings until you walk inside-There will ALWAYS be a zombie to infect the looter you ko'd but didn't manage to finish off - instantly turning them undead and introducing another enemy-There will ALWAYS be a looter shooting a gun like a moron and attracting all zombies in the map-Zombies will ALWAYS screw you over instead of the looters that attracted them-You will ALWAYS get ko'd when your medic isn't around-You will ALWAYS get pinned to the ground by a zombie when alone-Your allies will ALWAYS panic and run away - leaving your guy to fight alone when all of you could of taken out the lone zombie-Your medic will ALWAYS overheal when they panic-Your ally will ALWAYS get downed by a zombie in the doorway making you unable to move past and take out the zombie eating him-You will ALWAYS miss when you can't afford to-Your guy will ALWAYS miss when he has only 1 bullet left in the magazine-You will ALWAYS miss with a 95% chance to hit-You will ALWAYS miss 5 times in a row when it only takes one hit to finish the enemy off.Phrase of the day with this game is "Oh for f***s sake...."Seriously i've played this for 12 hours so far and achieved nothing because something always screws me over. All objects in a 10 meter proximity of me are not safe from my regular game rage.Bit I wull stull plae eet cuz i liek zumbees n luuting nd sirvaval

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2015
												Now it's been sometime, I'm posting a new review in place of the old one back when it was still in Early Access.I've been very interested in this project since it first appeared on Greenlight and have been following it's progress. It's a turn-based zombie survival game where you manage a shelter and have to deal with many harsh situations that may happen based on the survivors you have as not every survivor is as steady minded as you could imagine. Some look for love in the wrong place, others are mentally disturbed (due to what has happened and the situation you are in now) and you can even recruit animals to the shelter which give their own moral bonus, but also eat into your food supplies too.All the characters in the shelter have their own personalities. Some can even point out new locations where there would be a large storage of weapons or food based on their life before the disaster struck. Some can be very likable like the Loving and helpful Renee or others will be blunt and emotionless like the officer, Vic. There are multiple endings and hours of replayability with the many different dialog trees. I have not yet completed the game, but I have gotten far into it and built everything in the shelter, of course trying to gain enough food and fuel on each excersion to keep moral up becomes difficult with more people.Now I'm not going to say the game is perfect. There are still bugs in the game and issues where bodies will share the same square, however the dev team are still working on this game and want to make it the best experience for all of those like me who are craving for a zombie survival game where you are responsible for the survivors and all the survivors have varied and interesting personalities.If you are still uncertain, I'd suggest playing the demo to get a good feel for it. It has that wonderfully nostalgic feel of Fallout 1 + 2 as well as Wasteland.

number of helpful: 64 of 120 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
er 10, 2014
												Firstly, Dead State is a diamond in the rough.Let me say that I don't relate to people who fiercely defend titles and developers where the products are incomplete or have problems.  I've seen fans who jump onboard and immediately shout down anybody who has negative criticism of the game.  I pay for (and expect) quality, and really struggle with the new era of gaming which puts the public in the chair of tester.Having said that, I really enjoy Dead State.  A *lot*.It was formally released early December (about a week ago), and there are still a pretty wide range of improvements that could be made to the game.  The thing is, even without them, the game is fun.  It's quite immersive .. insofar as it pulls you into the story and the concerns of your survivors.A lot of games try to achieve immersion these days - but they have some kind of false idea of what immersion means .. making a game grindy and laborious may be exactly how it feels to chop down a tree in real life - but you soon get bored and realise it's just a game. What Dead State throws at you is relationships and a foundation of morale and needs that drives them, and then lets you try and survive in an open sandbox in Texas.Scavenge, deal with zombies, deal with friendly and hostile survivors, try to satisfy the needs of your community - those are the basic imperatives of the game.People interact with you, there are branching conversations - a very significant amount of dialogue.On the downside is that some elements feel a little unpolished.I find the combat to be fun and tense, and the environments you nervously scavenge through to be beautifully drawn .. but the combat mechanics themselves feel a tad simple and unpolished.  People have complained about lack of stealth, cover .. and yeah, I agree - there are some of the tactical systems in the game that could use a second look.What would that achieve ? It would take a GREAT game and make it a WONDERFUL game.Game is still very good in it's present state, I recommend it.

content:
4, 2015
												For those who are into zombie-apocalypse games, this game is a welcome new addition. You survive a plane crash and are taken to a shelter which you must lead. The goal of this game is simple: survive. Every day will be a struggle - there are many threats in this apocalyptic world of Splendid, Texas. Not so splendid anymore.The game is both a Fallout-like RPG as well as a turn based management game. You are in charge of managing a shelter which means gathering food, building upgrades such as fences to keep zombies out, finding survivors who may be able to help you get to safety, and dealing with crisis events such as a gang threatening to destroy your shelter. Each survivor has different areas in which they contribute to shelter management and it's up to you to manage the resources. In addition, there are conflicts and events that happen every day and it's up to you to deal with them.If you know Fallout's combat system, then you will know Dead State's combat. All in all the combat is relatively easy - but there are a few encounters where you will literally be in war against a small army of guys equipped with military gear and assault weapons so don't take everything for granted.The looting can get repetitive - it's pretty much kill everything, search containers, grab as much as you can and clear area. Combat is *usually* very easy, but there are modes this game has that will make it oh so much harder. And also, be very careful of what you say to fellow survivors. It takes just one bad statement to make them absolutely hate you. But this is a stressful time, after all. There's an achievement for rescuing all the survivors - some found randomly. All in all, it's a good game, and I recommend it. 7.5/10.

content:
, 2015
												So apparently, zombies are faster, have more powerful attacks, and have a better chance of hitting you than you do of hitting them. No matter who you select for your first party, its like watching the three stooges try to fight the undead. Miss, miss, miss, get eaten.Zombies can also sense you if you are directly behind them. No sneaking allowed.Also, they have 9 action points, which is as much or more than your starting party members. Which means they can shuffle much further than you can move, while apparently getting free or almost free attacks, which is infinitely better than the 3-8 AP required to attack them.All of this topped off with the fact that your weapons hit them for 7-25 damage, up to about 50 with the sledgehammer. This is out of a 50ish HP pool they have. Top that with the fact that they can hit you with anywhere from 7-62(?!?!?!?!) HP, after shuffling as far as you could move, out of your 90-110 HP pool.In a nutshell:-can't tank them-can't kite them-can't evade them-can't sneak past them-must rely on luck to beat them-if you don't outnumber them 2 or 3 to 1, it has a high probability of a loss.When the devs manage to botch what I heard was a good game before "Reanimated", they're pretty bad at their jobs. Instead of increasing zombie count or something to make it harder to just sneak up on all of the zombies, they made them super-zombie killjoys. 3 party members vs 3 zombies, one of the party members being a COP (you know, trained to use force against violent, unpredictable subjects) and a member speced to be a melee monster. All 3 die. Why? Because bad game.Un-**** your game, devs.

content:

												This is one of my favorite games. I love what they did here with their approach to survivor management. So much fun to recruit, utilize, and manage so many personalities. The conflict and the factions set up throughout the game kept me engaged and wanting more.Admittedly, there's far too much combat that gets far too repetitive over time and the inventory management is a complete drag once you have seen all of the item variations a few times. Playing in iron mode is cool in concept, but this game is far too long for me to risk losing all of my progress based on a few bad rolls. If consequences were less immediately dire or potentially game ending, I'd hop on it in a second. I was fine with losing some people through story events or even in combat late in the game once it was clear that I'd be able to finish it. The ending was disappointingly sparse on how the characters made out, but the journey there was well worth while to engage with them on the way.Crazy fun. Want more.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
er 17, 2015
												Dead State can best be described as Walking Dead Meets Fallout. With Brian Mitsoda of Vampire The Masquerade, this story driven game will let you decide if you are either a LaMOE or a Crusoe in this zombie shelter game. The story takes place shortly after you wake up in the middle of a world that has gone to hell in Texas. After the cops found you and stitched you up along with two other survivors. You are tasked with at first making sure the shelter doesn't fall apart and take responsibility for the people that you choose to bring into the Shelter and make sure they have enough fuel, food and parts to get through each day in one piece.As a zombie shelter game, there is notably less "railroad" situations where you will ineveitably lose allies. Theoretically you can end the game with every survivor alive and well when you finish the game unlike in State of Decay which ineveitably have you lose people to the zombies wherever you like it or not. That said, it's freeform so you can choose to be the few beacons of hope in a bleak genre or choose to bring out the worst in humanity as you kill those that are useless. Leave survivors to die or do internal purges after a mutiny by sending any member who was loyal to the mutineer to a suicidal march.Combat wise the game plays like Fallout and Wasteland, an AP system that allows you to move and engage your enemy with a diverse perk system that gives you your own perks as well as other members of the shelter who have their own contributing abilities to the shelter.The cast of survivor is a colorful mix from old war veterans, to an geek who uses the Fremen Battlecry or the avatar of Brian Mitsoda himself. Picking which survivor to come with you is important as some are illsuited for battle while others have limits to how far their moral compass will bend. A hint to know if your survivor has no qualms beign raiders is their attitude in combats. The more rough ones swear like a Borderlands player character and makes a nice addition to your motley crew of survivors.Replayability sadly is lacking, while i had reservations about playing it again the lack of fulfillment in some endings have made me think otherwise for a great zombie shelter game.Overrall I recommend this game for those who want their zombie survival fix.

number of helpful: 9 of 14 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
y 17, 2015
												Dead State is... Let us say, a strangely designed game. When you start to play it, for the first few hours, it is very interesting and engaging, if you, like me, can disregard very outdated graphics, somewhat clumsy interface and occasional bugs.At first, survival feels really hard. Every day, yout scavenging party goes out to find food and fuel, and usually can just about bring enough of both back to prevent Shelter from dying outright, but not enough to feel safe. It's a real struggle and it feels interesting. Even more interesting are dialogues with your fellow survivours.Unfortunately, it seems that time or other constraints prevented DoubleBear team from really completing this product. When you finally find horses that allow for faster travel (and, therefore, for two expeditions per day!), you beging to gather more food than strictly necessary for survival. At this point, the second part of the game should begin, but it doesn't. Most of the important events are tied only to day number, not your actions. And since survival is no longer a day-to-day concern, you start to feel bored from clearing same-looking supermarkets, houses and camps.The problem is compounded by many bugs in many scripts. People do not notice completed quests (thankfully, this mostly goes only for minor tasks). People disregard events that already happened. People give you information about locations you have already visited. The worst moment, however, came when one game faction reportedly wiped another, but when I came to their old site, they were there, along with a duplicate of character that came to Shelter with the news of disaster!The ending, when it comes, seems rarther aburpt. There are a number of endings, some of them more anti-climactic than others, but I must say I'm not very satisfied with them.A few words about combat. It's not particulary good, but it's not particulary bad, either. The dead stop being a serious threat quite soon, but armed people remain a problem nearly to the very end, especially in large numbers. AI is bad, but it doesn't matter too much. (And at least it's better than in JA: Flashback). I'd say the combat is on the par with Wasteland 2, which is not saying much, but it's not awful.Despite everything, I had fun with this game. I liked exploration and texts, even when they were bugged.  I wouldn not recommend it for everybody, though. You have to be tolerant of crashes (fortunately, quicksave is VERY quick!) and bad graphics. Still, I feel like a lot of love was put into it, and it shows, even if the end product is somewhat mishappen.I'd say you should wait for patches, but so far there was only one, and with the number of crashes, I'd expect the developers would try to hurry with fixing at least a few of them, so I do not have high hopes. Still, even with all the bugs, I managed to finish the game, so at least it's better in that respect than pre-patch Arcanum was :)

I duly recommend this game.

content:
, 2015
												Dead State is a great turn based game with a hardcore survival aspect to it. You have to recruit as many people as you can while you feed them and equip them for the hard times ahead. You also build up your base AKA the school and there are tons of upgrades for your school from a chicken coop, garage, farm and so much more. The part that most people complain about is they cant keep people happy or other stupid morale problems they may have(they lack people skillz). Just like in real life not every one you have in your town will see eye to eye about certain topics because the game is gonna throw a lot of random events at you that you need to deal with to make some people happy or even angry with you. There is perma-death if you are sloppy and get one of your guys surrounded and 3 or 4 zombies drop down on him for a quick snack you can beat he is getting back up but not as a human. Other complains I have read is that people think this is an alpha but your wrong the developers love this game and you can tell because they are always updating and fixing bugs for you. Come on they just released a nice update not to long ago and some companies would have made it a DLC but not these guys. There is also crafting, anything from armor, weapons, and even upgrades for your car once you get there. On top of that your played character is fully customizable from the way he looks to what kind of skills he/she has. You want to be a medic sure, you want to be a bad a$$ with a sledge hammer max melee skill, computers, gun skill, and a ton more. I have 86+ hours and I still haven't cleared out all of the areas on the map and even the map will throw random events at you. If you like zombies turn based hardcore survival games this will be right up your alley. This screenshot is just a taste of all the thing you have to do in 1 day to make sure sh$t doesn't hit the fan.http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/46505482712255338/9C4AD90CA32930F607A8FF14229CD4C93F55E3BB/And your people can only carry a certain amount of weight so deciding what items you need are crucial for your survival.

content:
er 22, 2015
												First things first: Just like anchovies or hot sauce, THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE.  TRY THE DEMO BEFORE YOU BUY.  The demo will give you a good feel of whether you will like the full game.	Even though I hit the "Yes, I would recommend," button—this is more of a mixed review. (I wish there was a middle option.)  Dead State requires deep thought and sometimes a touch of research.  There is more than one way to play—but you have to figure them out.  Although I personally liked going back to get my stats just right for my personal play style in the demo, not everyone will enjoy doing so.  This is not meant to be an easy game for those that want to just smash up some zombies for an adrenaline rush and gore fest. The game isn't something I'd recommend for the player that just wants to have some easy fun.  It is quite the opposite.	The game isn't very forgiving of mistakes and the right answer isn't simply handed to you.  Options are limited, negatives for the team are abundant and the player character is the only fully customizable ally.  You're forced to work with what you get, even the other survivors.  There is no “hone my skills to perfection by grinding first” easy button.  This game is meant to intrigue your mind and push your planning abilities.  For those hard core players that want to nitpick the details and get things just right, I'd say download the demo and dive in.  The save files even carry over from the demo.
