content:
, 2015
												Dead State.  What really should be an indie darling hasn't quite managed to come into it's own.  Let me clarify: the game is interesting, challenging and, depending on your definition, fun.  What I consider the core issue is that it was built with the same engine powering Age of Decadence.  Why is this important?  Well, Age of Decadence is a rather unique RPG and it's engine was tailored for what it offers.  Since Dead State is a more traditional SRPG I don't think this engine choice has really done it any favors.  Add onto that a shoestring budget and you have a game that can't quite meet it's own aspirations.  Like directing a B-movie you decide where to sacrifice to realize your project and I fear Dead State may have sacrificed too much.Before I get into why, I must explain why I recommend this game: If you are looking for a more classical take on zombie survival that takes its cues from pen and paper role-playing experiences with a heavy emphasis on character interaction there's a good chance this one is going to be memorable to you.  And for that alone I can give it a strong recommendation.  It isn't a bad game and it stands in opposition to every zombie game that focuses on little more than re-killing them.So why the longer review?  Largely because my recommendation matters only if you understand at it's core it's a budget product and it shows through in every single place you look.  Combat, for example, is fine if you imagine it like a board game (it plays like one) and use your imagination, but everything feels so static many things would be more compelling in a book: "The zombie lunges for your throat!  Luckily you push it aside!"  The game is a very spartan affair with simple animation and a barebones audioscape.  While you undoubtedly get into situations that will feel genuinely tense: it's because the premise is done very well and not because it has compelling on-screen activity.That may not bother you at all but for me it's hard to get past when larger issues arise in the continuity and premise.  Many things are presented so matter-of-factly, completely accepted and moved on from without any involvement from the player despite the emphasis on character interaction.  In a story-focused and character-driven narrative this is hard to overlook.  Take the very premise of gameplay: you run the shelter. Sweet, but while you very well may be a competent leader, it's handed to you with nary an objection or conversation despite being just some person they rescued from a plane crash.  The shelter is already established, everyone already knows each other and you are the total stranger.  Yet they immediately hand you the keys and let/ask you manage it.  You can literally ask people, "What can I get you to make life easier around here?" immediately after waking up from a head wound! You've yet to come to terms with the plane crash, let alone the strangers explaining everyone is now flesh hungry monsters who only want to kill and eat and your first activity is to get out of bed and build a fence?  Where's the character building here?  It's a classic case of reading the script and all the characters are in on it, this isn't a living intro: it assumes you know the plot of the game and provides an intro to hand wave off your history.  Nothing more.Yes, this is somewhat moot once the game opens up A LOT in the following days and it hardly ruins everything but it strips a lot of personal motivations from you.  You might be the main character, but your motivations are not just at the behest of the writer: you're expected to co-opt them wholesale without the game bothering to give you a chance to justify them to yourself.  For example, if the shelter was being run so poorly you NEEDED to be the leader, or the previous leader was a scheming psychopath or even if you just STARTED OUT as a member of the shelter during their first night, fine, but there is at least one if not TWO or THREE characters with leadership characteristics there when you wake up and yet they concede their positions immediately.  I hate to get so caught up on this but it really did bother me.I could easily dive into more criticisms like these but it really is a matter of engine and budget.  If you know the history of the project and engine, this is likely the best Double Bear could do with what they had.  It is a refreshing entry in both the RPG and zombie genres, framed from the perspective of the people surviving and their relationships, but its presentation makes it feel ten years out of date and the mechanics don't make up for that.  While I recommend it, you need to know what you are getting into beforehand.

Basically the mixture of rpg, survival and round-based strategy is a nice idea but there are some clouds covering the sun here.I'm not talking about the grafics which are okay but about some big design problems. The menus are far away from intuitive. it takes hours to manage your inventory ♥♥♥♥. Sometimes I feel like doing my taxes instead of playing a game.The game is also sometimes annoyingly complicated. After the first mission I searched for a place to sleep for 10 minutes. I clicked right and left on every bed until I finally found THE ONE I could sleep in. I mean the game shows you a perfect straight street on a sunny day and you're strolling around with your party and suddenly 5 zombies appear in front of you ! Have they been invisible ? Can everyone in your party only look into 5 meters distance ? Same counts for weapon range. I can throw my keyboard farther than these guns can shoot.Best joke is to heal somebody. I was wounded and found a complete, full medkit. Nevertheless I could not heal myself because you need to put the contents of the medkit into your medic satchel to heal someone. number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
y 21, 2015
												I've put a lot of time in on this game, I was one of the kick starter backers who wanted to believe but was soemwhat jaded on the promised returns even at that time. The Truth: This is an old school isometric RPG and is faithful to that lineage. It is hard as balls (unless you want to save scum) it's not terribly intuitive to start,  and the graphics evoke a very specific "little bit dated" style.Now with all that said, if you are the sort of person that has fond memories of about fallout 1 and 2. The Baldur's gate series and a host of others in that game you are going to like it. You've been weened on hardship and know how to savor when things finally come together after the sting of perhaps some very bitter defeats.The Good: The game is a faithful re-imagining of old school iso RPG's. Yes it trades on a lot of nostalgia but there is also a lot of solid game play and interaction here. There is a wealth of stuff to explore  and characters to balance out and it feels like you have quite a bit of freedom to grow. You can pour hours into this game and have extremely knife edge victories against serious odds. The crisis events and other things pressed on you are interesting and add a definite personality management aspect.The bad: The games interface is clunky, inventory management is a PITA (pro-tip you can manage ally inventory fromt he main shelter inventory, not just your own). Likewise it really really needed a means to check an ally's overall stats from the main shelter screen. I suspect this was an intentional design decision but it hurts the game more then it helps my immersion. Poor combat scaling: Don't get me wrong I like that if you bring a knife to a gun fight you'll get your butt kicked but on the other hand melee feels really under whelming even when you've crossed the distance through the hail of gun fire. Conversely guns start out awesome and just stay that way sans noise and ammo concerns. Lastly the game really really needs (and at least thus far I havn't found) some sort of trading mechanic to get goods you need for stuff you have a surplus of. I've got arrows, bolts, and certain types of ammo coming out of my ears but so far have found a grand total of one stick of deoderant and one box of sleeping pills.The final verdict: If you have the patience for a bit harder experience then seems to get mass produced in some of the hand holding games today you will get a fantastic return on investment from this game, well worth the 30 bucks or less if it's on sale. If you don't then you will probably end up not liking it.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Let me start with this, I have owned this game since it came out because I love the concept of it. I started playing at the initial release, but I did not get into the game because, quite frankly, I was overwhelmed by its complexity. I tried again a couple months later, but still did not get into it. I saw that the Reanimated edition was released and finally dug into the game, giving it the time it deserved. I can now say that I love this game and am 100% addicted to it!This game is complex, difficult, and so SO rewarding. It's been said before, but this game is basically Fallout 1&2 plus X-Com plus Walking Dead. And this combo works so amazing! Sure it is not perfect, and could use a little more polish, but the game is so much more than the sum of all parts and is one of the best gaming experiences I had in years.The negative reviews on Steam seem to all complain about the morale system and/or the bugs. I can't really speak to how the game was before the Reanimated edition, but I will say there was only 1 bug that I ran into. It was a dialogue bug that happened during a random encounter, where the guy I knocked out was talking the same text as he said when the fight started. I hit him one more time with my bat to kill him and that solved that problem... I didn't see any other bugs, which is impressive considering the scope of this game.As far as morale... this is the end of the world! It is supposed to be difficult to keep a group together. I struggled through at first and had to make some rough choices about whether to kick people out of my group or not (which I did). But as you progress, it is possible for you to make things work. Overcoming these obstacles is so much more rewarding.  The people that complain about morale are essentially saying the game is too hard, the end of the world isn't meant to be easy and I wouldn't have it any other way.In closing, don't let the negative reviews keep you from trying this game. At the least, download the demo and dedicate enough time to it so that you understand what this game is all about. Once you do, you will find a gem of a game that you'll love and find nearly impossible to put down.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2015
												After having kickstarted then played through this game nearly three times in various phases of developement I'm amazed this title still sits as "mostly positive". I imagine that a lot of the negative or neutral reviews came in while this game was still in developement- the occaisional crashes, corrupt savegames, noise radius, and other issues have largely been hammered out (my last playthrough of over 120 hours contained none of these issues to memory). This is a great game. Comparatively on the level of the first 2 fallout games - there's a deep crafting tree, a large amount of replayability from the skill tree/dialogues/npc interactions. You play as the lone survivor of an ill fated plane in Texas in the opening weeks of a zombie apocalypse engulfing the world. Boarded up in a school with a handful of other survivors from various walks of life it quickly engulfs the player in the tasks of figuring out basic needs in the new world (security, food, fuel, medicine) while also providing the unique challenge of managing your survivors' happiness and other needs. There will be conflicts that arise both internal and external amongst your group and every NPC that you come across will stretch your party's abilities as well as its needs. As a result, especially on the harder modes- which is the best experience, in my opinion, you will be forced to make decisions regarding what new members bring to the group versus the resources they consume and potential conflicts they bring. The dialogue, of which there is a good amount of, is well written and each of the many NPCs have well written backstories, motivations, and unique needs.   Tied in with the NPC interactions are a series of events that occur- some random, others timed, that move the story forward as well as challenge your settlement. Ultimately, this is a game that moves past the traditional RPG/survival genres to ask the player how they would treat others in such a scenario. This topic is also examined in various lights by your NPCs with their backstories and actions. Aside from being a well made, polished, and excellently written game there's one thing that I've cited as a reason to purchase this game- choice and causation. Rarely in games are there cascading events where one choice by the player leads to both scripted and unscripted outcomes that were unforseen. To be more clear, each playthrough of mine has brought about events and outcomes where "savescum" tactics would not work because your choices and outcomes were determined hours or days ago. This game provides a multitude of such occurances. It's hard to explain how glorious this is without having played the game suffice it to say that those that appreciate the "what ifs" will play through the game at least a second time.  TL;DR: Played through game 3 times since early developement. Worth the price at $60. Buy it if you have any appreciation for survival/rpg/writing. Watch for this studio's future releases- this is an excellent and so far, it seems, underappreciated game.

er 7, 2014
												I've followed this game before I even bought it and I'm pretty happy with the content, I've played this game from beta 4 until release. There is still room for improvement and the Devs see it and will update the game as time goes on. The combat in the game is turn based, if you are careful you can avoid combat completely. The NPC interaction is what I really like, I hope they add more personal quests and crisis moments. I'd also like to see more base upgrades and research, and interaction/events once you get the upgrades. With so many people at the base late game there should more options to allocate the survivors and missions/crisis tied to those.In the future this game could be a 10/10, right now it is a 7.5/10 for me. ***SOME POSSIBLE SPOILERS** The best moment for me so far was when I was on a scavenger mission with fresh survivors, I walked into a downtown area, it looked looted so I decided to proceed with caution. While my team was looting I decided to send one of the survivors to scout the area... and then I saw it... the park...  shards of metal everywhere and what looked like an elderly woman and a man impaled to the benches, I quickly gathered my team, but it was too late a heavily armed raider group got the drop on us. They knocked down the scout nearly killing her, I rushed the rest of my crew over to save her life. Fire, metal and blood, flew through the evening sky, my combat medic rushed over and secured the downed survivor.Things looked like they were changing... then the boss came out. Our pistols and bats did little to slow him down, and we were surrounded. I suddenly remembered my melee specialist was holding on to an assault rifle and my ranger happened to have the ammo, we were able to take out the raiders one by one, my melee specialist picked up a shield off a dead raider and rushed over to deflect incoming fire while the scout and medic found cover, my ranger managed to pick off the last raider, and we managed to walk away with no casualties, hardened by the experience and the new equipment.

content:
y 30, 2015
												I slacker backed Dead State.  I then promptly forgot about it.  So I only started playing around the time Patch 4 came out.  So I started from then.Warning - This is a game that will be somewhat ruined by reading Wiki's first.  Allies have stories, and sometimes they can be unpleasant.  If you cheat and read about it in advance, you will lose a lot of the enjoyment in the game.Gameplay - Interaction.  There is a lot of interaction between you and the "Allies" it adds a lot of flavour, and lets you like and dislike the allies.  The Events are pretty regular, and generally pretty interesting. It can be a little repetitive, and hard to know when something new is available to talk about.Non-Allies.  I don't know if I am doing something wrong, but every survivor group I meet seems to attack me.  Sometimes I miss the warning messages in the bottom left of the screen, which means I keep goign when someone has warned me off.It would be nice if there were more groups willing to trade with your group, but not join.Gameplay - Combat.   Combat is quite a simple turn based affair.  There is some complexity with it, in that you do have a reasonable selections of weapons, there are several tactics that can be used in different circumstances etc.   Important to not however the Zombies are not the true danger in this game.  It is the living survivors who will try and kill you.  Zombies quickly become easy kills once you work out how to avoid notice and whittle them down.  They can still be dangerous in numbers of course, and if your allies get bitten they can be infected, but overall they are not a great concern.  Some of the complexity comes into drawing enemies into each othrer. Throwing a fire cracker to attract any Z nearby right into the middle of a group of violent looters. Fun.And the gun toting loonies aren't easy either.  Well at least not the first time you meet them.  Once you have some better gear it becomes less of a challenge.Bugs. - I haven't come across any game breakers.I did get the pleasnt oaks hostile email howerver.Overall I am loving this game.  I recommend it.

content:
, 2016
												Dead state the game with potential that just simply falls short.When i first saw this game i thought it would be a great game with micromanagable features to make everyones experience different and in a way it is but there is so much that is missing in this game to make it really great. First of all if you are buying this game hoping for a breeze then you are FAR FROM IT. This game is challenging. Not just challenging but almost unplayable at points due to the general difficulty right from the start. Now i played this on its base difficulty with no \"iron man\" or \"survivor\" options enabled and this game is still ridiculously hard. Don\'t get me wrong. I love a good challenging game, it makes me feel alive and puts me to the test. But this game takes it way too far as after a good 9 hours gameplay i still feel so weak against everything. I had 3 fully equiped survivors out on a mission but we got stuck in a room and only one could fight at a time meaning that the endless horde of zombies waiting very politely outside the door ended up getting the better of me ONE BY ONE.  Not only is it hard when it is supposed to be but the features it lacks makes it even more fustrating. Want your guys to take cover behind an obstacle to avoid missle fire? Nope. Want to climb on top of a nearby building to escape a zombie horde? Nope. Want to simply trade an item within your shelter to a friendly survivor? Nope. These are just many of the infuriating events that can occur to you and happened to me basically every event. However this game isn\'t all bad. If you feel inclined to challenge yourself to the point you regretably put a hole through your monitor than be my guest because this game has so much to it and can be so much more. I just think that for a \"survival strategy\" there has to be some element of strategy other than just luck and using the right weapon. Unfortunately the good outweighs the bad for this one so i simply can\'t recommend :(

content:
y 4, 2015
												Overall a fun game, I haven't finished it yet, but I'm at the point where there is no challenge.  It blends a few concepts well, and while I found the game overall very fun, I do have a few issues that I think keep it from being great.  I may not play it again, but I would definitely be interested in a sequel or the same concepts taken in another direction.  If you combined most of the concepts of Dead State and State of Decay into a 4x, I think it would be a very interesting game.7/10 ++Map design, can't say enough about this, it truely feels like you're living in a zombie apocalypse.  From the wrecked cars, ransacked stores and homes, trails of blood, graffiti on the walls warning of zombie inhabitants, to the somber reality that many will simply take their own lives in their houses with their loved ones.  Double bear did a great job setting the environment++Moral choices, did a great job here.  You have several dialog choices, when I made my decision it seemed to be something I would say in that situation.  NPC's that join your shelter will remember dialog choices you've made with them and bring them up in future conversations+Crisis and random keep it interesting, hostile human NPC's can be turned against zombies--Game is to easy, once you get past the first few days, other humans are the only real competition.  They are easily avoided, or distracted, and you can come back later and whipe them out with better equipment--Item durability, nothing breaks, leaving you with stacks of items and weapons.  You can recycle them in later stages for parts, but I prefer a more realistic game and would like things to break and have value--Useless items, there's a large variety of weapons and items, but I spent 80% of the game using aluminum bats.  Zombie s would die in two hits and most humans were no problem, even if they had guns.-Micromanagement is pretty bad starting off, but gets a little better.  It gets annoying having to run to the storeroom to swap items, the job board to assign tasks, and the exit zone of the shelter to reach the map-Map is stagnant, no roaming hordes of humans or zombies, once you clear an area you have no reason to return-

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2015
												Dead State, is a great game. It uses an isometric view, turn based combat and base building/management NPC interaction system.The plot has so far been excellent, with well written background stories for NPCs. The dialogue, and the interaction really makes you feel like you're dealing with the daily problems of life in the apocalypse. You must scavenge for supplies, repair your base, and upgrade it, But you have to deal with the people you care for as well. Keeping up moral, finding personal items they need, while assigning them tasks and job schedules around the base.The interface at first seems abit clunky, but took me very little time to get used to it. The sound & graphics, while not cutting-edge, are done very nicely. One thing I'd really like to point out, is the areas you visit while looking for supplies or running errands. Every map area, tells a story if you look. Very impressively done, for example I was looting a local neighborhood and every house every block, you could see the damage or the carnage and piece together what happened there. A car slammed into a power-pole, the trail of blood as the driver tried to escape to a house... The door smashed, his body half devoured in the doorway ! Just little stuff like that seriously adds to the ambience, and feel of the game's setting.I also would like to point out the leveling and skill system, is well done. You really do get the feeling that each level is really going to help you survive. You don't have to reach level X before you can survive on your own ; each of level you gain does give you the sense of accomplishment. And so far most skills, that I've gained/used have a purpose, have a use that just might keep you out of the hands of the Dead for just another day...The bad... The game does have some bugs. I haven't really experienced anything to severe, or to frequent to prevent me from playing on. So far I crashed once, loading a save-game. Just once, and reloading the game and reloading the save went fine on the next attempt. I know there are some odd dialogue mix ups that others have had an issue with ; But so far I have not.Over all, a well done game that is enjoyable.

content:
ry 24, 2014
												Dead State often gets compared to Fallout but I think that's unfair to both games. It doesn't have Fallout's dark humour or intricate combat system but what it does have is a fairly complex shelter management simulator. Basically the game is about managing your squad, your resources, your shelter upgrades, and all the survivors who are working in the shelter when you go on scavenging runs (including the shelters overall morale and each survivor's individual mood).A fairer comparisson would be State of Decay or Jagged Alliance 2 (the original). The game isn't about your character surviving in a post apocolyptic world but about a group trying to scrape by in one. The turn based tactical battles are not an end in themselves, they're mearly a way to get more food, fuel, parts and medicine so your shelter can survive longer. Your character levels up but you have no personal goals: it's all about keeping the others happy, alive and away from each other's throats.If you liked State of Decay (but thought it'd be better as a turn based strategy) or loved Jagged Alliance 2 (but wished it had zombies) then this could very well be the game for you.

content:
ry 15, 2015
												Dead State is a survival/horror RPG with strong base-building elements set in the zombie apocalypse. (Think Fallout Tactics but open-ended with a strategic/resource management layer). As the elected leader of a small group of survivors, you must go on runs for supplies, locate and rescue other survivors, allocate resources and gradually build up your shelter from a bare-bones school into a fortified complex. You must constantly deal with not only the hordes of walking dead, but perhaps more importantly, the living, who in many cases are even more dangerous. Everyone you find has their own story, their own motivations, priorities, and attitude towards life and what is happening out in the world. As your shelter and group grows in size and reputation, people will eventually begin coming to you, leaving you with a choice as to how to deal with them. Letting in everyone may seem like a good idea, but eventually you will have to deal with the personality conflicts that arise between certain members of your group. Threats to your survival will arise both from the outside and from inside the shelter itself, forcing you to make tough, black-or-white decisions about how to deal with them. Food shortages, supply shortages, morale problems, and epidemics of disease are daily specters. Do a bad job in dealing with these issues, and other strong-willed members of the group may decide to challenge your leadership, putting you at risk of being thrown out of your own shelter.Combat is squad-based, turn-based, and tactical. Traveling to any of the game's many scattered locations to scavenge for supplies invariably results in hostile encounters with the both walking dead and rival groups of hostile scavengers or survivors. Each member of your group has a specific set of skills that may make them suitable as a melee fighter, ranged combatant, or combat medic, and it is up to you to equip and assemble your squad with those things in mind, using whatever weapons, armor, equipment and medical supplies you have managed to scrounge or manufacture. The pros and cons of various weapons and armor, the layout of external obstacles and the internals of buildings, and proper noise management all play into getting your scavenging team in and out of dangerous situations alive and, hopefully, with backpacks full of badly-needed loot.The game does have some interface and gameplay issues, and there have been alot of reports from users about crashes as well as glitches and bugs ranging from annoying to game-breaking throughout the game's release history. Personally, at 60 hours/50 game days in, I have not encountered anything more than a few minor glitches that, while annoying, have not seriously impacted my gameplay, in addition to a few isolated crashes. Luckily, the devs wisely included an automated bug-reporting tool with the full game that will allow you to notify them whenever there is a crash. I would advise anyone who buys the game to backup your save files just in case something catastrophic happens. I will admit that the game could use a few more updates, in my opinion, but more in terms of things to be added or modified rather than fixed outright. Overall I feel that the basic mechanics of the game are solid, providing a compelling and realistic simulation of trying to lead a group of survivors through the zombie apocalypse. I definitely recommend it to anyone who enjoys open-ended RPGs or turn-based strategy games.

												Even when it has some bugs (enemies shooting through walls, enemies passing through walls for example) after near 70 hours of gameplay and having ended the game i just can recommed the game to everyone into RPGs and Zombies. This is not a zombie bashing game, its a survival experience, where you manage and develop your own community of survivors, with all the social and survival problems. Social aspect of the game is not very developed, and in the end it becomes very easy (once you have a good set of weapons and armor zombies are a joke). Game ended at day 85 but i didnt have anything else to do since day 79.Anyway, as i said, its a good game that can keep you entertained for several hours. Its not the definitve zombie game, but fans of RPGs, turn combat based games (not as good as X-com) will enjoy it.

content:
r 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Early Access Review:Single Player, Turn based, isometric, dialog heavy RPG, with resource management, a world map with near a hundred tactical locations on it and a central hub/base which can be upgraded.Plays a lot like if Fallout 1/2 & Jagged Alliance 1/2 gameplay were mixed with Walking Dead's story. Also reminded me of State of Decay, but with turn based combat instead of 3rd person realtime, in that it focuses heavily on upgrading a shelter, scavenging and dealing with NPC allies along with external threats. Dead State is centered around the "Shelter", a school that the player's allies have fortified, The problems the player has to solve are both internal and external, NPCs have problems with each other, shelter upgrades break down or NPCs want to know what happened to their loved ones or people they knew. Then there's external threats in the form of hostile factions that the player can negotiate with, antagonize or even wipe out.  So far I've encountered 35 recruitable NPCs who have their own story to tell if I ask them, or sometimes don't ask them. Every morning in the game there's invariably one or two people at my room's door wanting me to either deal with a problem or to provide me with a new location on the world map to explore. One of the central game mechancis though is Crisis Events, which deal with large problems that the entire shelter's population wants solved in one way or the other. Diplomacy by the player can help persuade NPCs that the player's decision is the correct one. Or the player can choose an option that pleases the most people to increase the mood (personal) and morale(entire population) of the Shelter.I also like how easy it is to mod the dialogs in this game. So I can fix problems or change things that I don't like which is always a plus.I recommend this game for anyone who's a fan of old school RPGs.

I will say this though, this is a good zombie turn-based game with a great story behind it, and I am glad to have backed it up with my very early access purchase of it.

content:
y 14
												In the game of attrition, there are no winnersAt the moment of writing this review, The Steam page for Dead State Reanimated rates this game as mostly positive and that is how I would rate my experience playing it: For every great thing this game does, it is usually followed by a major flaw that undermines the Dead State’s overall impression. If you like to play modern RPGs like Mass Effect, The Witcher 3 or Dragon Age, chances are you won’t find this game enjoyable. But if you fondly remember old RPG classics, like Fallout 1 and 2, or Baldur’s Gate series, and you’re armed with patience then you will enjoy Dead State… most of the time. Allow me to dissect this game for you (no pun intended):Pros:+ Good overall writing and gameplay+ Tactical and satisfying turn-based combat+ Interesting noise level, survival and experience system+ Decent sim management gameplay while in the shelter, with various resources that need to be balanced+ Lots of diverse and unique allies that will join your cause, each with different personality, wants and demands+ Strong level design and good, albeit simplistic artistic and graphical presentationCons:- Game has a very sluggish pace with unavoidable grinding- Quests are far and few, mostly fetch-based and primitive- Disappointing end game content- Thrown weapons are unbalanced- Combat rounds can drag on and game is plentiful with annoying bugs- Limited lore and zombie tropes make the game world a very uninteresting place to reside in- UI and inventory are needlessly complex and counter-intuitive- Minimalistic sound and music design serve to the detriment of game’s atmosphereDead State was made by many creative individuals, including Brian Mitsoda who was a writer for the legendary game Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines, and that means the writing in this game is constantly on a high level of polish. All dialogues in Dead State are well written, as well are many data items you’ll find as you explore the world, which carry poignant and memorable articles to read. Nearly 50 allies you’ll have a chance to meet are all well-rounded characters that will follow you on your adventures or help you build more things in the shelter, if you are on their good side. But the off trade is that they don’t evolve as in other games with fewer companions that are extremely well-written and change dramatically as the game goes on. You are stuck in a world overrun by zombies, and you’ll need people, resources and the main headquarter to survive. The Shelter you find at the start of the game is an interesting concept, as it can be upgraded in order to provide a bonus to protection or a new type or resource against the overwhelming odds. There are many resources in the game you’ll have collect if you want to survive another day: food, fuel, spare parts and luxury items all grant mood boosts to you and allies, and keeping them well feed and taken care of is very important, otherwise they’ll fall into depression, inner-struggle and violence or will abandon you completely. That is why you’ll have to collect as much resources on your travels as you can.While you travel on the map, you’ll encounter many settlements that may be peaceful, but usually want you dead. All levels in the game you visit are well designed with many small and welcoming details developers could have easily omit, and add a lot to the overall atmosphere of the game. You’ll have to watch on the amount of noise you make, measured in decibels, otherwise you’ll attract the restless undead to your current location. You can also use the noise to you benefit, by directing zombies to the dangerous living enemies, while you wait out their clash to end and scavenge the remains of the battle. The living are the most daunting enemies in the game, as most of them liberally use firearms that can easily incapacitate you and your allies, and make a lot of unnecessary noise. Zombies on the other hand serve as an obstacle and a nuisance, since they are slow and their attacks are limited. However they can infect you if you are not careful, slowly leading to your doom.Leveling system in Dead State also differs from other RPGs: you only gain experience by surviving another day, and securing as much resources as you can. Surviving battle encounters yield you no experience, but you do get from it various traditional weapons and firearms that can be upgraded in the shelter to be more precise and deadly.  The combat is similar to first two Fallout games, where your positioning, use of a correct weapon on a correct enemy, and wisely using your skills and setting traps and snares are key to your victory. The longer the combat prolongs, chances of your survival diminish significantly. But there is a negative side to this type of combat: turns can slow down as more and more enemies enter the fray, human enemies can go dumb occasionally and move around not knowing how to get to you. Thrown weapons such as grenades break the careful balance of all weapons in the game as they can be flung so far, that if they are aimed at you, you’ll have no option from protecting yourself from their devastating effects.Biggest flaw of Dead State is the slow pace the game is developing and the main story is resolving. There are no traditional quests, with self-contained stories to tell and dramatic impact, only simple list of things to do for you or for your allies. And almost all of them involve annoying fetch-me–this and fetch-me-that demands. The number of encounters on the global map is limited and when you discover them all, you’ll have nothing to do but to wait for the end of the game to begin. And the amount of grinding you have to do is staggeringly bad: everything that is not nailed to the ground, you’ll have to pick up at some point. Your and allies’ Inventory will fill up so quickly that you’ll be forced to go back to the shelter to unload everything you’ve found and then return again to the latest destination to haul the rest of the stuff. This kind of pick-up-deliver-pick-up-again philosophy drags the entire pace of the game down and your enjoyment as well. You’ll also struggle with bafflingly illogical interface: how to split objects in your inventory and move them around, how to access the inventory of the vehicle, how to access skills you can use in combat and how many steps you have to take to assign your allies daily chores to do. And if that doesn’t drive you crazy, a letdown of the end content, the final battle and abrupt endings will leave you wanting for more grandiose conclusion. Music is un-intrusive and forgettable, while sound effects are minimal and underused, thus missing the chance for them to aid in building more memorable atmosphere and emphasize the dialogues and emotional bonds you and your allies share. Still, for me Dead State manages to be an overall mostly positive experience. I wish this kind of game wasn’t settled among zombies, for me one of the most overused and least interesting/frightening horror tropes and it is too bad that the game didn’t try to change and evolve our expectations regarding zombies. But at one point in the game, pressured by many choices, good and bad that I’ve made, and combat encounters I’ve survived and will have to endure, I started to adopt the ruthless survivalist way of thinking without even noticing at first. As I always want to play and do play as a good guy, this game made me aware of how enjoyable it can be to be a bad guy once in a while :D Thus I give it a cautious recommendation to the fans of classic RPG games and zombies, but I’ll also understand anyone who finds the amount of flaws to be a bit too much.

content:
16, 2015
												I only played Reanimated, following my usual rules of giving games at least 6 months after release to solve the main problems. I finished the game, fairly completely, maybe missing 2 or 3 characters due to time, and I also saw two of the possible, positive endings. As an experience, one of the best games I've played in a long time, coming close to the original JA2 experience and surpassing it in certain places. Played on highest difficulty levels, but not iron man (I have a job and a family...;-))Pros: For this gaming genre, a very refeshing theme. Early game captures the survival aspects well, with shortages of people, food and equipment. Interactions between characters are quite deep, with serious and not obvious consequences to your actions. The game is not afraid of serious issues and does not give easy answers. Zombies behave like zombies in combat...be careful and quiet, and they are easy kills. Writing is very good - I especially enjoyed the final discussions after one of the endings, and the little touches from the characters. Combat is fun, and you feel a strong progression in skill as your stats and weapons improve. Humans are a significant challenge early game, with military almost overwhelming, but only difficult in large numbers at the end. Lots of easter eggs! The RPG codex was a highlight...Cons: The base building aspect is over by about halfway through the game. I would like to see many more options here, as even the weapon options are not that interesting. I am not sure if I missed something, but several directions seem to be undeveloped, particularly related to some of the skills people have. There were some very interesting possibilities sugggested and an obvious ending or two absent. Still a few bugs in the quests, especially when you do them out of order. Even at the highest level, infection is too rare. Having more infections, but with the possibility of cures or longer term suppression would have balanced it better. You must take your own character on missions. This makes a combat build important early on.A great pity that an unfortunate early release and negative feedback seems to have killed future games.

ry 25, 2015
												I haven't played for too long and while I will agree with most that this game has potential I'm starting to wish I had saved my money.  Combat is already getting REALLY repetitive whether it be bandits or zombies.  Equipment and inventory is a hassle and I can't believe it's as interface unfriendly as it is.  The shelter just has people standing around even if you assign them jobs and nothing really feels alive.  All of these complaints may seem mundane but when they add up it feels like a game that slowly lulls me to sleep or frustrates me.  If it was $10 i'd say sure but for $30... I feel let down, especially with all the die hard reviews saying this was good but it feels too much like an old game with half the personality.   I remember playing Baldurs Gate 1 and 2 and even Fallout 2 and was blown away at the time by the story telling.  Not only does Baldurs Gate 2 look better than this and that's a title that's MUCH older, but it's less buggy and the world felt more developed.  I put in many hours just to get my moneys worth but I believe DoubleBear rushed this and dupped people into buying an incomplete game which was vastly overpriced.  Sorry DoubleBear, I know some Devs on your team put their hearts out into this, but when it all adds up it just wasn't worth it.

content:
ry 24, 2016
												Many of the other reviews have already said it: the game is more chore than fun--and that's further reinforced by a clunky UI and stale writing (not bad, mind you, just stale). Combat--which might be expected to be the highlight--is generally dull and poorly balanced (on hardcore at least) with zombies/looters almost invariably sensing you from behind, with no stealth emchanism to sneak up on them effectively--and then even with a three-on-one in close combat the very real chance one of your members will take serious damage, as you whiff far too often from point blank range. Combine this with the sparse mechanics, like the noise level, which is poorly explained/clumsily executed (compare with Invisible Inc's alarm meter, or Thief's noise gem, both of which clearly and intuitively provide information while being stylistically coherent inside the game world) and you get a scenario where you can neither effectively sneak around and loot nor effectively tactically engage foes.Base building and management suffer from an abundance of materials as opposed to a scarcity (not necessarily a problem, in and of itself), but it gives more of an impression of inventory management and 'finding x item to keep y character happy' as opposed to a struggle to survive, quickly lapsing into tedium,Sadly, like so many other turn-based games of the same ilk, Jagged Alliance 2 came along over a decade ago and set the high watermark that so very, very many of these games have broken themselves against over the years. Kudos for the effort, but zombie games aren't exactly a scarce genre, and many of the others, from low-fi indie gems like Rogue Survivor or Neo Survivor, through mid-rangers like 7 Days to Die, all the way to high-gloss AAAs like Dying Light, pick aspects and do them better.I don't think this is a 'bad' game, and I applaud the devs for the effort, but I'm really not motivated to play something this tedious when there's already a definite feeling that rewards for the invested time will be minimal.

content:
er 21, 2016
												TLDR: After a considerable number of playthroughs this game is easily one of my favorites in the RPG-zombie genre. Play it if you're a fan of survival RPGs with story, zombies, and base building.While it certainly has its flaws, it is rather well made and features a fairly compelling narrative in addition to some engrossing turn-based gameplay and survival challenges that, especially on the hardcore setting, is still difficult even for expereinced veterans. On top of all this, it's also fairly true to the classic zombie lore of films and TV. There's no super-zombies, no 'special' zombies, and the later-game difficulty comes more from other humans--just as it should be.Upgrading your shelter is rewarding and you get to see the fruits of your labor build up over time. Survivors whom you rescue grow stronger over time and you get to (somewhat) influence their growth, deal with their tantrums and moods, deal with allies who get bitten, and so forth. While the story is entirely scripted, there are a lot of events that trigger based on certain conditions, and that makes no two playthroughs exactly alike.The biggest disapointment is the AI, and by extention the way zombie turns are managed by the engine. Most enemies will simply charge you head on, even though they have no chance to win, although there is simulated panic. There are numerous pathing exploits that make some of the harder missions too easy since you can't step over an incapacited body without killing it first. Worst is that some of the larger levels / larger zombie hoardes can take ages to resolve a turn or complete the level, making it a tedious chore that involves a lot of waiting.Still, no game is perfect, and this one is better than most.

content:
10
												Dead State Reanimated has a lot of heart. But I only recommend this title to people with a lot of time and patience on their hand. Dead state combine several types of games into one. It is fascinating to build a community and fill it with survivors of the zombie apocalypse. It is awesome to explore the numerous characters backgrounds and affect how they continue their stories under your leadership. You also get a fleshed out RPG experience, where you get to equip and level up as you go along. Exploration is also done quite well, in that you explore the surroundings around your little community, to find resources, allies and an abundance of enemies to kill. There are a certain beauty to the turn based fighting mechanics, which is done on painstakingly designed locations, which each tell a tale of the zombie apocalypse. There are small random encounters as well, but even those are also quite varied and unique in nature. This is truly where the game shines, as every place you visit will bring a new setting to explore. You even get to collect snippets of the events leading up to the apocalypse, which together tells a rather fleshed out and chilling tale of how society broke down, from numerous points of view.Sadly this game is not without its flaws. Most prominently, it shows that there wasn't enough man hours to make this game truly stand out in its genre. I really liked that there is a larger story in Dead State, which leads to several endings, depending on what resources you have collected, and how you have interacted with survivors on the map. But the pacing of this story isn't working very well, and it is rather glaring that the development of your survivors storyline simply stop after a couple of weeks in the community. You are also likely to run out of places to explore, on the map, long before the ending comes around. The same goes for projects in your community which simply grinds to a halt. I feel like the developers intended to flesh out this part of the game too, but never got around to it. It is obvious that there were plans for more endings, which was sadly cut out. And the endings we were left with really should have given us more than they did. Basically, this game would have been far better if it had ended around its halfway point. I played this game on the highest difficulty, which should have forced me to make hard choices on where my resources and skill points would be placed, while I struggled to get to one of the endings.All in all I enjoyed this game. I would definitely buy an expansion, if it came with: More fleshed out dialog and character development. More locations, specifically locked away, until the late game, along with more types of advanced enemies and maybe a bunch of boss battles. More projects to explore along with more ways and choices to improve the community. Make the hardest difficulties a struggle to complete. But most importantly, make the endings more engaging as well as better fleshed out.

content:
8
												Dead State offers a pretty unique combination of turn-based tactical RPG battles (along the lines of Fallout 2, Jagged Alliance, XCom, etc.), exploration, and base/resource/personnel management that makes me strongly recommend this game. It scratches an itch that few other games get near. A good comparison would be to imagine XCom if it had much more primitive, clunky, unpolished combat, but more more involved base management and open-world exploration.Pros:+ The game bills itself as an "apocalypse simulator" and it delivers on this. Rather than going off in a sci-fi direction with the zombie apocalypse, the game is almost disturbing realistic is how people interact with each other and the problems you face. Your main threat (after the first few days) isn't the zombies at all but looters, biker gangs, rogue soldiers, decent people willing to do anything to survive, and even your own party members. In addition, you gradually find little "data items" throughout the game which gradually reveal the backstory of the apocalypse. Once again, it is almost disturbingly realistic in terms of how people really act.+ The presence of both zombies and hostile humans in missions offers the possibility some interesting tactics like luring zombies into attacking your enemies. Also, you never quite know what you will find when you go out exploring.+ If you like management games, you'll like how you have to worry about your base's food, fuel, morale, interpersonal relationships, and many other things that you need to keep your eye on for your base to keep going. Resources are scarce (at times), and you'll definitely be agonizing over certain decisions. This is often the aspect of games like this that gets cut for the sake of making a more exiciting action-oriented game, but I like having the management aspects there. Cons:- A lot of things about the UI, controls, and information displays could have been done better. It feels a bit like the 80s when you realize you've got to have a sheet of paper or spreadsheet handy to keep track of which locations you've explored and where you've left some resources that you couldn't carry home. You'll have some frustrating moments where you accidentally throw a grenade at the wrong enemy or accidentally bandage an ally who doesn't need it due to the clunky controls. You'll be grumbling over how clunky and time-consuming it is to manage your base's inventory and equip your party members. These things sometimes make the game feel like a beta version that should have gotten a full makeover before release.- The game starts to stall out in the mid-game when you are well-equipped enough that zombies are no threat and you get to the point of just wandering around exploring random locations, and most of the time you don't find anything interesting that you haven't seen before. I can't complain too much about this, though, because it took me dozens of hours of play before I got to this point.- There are a few small things that are very frustrating in how they were implemented. For example, there is a crafting system to make ammo, but the resources required are absurdly high. Another example is that your main character (who represents the player) has to go on every single mission and is not permitted to heal/craft/build at the base while others go out exploring--effectively meaning you *must* make a combat-oriented character. These kinds of things can detract from both realism and gameplay.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2015
												UPDATED (and rating changed)Not recommend at full price, if it's on sale, get it if you are open to the overall ides.Also please read the comments for updates!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!This is not a terrible game, actually it is a fun game to play and I like it.It just does a terrible job at selling it's strengths!The overall idea is nice, of course nothing new, but still I like it. "Tactical" Combat, Ressource Managment, Exploring, Survival, role-playing and npc-interactions in Zombie-infested apocalypse, if that is something which intrigues you, you may have a nice time with it.But alot of the stuff put into it feels unfinished and/or falls flat when it comes to utilizing it's potential, especially the combat, which is sad, but it shines in other (very well hidden) aspects.Combat in general:The combat, one of the main parts of the game, since it happens so often, is lacklusting. One of the most often used tactics is being seen as early as possible, since enemies almost always got the first attack, so you want them to see you early so they first have to get close to you, spending their action points for moving, instead of attacking. Of course this tactic fails when it comes to human enemies with guns.The lack of a stealth system is imo a terrible design choice. You can't sneak up on anybody/anything, at least not without initiating combat a few tiles away, so that you may have at least one (normal) attack on a chosen enemy, which wouldn't be that bad, if wasn't for the high amount of APs you need for your actions. At this point I can only utilize this "tactic" with my main char, since all other survivors are almost literally useless (too few APs, low skill values).Also the special attacks are just not optimized. For example, there is an attack called flurry which executes as 3 attacks with 30% reduced accuracy, but on my Main char it costs 6 APs, while the normal attack costs 2 (reduced costs for high dex), so instead of using my APs for 3 attacks with normal accuray, I can could spend them on this "special" attack with reduced AP. Just wow, I am amazed.As wrote above, generally enemies move/attack first (if you don't want to waste APs to "counteract" this). That also happens when someone reanimates as a Zombie (which is a cool mechanic in general btw). Ko'ed NPCs can and will be attacked by nearby Zombies, thus getting infected. They die and come back as Zombies. But why do they have to have the initiative then? They come back and can immediatly move and attack someone. Again imo another bad design choice.The Gunfighting: Mostly you wouldn't want to use guns, since they make too much noise, thus attracting nearby enemies (which is btw one of the good things about this game), but nevertheless there are moments you don't care much about noise, but how it was executed is just not good. Reloading takes an insane amount of APs, it's 7 (out of 8) for one of my fellow survivors, who was a Sheriff before the apocalypse hit. Okay, I get it, reloading just takes more time than shooting at something, but how translates this former Sheriff almost not being able to hit a human-sized (zombie) target less than 5m away to realism?! Not everyone has to be a good shot, but seriously?! Imo it would have been better if gunfighting was given some more love. The only advantage of using guns, instead of melee, is that you don't have to close the full distance to your target, that way saving some APs, but that's it. Attracting nearby enemies and the scarcity of ammunition are good mechanics/design choices, everything else...not so.Inventory Managment and Looting: It's tedious. Beginning with not being able to check the skills of your people while browsing your storage, but sadly not ending there. It would have been nice if you could change chars on looting screen, when not engaged in combat.Another irritating thing is that sometimes the standard action on ko'ed looters(NPC enemies) is "attack", instead of "loot/search". Via right-click you change the desired action, but why it is sometimes loot and some other times attack, I still haven't figured out (see comments for update)UI:It lacks "Tool Tips", those informations you get about items, skills and so on in other games, also a nice addition would have been a clock display, speaking of, maybe it isn't necessary, have to figure out first, if time passes when exploring an area. In all else regards, it's nothing special, just essentials.The used font also is a problem. On higher resolutions it's too small and the color makes it hard to read. NPC interactions: Fleshed out well enough, even if it may not appear so at first glance (even some ingame days into it), but after some more time you'll find many possibilities to interact with NPCs in various, entertaining ways.Stability: On my system (which is quite stable I may add) the game isn't stable at all. 7.7 hours into the game and it crashed 3 times already, which is something I could excuse if it was a brand new title, because you can't rule out something like this on a diverse platform like the PC, but that shouldn't happen anymore after being for sale for month. (see comments)Last words: It really isn't all bad, despite what you might think after reading this, at least I enjoy playing it, though I believe it to be shy of it's potential and and the price tag is just a tad too high imo. If you are into this kind of games get it for a reduced price when it is on sale (20€ would be okay I guess), though in my opinion you won't be butthurt if you bought it at full price, just don't expect a new standards setting gamechanger.

content:
er 10, 2015
												 - Some really interesting bits of writing - Too many NPCs bug you about nonsensical things ("Stop taking me out into the field!" when I'd never actually done that) - Combat has few tactical options. You can't take cover or delay your action. - Too often you are forced into ridiculous fights (15 zombie on a narrow road with the only exit on the opposite side) - During a fight, the active character cycles between EVERY character on the entire map. Even if they're not active or near you. In some maps, after your guys take a turn, it can take almost a minute of just watching it cycle through zombies that aren't active and do nothing. - The turn order is useless for know when a specific enemy will move since their portrait is only loosely related to their in-world model - There's an option to show which containers on the map can be looted (most can't). This is off by default, and turns itself off each time you play - There are horrible glitches in how it renders area with multiple levels. When on a map like that you will often see people floating in air, or have the ground below you disappear - You can tilt the camera, but only very slightly which makes it hard to see certain areas that you want to move to - You can get "Status effects" like poisoned, bleeding, etc. These are shown by an icon, but there is no tooltip when you hover over them so you have to look them up in the manual. - The pathfinding is bad. It will show that you can't reach an area, but if you click a few squares at a time, you'll get there - If you want to move to a square that contains a corpse, you need to carefully target around the corpse. - Having the Science skill means your melee attacks inflict Poison. What? - When looting it shows you how much you are carrying, but not how much you can carry. - The game maintains a To Do list, but even when you complete them they will often not be crossed off - In combat, facing is important but you have no way to change your facing - Weapons have special attacks, but there's no way in-game to see what they are. You have to go read the manual.Overall, it's unpolished and unfinished. If you can get it on sale, it's still worth picking up and trying. I wouldn't pay full price or recommend spending the time to finish the game once it starts to drag.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2015
												This game proves once again — to make an immersive game there's no need to have an AAA-game engine. The most important thing is the story. Here you have the Dead State, where story unfolds before your eyes, and you really feel how you become a new leader of a small community during apocalypse. Yes, most dialogues become repetative soon, but in the mornings you always have some situations happening, and you need to make decisions which affect your gameplay.You need to keep your small society happy, fed and safe; you may set tasks on job boards, and recent game update made it so that NPCs are actually animated basically, and it adds some immersion too.Pros:- Interesting random situations, good decision-making game- A great mix of Fallout/Wasteland2/Fallout Tactics/XCOM and even... The Sims :) Turn-based combat and real-time movement, when time is running only when you want it to run, makes gameplay run smoothly, at your own preferred pace.- Good dialogues, not very short, and not too long — you won't get bored reading them- Immersion is greatCons:- Some repetativeness in NPC dialogues- Some UI issues- I had couple of glitches and CTDs while I was playing, but fortunately there's a quicksave and autosave function- Background music is great, but it is repetativeFuture suggestions, although the game is in it's final state, I see that devs still actually change some things:- It would be great if there was some voiceacting involved :) - More randomness to the radio? Dynamic news?- Ability to send additional scavenge parties without the leader?- Loot balance? I'm on my day 31st now, still can't find any DVDs for recreation room, while I have lots of DVD players :)

content:
1, 2015
												 Gotta say I love this game.  This is what Indie developers can do when they work hard on a project they believe in, and see it through to the end (....>..>  Looking at you Rust and others)  Anyways if you like either Tactical games, or zombies, or sandbox games, or exploration games, or shooting dem bad guys, or just scavenging your enemies bodies for cool new stuff then you must buy this game.      To simplify, this game is an strategically more detailed XCOM but with Zombies instead of aliens. Thik of it as "XCOM Enemy Unnown - Zombies Ultimate Survival Edition" if you will.  I mean freaking zombies, who doesnt love zombies.  Global defense isnt your goal, but Survival of you and your fellow survivors that matters. So build your Base Defense the best you can, keep your people safe, especially while you are out looking for weapons, food, fuel, water, a can opener..... (lol) etc, you get the point. Oh and zombies, I Mean Freaking ZOMBIES!!! DUDE!!!!!    Combat is tactical and turn based, youll want to weigh your options if you come across zombies or people. With zombies its a choice of "Do I wanna take em down quietly one at a time with my axes, knives and such in melee risking return/counter attacks or do I want to risk the noise and pull out my .12 Gauge Semi Auto Shotgun and get it done fast with no chance of them getting even near me.  Also using a party member as bait works well to, just dont use anyone you actually like because you can expect them to survive long enough that you learn their name but thats about it, hes gonna die in a mission/trip or two.   Now with humans its a whole other ball game, are they friendly or hostile?  Are they pretending to be friendly to get easy access on you with a nasty suprise later. They got guns!   Oh Crap!  but we are sneaking through a town full of zombies and we are to smart to fire our weapons and call the Zeds down on us all, buuuuut are these other people just as smart or will they open fire as soon as they catch you in the corner of their eye?   In total, there is a lot of fun to be had with this game, a lot of choices both in story and out of it. Suport this dev team, they do great work, and all of te content updates have been free, no BS DLC to speak of, they make it and just drop it in there for us to enjoy.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Amazing game.  Buy it!  The writing is terse but perfectly composed:  you get to know these characters and care when they die, or turn against you, or become disillusioned with your leadership (yes, all this can happen organically within the game system).  This game creates a tremendous sense of atmosphere and freedom:  every place, however insignificant, has a story if you look closely, and the game throws plot events at you at a slow but believable pace that lets you explore and deal with the crises that emerge naturally from the dynamics of the world and your own play style.  This is one of the very few times I have felt like I do when playing a tabletop RPG with a truly excellent GM.  This writer knows what he is doing.  Plus... this is a very satisfyingly long game, especially given the price:  look above to see how many hours I've given this game and I haven't finished it nor can I guess how it might end other than... well... badly.  But that is the apocalypse!

												If Fallout 2 and State of Decay had a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child, this would be it.Edit:  Seriously, this is a very good game.  The plot can be gripping if you allow it to be.  The characters have personality and they can get on your nerves, but if you want to keep them [you do want to, you need their skills and manpower] you'll have to placate them.  It's not impossible to make everyone happy, but it does require some effort.The turn based combat is a lot of fun, even given how much of it there can be it never really came off as tedious to me.  There are even a few situations where you can manipulate the undead to help you in wearing down some enemies for you to swoop in for the kill.The story and atmosphere are immersive and it's was easy enough for me to lose myself in the game, especially if you have a favorite character personaily or concept to role play with.I most certainly endorse and would recommend this game.

8, 2015
												I give this game a very very tentative positive review. Overall, you get what the game promises up front, so there is no deception as far as marketing goes and there being a free demo is a huge plus.That said, I have issues with this game. For one, I feel like having a main character that you play as is very limiting. Of course you should always play as the leader, that's the style of game it is, but if your character is deemed unfit for leadership, game over. If your character dies, game over. I think this is far too limiting and they should go with a 'State of Decay' model in that if you die, (or as in this game, if you're stripped of leadership, or banished, whatever) the next NPC up becomes the player character. I just think that one thing limits this game far too much.I also wish you could negotiate with human looters rather than be forced to engage them in combat or run. I mean sure, there are always going to be ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s you just can't talk to, but I find it hard to believe that your group is the only one that would be even willing to negotiate.But overall, I enjoyed it while I played it and intend to play it more in the future, so even with the negatives, I can't give it a negative if I'm still playing.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
9, 2015
												This is a very interesting game, I can only give it a so-so rating.The graphics, it's pretty lowgrade and very cartoonie. So if you are big on visuals than look elsewhere.The idea behind the game is very good. Set in a zombie end world scenario, you are a survivor trying to survive day to day by collecting resources and gathering npc party members in a stronghold. You character is fully customizable in terms of skills and stats. The NPCs are not, only a few choices in game on which way they will specialize, but those of use played Baulder's Gate and some RPGs this is a minor inconvinience.The game play is not bad, u have to manage ur shelter/stronghold. Collecting, gathering, or fishing for supplies day after day to keep everyone fed and fuel for the generator so you have electricity. You need electricity for alot of functions in your shelter so it's best to keep the fuel stockpile full. Meds and other supplies also is needed for the shelter. The constant threat of hunger, low meds, and lack of fuel keeps you running out to grab more and explore more. This is very good part of the game and keeps the days rolling.The Combat is very basic, i mean it in a bad way. no cover system or anything. extreme linear movement in a square grid system, firearms have very little range and there is preciously little ammo making using guns frustrating. Also gun fire or loud noise attracts random zombies, they spawn at edge of map and walk towards the sounds, it's a good idea but then it's really lame because only 1 zombie come, well per noise meter raised. Sometimes they dont come at all, i mean there should be some indication or more zombies. It's very frustrating you cant take cover behind a stone pillar or  a tree or the corner of the house and you see the enemy shoot right through obsticles. So combat in this game is pretty terrible. Im comparing to earlier games like wasteland 2 or xcom. This needs work.Story is very good and there are unexpected turns, you can't keep everyone happy is the underline theme.So in this state I cannot recommend the game because I simply dread combat everytime i runinto it and it's every few minuts while scavenging. I get so bored.

content:
er 22, 2015
												When I picked this game up, I thought, :bleh another zombie killing game with barely any plot to it." I was wrong. There is and isn't a story. The story is to survive, which is the most common theme, however, it does NOT focus on zombie killing. That's just a bonus. It's a story about how people need to survive off of each other when everyone's worlds  shatter collectively. Many needs can happen, people can experience bad memories, (especially when you have one of your teammates get eaten by a zombie then come back) and so much more. It's like Romero's movies. Sure there's zombies, but the worst enemy is the people who will do anything it takes to survive.PROs:*Customizable character creation*Skills with a different trait for a given amount of points put into one thing*Each weapon has its own stats (Some can break. Some weapons are improvised and shouldn't really be use)*Stats are simplistic and easy to understand.*The interactions of people and how they can survive in the world while trying to maintain their own sanity.*The lifeness of each character (Each character has their own personality.)*Animal companions. Have your animals help keep morale up or help defend your base!*Situations that upcome and can change how people can view you.Cons:*Zombie AI. If there's a horde of them, they won't move one by one, they'll all move THEN get a turn to attack each of your characters. I understand these things operate on sound so using weapons isn't great. However, when a whole horde comes, it usually screws you over.*Some characters are kind of useless than others. *Story. LIke I said, it's more focused on survival and the desperation of people during the end of the world. However, if there is a main goal, I can't seem to figure it out.*Combat is a bit awkward.*If you're a graphic snob, aka, HAS to be 1080p and 60 fps, then this game isn't for you. The graphics are good, but not the best. Look for another game. *The motorcycle gang members have super powerful weapons, even at early game, and can bring you down to half or a quarter of your health in one hit and when you DO kill them, their weapons dont have ANY ammo or any on their bodies.Overall I would rate it 9/10. It could use a bit of work, but it is a great game. If you like the theme of the world turning upside down during the zombie apocolypse, and people doing everything they need to survive, then this game is for you. If not, try Left 4 Dead or some other game for your satisfying zombie head shots.

												*Disclaimer: I know one of the artists as an internet friend*This is a wonderfully difficult game that seriously makes you think about your decisions. Unlike a lot of other games that are in this thread you gain exp by completing tasks, not killing zombies. Knowing that turns the game into a huge puzzle that given some time you can work your way through with minimal causalties. Be prepared to want to restart a couple times because if you don't pay attention and miss something important you will likely end up dead. My biggest advice is to PAY ATTENTION!Having played through Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines I enjoy Brian Mitsoda's work, and as the head writer on the project expect some in depth, thought raising dialogue. I would seriously play throguh just for the work he was able to do with this.

content:
5, 2015
												The game, at the moment when I played it, was quite buggy. The game does come across as somewhat alpha in certain areas but I could overlook those parts and enjoy the rest of the game just fine.You can read positive things from other reviewers, I'm going to focus on the negative aspects of the game while still reccomending it for any cRPG fan or zombie fan.Sometimes the character you're moving stands completely still and glides across the floor.Sometimes when you run across a large distance of the map one of your companions get stuck along the way and 'appears' to be running along right behind you until you see them glitch back and start re-running from wherever they got stuck.There are certain rooms and lootables that are not accessible because of path issues. Nothing that major really. You lose out on barely half a dozen items each time but it's still a bit annoying. What I mean is that you open a door to a hotel room and you can't enter it. Kind of like a misplaced invisible wall.Zombies and mercs and stuff just stand still pretty much constantly and there are times when you simply walk into a gunfight where the opposition will have the first move with no way to circumvent it.SPOILER The 'end game' happens after day 80, however there is only enough interaction between NPC's in the shelter for 60 days (at least that's all there was for me). So there will be this long boring gap of pretty much nothing happening after 60 days./SPOILERThe melee and ranged are completely unbalanced. Melee is fantastic for handling zombies but useless against late-game humans whereas ranged make zombie fights extremely tedious (and it's a waste of high-tier weapon ammo) but are pretty much a necessity for late game fights. It got to the point that there are human enemies in the game that can 'only' significantly get hurt by critical hits of high tier ranged weapons. So invest in Ranged 'and' melee.The car guzzles 'way' too much gas even with all the upgrades. Don't bother with it.I'll leave it at that for now.
