content:
19, 2015
												I am edditing my review, I want to be heard and since my Fierhorn79 account is banned and my super old Fierhorn account was perm banned by steam at the request of Doublebear for ban evasion. *The Highlighted Review Below* (Brian's DoubleBear statement) http://steamcommunity.com/app/239840/discussions/0/627456359689053892/My reply to Brian and Dead State DevsI wanted to take a minute to both defend myself and address Brian and Annie Mitsoda's statements.When I saw that Brian Mitsoda made a response it gave me hope that he and DoubleBear would address that main reason for my review not just the fact that the Review was wrongfully flagged by someone at Doublebear and then continue into a rant trying to discredit me. That main concern being the business decision to move a game from Early Access to full release during the Steam holiday season. The game on the release date had a long list of known bugs, several of them either game or story breaking. Yes there have been patches and some of the bugs have been fixed, but this does not cancel out they original concern. The choice that was made looks like Doublebear tried to trick gamers into buying a game thinking it was finished when in fact by DoubleBears own known issues list on the day of release it was not done. I and now I think others feel that a company should be held accountable for these type of actions. I have never asked for an extreme punishment, all I expected was for Doublebear to say what was going on to cause them to do this and to issue an apology to their loyal fans. Is open communication too much to ask for from the people who funded your game. Instead of dealing with my concerns directly Developers and mods have tried to silence myself and others. This game would not be a reality without people like me with our little 30 dollars. The attitude that I have seen from DoubleBear has come off at entitled and ungrateful for the opportunity that has been given to them. Now onto less important stuff. My defense.First of I want to say I was deeply offended by Annie Mitsoda's personal attacks on me on tumblr. Being called a @ickbag & #ucker was far less offensive than the way she disregards my 30 dollars. Just so you know that 30 bucks is three hours of my work day. I might be nothing to you but I put my hard earned money towards your dream.http://imgur.com/p97JvCIhttp://murderblonde.tumblr.com/post/105832304380/exhaustionBrain and friends at DoubleBear continue to claim I engaged in "abusive comments towards both the devs and mods" and this is why threads were locked and deleted. This is not the case , I as well never harassed anyone. They can't provide screen shot of where I did any of the things they claim because they did not happen. What screen shots of locked and deleted threads they do show are just snippets without showing what anyone else is say. I was never off topic ,never spammed, never directly attacked anyone. The claim that I harassed DoubleBear requesting a public apology be given to the community is just absurd. I was the only one on any of these forums to get banned when there were people making direct personal attacks on me that were defending the developers that were not even given a warning by the DoubleBear mods.1)First thread was shut down for no good reason.2)Second one I thought maybe they shut it down because the attacks on me. I knew I did not break the rules so I made another post pasting most of the OP and then adding another paragraph to make it new. This was right away shut down.3)Third post was a little snarky post about how they shut down post that are on the top that are critical.4)Fourth post was actually made by another person. This is the one I got banned in and I did nothing except ask Brian to say sorry. Never broke a forum rule once. No warning just a ban. Yes you will notice #114 &115 are back to back but that is only because the I did not copy the second part over from my wordpad. You will notice that there are several posts in between #115 and my next post. Too bad the devs only provide what I say in a attempt to manipulate the way this looks.http://imgur.com/tjdBGs9http://imgur.com/Tj84fUi5)I by this point was not happy. I felt like an American being silenced and someone who my 30 bucks and support was being treated like trash. I contacted the mod(Caidoz) through a private ban email. Its funny how they just provide one snippet of the conversation and deleted the email from my account so I can't provide a picture. Yes I did say I can just create tons of alt account in this private chat. I wanted Caidoz to know his ability to silence had no power over me. I never once said I was going to abuse this and mass spam threads or upvote my own review. First of the time and money it would take to get 300 accounts is ridiculous. http://imgur.com/l0XxiVXI have had this alt account for 6+ years and I did not use it until now to defend myself after many attacks. So with all the above being said I am a forgiving gamer. If DoubleBear publicly apologies for the early release and explains why they did it then I think everyone should forgive and get behind this company to help them finish what I think will be a great game when complete. On a personal note I think Brian and Annie Mitsoda's own me a private apology for the slander and attacks personally against me.Fierhorn79**********************************Review**********************************Wanted to start off by saying I was a huge supporter of this game pre Steam Early Access and during early access. I enjoyed beta testing the game for DoubleBear and helping them to use the EA process to better the game. I think the game is a blast even in its frustrating buggy state.Now onto the reason why I think people should not buy this game or support the company DoubleBear for any future games until the Give a public apology.I don't know about all of you but I found Kickstarter and Steam Early Access to be a wonderful breath of fresh air. I was sick of big AAA and medium sized AA Developers and Publishers pushing out 3/4 made buggy games that after I paid full price for had to wait months before it was patched up and enjoyable. This was the norm and I was sick of it.So I started supporting only EA and Kickstarter games, more than I could afford at times. Dead State is one of those games and I was very happy to support Doublebear.Sadly DoubleBear betrayed its fans and sought to deceive new buyers into believing that Dead State was a finished product in order to take full advantage of the Holiday shopping season. Brian and the Dead State team had pages of known bugs and some of them were game and story breaking. Ask yourself what reason would a Developer move a product that is known to be a buggy mess from Early Access to calling the game fully released. We the gamers are there Publisher and we were not on their backs pushing them to release the game in a unfinished state in order to reap the profit from the Holiday season. My over all point is that when small gamer funded games pull the same fast one as big AAA developers something has to be done about it. This type of behavior and not be rewarded.These type of actions corrupt the new system from within. If this is allowed to happen then we get get a bunch of small studios acting just like the AAA ones because they can. I and many others went onto Dead States forums to ask for an appology and get an answer why they felt the need to move a unfinished game from EA to fully released. We all found ourselves pounced on ,forum post locked and in several cases found ourselves banned. These type of actions are those of people wanting to hide what they did not ones wanting to correct the mistake that was made.I don't know DoubleBears reasons to fall to to such a low level. If they had funding problems there are so many other more honest options. We gamers have shown ourselves to be very giving.I ask people to avoid this game until the game is finished

content:
er 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								Okay, so I'd be one of the first gamers to tell you that I do not buy early access games, even if i really want to play it, i dont want to ruin the finished product for myself. Well this game changed that for me. Specifically, it was reading reviews from people hailing how awesome the game was with over 500 hours logged into this game - an early access game with that many hours clocked in by one person really grabbed my attention.So, going out on a limb i decided to get this game - figuring hey, I'll at least get access to the full version when it comes out, and probably cheaper than if i waited.A good choice, I think. Now I only just started playing the game, but holy crap is it addicting as all hell!So, to start, the main gameplay of this game is a turn based RPG, much like Fallout 1 and 2 (hell even the UI is layed out the same for the most part), except you have a party of 4 that you take out on ventures with you. But the game is so much more than that. The travelling around and fighting is actually a small part of this game. The core of the game is that you're basically the leader of a Zombie apocalypse team that found themselves barricaded in a School. The school is your base, and you can upgrade the base with tons of different things, like a better fence, a workshop, a garage for fixing and building cars, and so much more.So how it works, is the game day starts at 8 am, and you got free roam of your school. You can go around talking to your team members, ask them about their attitude and certain things they'd like you to grab them from the field such as soap, or chocolate or what have you (getting these items for them will increase their morale, which plays a huge part in this game, but I'll get to that).You have a white board in the cafeteria, where you can allocate your members to go do certain jobs during the day, each job takes varying hours (and will decrease if you get another member to help them with it), mechanical jobs will go much faster if you have someone with a high mechanical skill doing those jobs.Each member has their own set of skills (as well as the PC that he chooses at the beginning of the game, and can increase as you 'level up') and you decide what jobs they do depending on their skills.While the rest of your team is doing jobs (you can have the PC do some of these various jobs, but you cant do anything while that happens), you can pick a team of up to 4 members as your raiding party. With these guys you can leave your base and get to travel the map (which is literally a map of texas, with all the interstates and towns and cities and all that). Travelling the map takes time, and is slower or faster depending on your travel method. At the start, you can only travel by foot, but later on you can get horses and even cars to speed up the process.As the time goes by during the day, your members back at base will be doing their tasks you assigned them, while you are finding random super markets, hospitals, neighbourhoods, and so on and looting any materials you can find, weapons, food, luxuries, parts and tools and so on.However, you MUST be back at your shelter by 3 am, otherwise you get a game over (im pretty sure, i never let myself be out that long yet), so obviously you cant travel too far from base without some sort of transportation.While going to various locations, you must avoid or kill zombies, who are not only hostile but if they get a bite on your allies while their health is low, they infect them. Your allies, if infected will go up to 3 days without treatment before they will kill themselves or turn into zombies and attack you. There are antibiotics you can find that as long as you have them in stock, your allies will take them staving off the infection (but not curing it), so you can keep infected allies indefinitely, you just need to have a supply of antibiotics.You can also find other people, looters who are hostile and you must kill to survive, to even other survivors you can recruit to join your cause. However, watch out when firing guns off liberally in a battlefield, as it attracts zombies, and getting guys infected is the last thing you need.On top of all this, the most important part of the game is your shelter Morale. You have a morale level that goes up and down depending on recent events and moods of allies. Every ally has their own morale level that can be increased by giving them special items, keeping a stock of luxury items on hand, and even having other allies do jobs such as cooking for the crew to bring morale up for everyone. Morale is affected by everything, ranging from having broken generators (or no gas to run them) to the amount of food on hand, to having a secure base or what have you.If morale with people get too low, they may find that they are better off out in the wasteland and leave your crew, to even if morale is so bad for everyone you can have a mutiny and your crew will outcast you from your own base.This game is so damn addicting, I wish i had more time to play it haha. I would recommend this game to any RPG fan out there, specifically if you like survival horror. A solid game, and worth the money for sure. I would even go as far to say that this one could be nominated as Game of the Year, especially if im only playing an unfinished product so far.

content:
2
												Dead State is a game in the tradition of Wasteland and the early (isometric) Fallout games.In spite of the fantastical setting of a Zombie apocalypse, the characters are very relatable. You are a survivor of an airplane crash (the pilots got overwhelmed by the infected) and you find shelter with a few other survivors in a local school. You need to repair the fence, find food and fuel for the generator and most importantly you need to keep up morale. You can assign tasks for the people to repair or build things, like a recycler, a well, a workshop, a roof garden and so on. Gradually you become more and more self-sufficient. You can find new survivors to strengthen your workforce, but you also have to manage their conflicts and deal with crisis events, and maintain your authority.You can lead a scavenging party of max 4 to find resources and contacts outside the shelter. Zombies are everywhere, and you are in constant danger of being swarmed by them, and even have your people bitten and infected. You may also find armed looters, gangbangers, hostile survivalists, rogue soldiers, and demoralized police on your path.Although the graphics and sound effects are basic, they are expressive and effective.The game is quite engaging and suspenseful, and I can recommend it with the caveat that this game can really, really test your patience.There is an extensive demo available.

6, 2016
												One of the best turn based roleplaying games ever made. Graphics are decent, but run slowly when show crowds and sometimes crushes to desktop: to avoid problems save quickly as an habit, in this case the effort worth because game is really good. Mechanics is wonderfull, remembers the firsts Fallout titles, but has deeper rules because the player lead a group and their shelter for everything: build upgrades, craft or repair items, manage social conflicts, find more survivals and needs as food, fuel, materials... is really advisable read the manual. Combat is oriented to patience tactics, silence, concealment and ambush. Types of weapons and armours are variety and complete. There are two kind of foes, humans of hostile  factions and classic zombies. The sandbox map is huge, with 60 locations, each with a specific situation. Think logically is important, decisions bring consequences and different endings.Texts of choices and missions has no bugs. Touch every common topic of apocalyptical genre, and is really long: explore every corner take circa 200 hours. By the adult dialogues, lack of frenzy action and technical issues, not recommendable for teenagers.

												IF YOU'RE HAVING ISSUES WITH THE GAME CRASHING TRY THIS:http://steamcommunity.com/app/239840/discussions/1/620713633843067876/I was at my wit's end trying to run this game. The longest I could play it was 10 minutes before game crash, freeze (requiring manual close), computer lockup (requiring manual reboot) and game crashing so hard that it caused involuntary reboot (sometimes with BSOD!).I have a fast system with dual GPU's that can run high graphics (I used auto detect), so there's no issues with the base hardware. [I have no issues with any other games.]I used Display Driver Uninstall to install a perfectly new/clean version of my graphics drivers.I REINSTALLED WINDOWS 10! I'm still annoyed at all the stuff I have to reconfigure or reinstall.Even after that, the game failed again and again.I was ready to leave a thumbsdown when I finally found that Troubleshooting Guide.Something on there solved my problem and now the game runs basically fine. If you're having issues with the game crashing, try it before leaving a negative review.I suppose you may not like the actual game but in my opinion what you see is what you get. It's exactly what I wanted.Well, I wanted a game that was supported by the developer, but we can't have it all.

content:
2, 2016
												Fun turn based zombie apoco game.Great for a indy title.However, I do believe small additions can make this game great for any production level.It needs a bit more customization. Don't force the main character to remain.Have it if he dies you can continue as the other survivors. So it becomes group focused, instead of a single leader.Taking a few notes from XCom this could be a amazing experience especially for a Ironman mode play through.I personally believe you need voiced dialogue for the responses. But it is understandable not to, it would increase the story for me at least. With out the emotional reaction of the voice actors it is no where near as impactful.Aside customization of your own character, and maybe other survivors in your group.They have done a great job with the items you get, and luxury items.They could extend a bit more, but that at this time for the first entry is well done.Instead of it focusing specifically in Texas. Maybe have it focused around a country.This is near the start so it makes sense for walking distance places to have supplies still.But, it would make it more interesting if you traveled across a landscape to get supplies.Such as multiple states. As well it gives the opportunity for different environments.A lot is here, and the fundamental system is great for what it is. But it could be great, as of now it is good.I suggest picking it up if you are a turned based RPG fan.

												This game caught a lot of flack at first because it was released a bit early, and if we are talking honestly it probably did. It was buggy and I would save often cause I knew lots of things could go wrong. I think that effected the ratings quite a bit. BUT with the new changes and even before this game holds up.  If you like people and recourse managment you'll like this game. There is a real sense of urgency, of trying to squeeze as much out of everyday as you can. Once you have 20+ mouths to feed you have to be sure everything is gonna run smoothly. The human enemies are certainly tough and finding new ways to fight each group or situation is always entertaining as well as challenging.

armor of me, soo i shotted around and 3-4 zombies of map have come, i lured them to the looters and they have killed almost all of them and the looters have become zombies and they have killed all the other looters then i killed all the other zombies and i conquered the camp with only a revolver and a fireaxe, this concept it's very interesting and can be an obastacle lf you want to use a lot of firearms and going around doing call of duty 360noscope.3) The story for now was interesting, but nothing special i think, i hope this game will become more "Freeroaming" because for now he seems too linear and withtout a lot of choice possible, they say the game will be "Months" long and with over 10.000 dialogue options but i really hope they will give us a repliability, because there is no point to play this game lf all the things will be always the same except for the little decisions we can make ( Example, to save some survivors, making visits in places and such ), i really hope for a freeroaming game4) The places to visit are not a lot ( around 7-10 for now ) 1 supermarket, 1 pharmacy, 1 enemy camp with bandits, 1 town all of the starting city, 1 resident area of the starting city, 1 random church and other places now i don't remember, they are interesting, very well made and the effects are ok for now, but has i told you they are always the same, zombies in the same places, not too much to interact with just sometimes the bags you found around and i found them already boring for now even because the zombies don't move! I will find it more funny lf random zombies can come out of the map and roam around the map, but for now this can be not a problem, since a lot features are not been implemented yet soo we just need to wait to see the rest of the game for now.5) The crafting part of the game was interesting, but not too much for now. You have the same jobs of some games ( Farmer, Doctor, Nurse, Chemical, Mechanic and soo on ) but for now they can't craft for you a lot even because you can't build the areas you need to make them work. For what i have seen you can only craft some things like lethear armors, military armors and helmets, your own ammunitions for pistols / rifles ecc but there is not too much variety he seems like State of Decay where you can craft only little things like molotovs or fireworks to lure the zombies away.6) The place where your hide it's a school, a normal place we see in some zombie movies or in zombies games ( Like Zombie Fort lf somebody knows that title ) and it's very well maded, a lot of classrooms where can become new areas, basements, garden where you will build farms and other things, but for now everything it's looked. He seems a bit empty for now even because the npc's you have are just stuck in the same place with the same pose and withtout an animation, soo they are like statues and it's a bit sad.7) The animations for now are nothing cool, the zombie animations for when they try to bite you are ok, when they die they use the same pose ( Soo for example lf two zombies dies in the same space, you can loot only one ) and it's nothing different, the walk of the character is nothing special even for the looters and when the zombies uses normal attack they just slap your face sometimes.For me the game is great, he has a lot of potential and can be fun! For now you can't do anything and there is no point to play it more then 1 max 2 times, i hope they will add a lot of random things, they will fix the enemies stuck in the same poses forever, they make the game a bit more "Live", random zombies / events and such. For now lf you want it look first on some gameplays on youtube because he can be for now a bit frustrating to buy, or you can simply wait the 3-5 months they said for the game to finish.Thanks for reading and sorry for my bad english, but it's not my main language :3

												While there are some issues like the occasional random crash, sometimes wonky camera controls, a lack of an indicator for max carrry weight while looting something(95.3/110 for example. all you see is the 95.3). and most recently, the innability to communicate with a dog I found in a house because apparently with dogs i can only speak to them from behind, and this dog has his back to a wall, so i can't interact with it at all, I would certainly recomend this game to SHTF gamers and people who enjoy RPG meets base building.Its kind of like 'wasteland 2' meets 'state of decay'/'the walking dead'EDIT: almost a year since the last time I reviewed this game, and while it feels more polished in a lot of ways, it still has some issues.still no max weight indicator like 95.3/110.00. all you see while looting is the 95.3. you have to go directly to your inventory to see your actual max carry capacity.when a particular character jumps the fence and leaves the shelter during the night, the narrative and dialogue tell me that he took ONLY his axe and that he wasnt the type to steal, and yet the electrified baton, corrogated shield, and the armor with 8 defence(whos name escapes me) are missing as well.Enemies sometimes move on top of one another and get 'stuck' where neither one can move, can sometimes attack, and cant be killed(in my experience).The screen sometimes jumps around a bit RIIIIIGHT when I'm selecting my move/attack target and I waste a turn goig in some random direction instead of attacking. this usually isn't too much of a problem, but in a tough fight where every single turn counts... it caused me to waste about 1 hour of time having to reload after the camera jump caused 2 of my party to die.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												Dead State has positives and negatives.  I expected a completely open world which, frankly, has been a standard since Might and Magic and Baldur's Gate.  I restarted the game to carefully follow the tutorial.  Then I had to figure out myself how to find locations on the map when they're not already marked so I restarted again because I lost a day or two.  Later I learned that you will not find some locations until an ally tells you about them.Despite that, I found Dead State to be fun and engrossing.  The shelter, the upgrades, the morale system, and the crafting system are all excellent.  Combat is flexible and you can approach a fight in many different ways.  I spent about 30 hours on the first 16 days and enjoyed it a lot.After that, I started to find some of the religious, political, and personal issues of the allies to be a pain in the butt.   I just wanted to survive the zombie apocalypse not be a politician and social counselor.   If there are zombies around your fence, aren't people going to be a little more concerned about survival.  Some of these allies that  show up are just plain unrealistic.  It's like Dead State turned into some nightmare, reality show.Finding comfort items and medicine for allies was great.  Looking for family members - awesome.  Beyond that, if things are brought up I'd rather look at it through the lens of surviving the immdediate threat of zombies.  For most people, I think a safe place from zombies is more than enough to keep their morale up.  Just my opinion.So I'm giving the game a qualified thumbs up.

content:
22, 2015
												Dead State is a different approach to all the Zombie games out there. The game is driven by npc characters personal stories which are many of times linked to missions and side quests. The game's main focus is not on combating zombies but base upgrading and keepings your surviving npcs morale happy and keeping them safe in zombie apocalyptic world. Combating zombies is only an obstacle to these objectives and your base can come under attack by the living and the dead. Among your npcs are personalites that may clash with each other and even you the Protagonist in the story. Zombies can kill you if you dont plan an attack when you approach them in a turn base combat. Outside of combat is free roam. Think of this game like "This war of Mine" meets "wasteland 2". The developers seem to be continuing to fix bugs and add more contents to this final release game...

content:
ry 3, 2015
												I have exactly 100 hours of a single play through in this game, so I figured I would give a quick impression. This has probably been my most enjoyed zombie apocalypse themed game yet, and I have played almost every offering on the market. The game does need smoothing out and some balancing and some randomization for the map and big story events or end game would go a long way to make the game more replayable. That said, the scavenging, base management, and combat is all addictively enjoyable. Even the character development was very well done and each path of skill advancement can have a huge impact of how you tackle the zombie apocalypse (i.e. you are not required to be a combat monkey to succeed). For fans of turn based RPGs with base management elements, I would highly recommend you pick this up!

content:
19, 2015
												Great game, needs more shelter upgrades though. I had recruited 40 people at the end and there was just not enough room. Something like expanding the size of the Shelter Fort would have been cool.One thing, everyone came to me with their problems, loss of loved ones, depression, hunger, sickness whatever - But nobody ever asked how I felt. Or tried to help me, apart from Grant I suppose but im not sure if he counts.I would have liked it if the player character wasnt so invincible, maybe they should have had the ocasional sick day or depression, I mean in my game he had just lost his whole family, wife an dkids in the plane crash. And all he gets is "Oh sorry about that, listen would you mind being our leader and going out and finding materials to repair the fence and food and stuff thanks bye."Also its strange that the Player has to lead every scavenger party, what if you were playing as a scientist or a mechanic? ANd your skills are needed back at the fort, building upgrades, repairing the wall, making bullets? No sorry you have to lead the scavenger team so you have to put points into Ranged, Melee and Survival. Anything else is just a waste. Why bother giving us the freedom to create our own character, then railroad us into having to make them a soldier/fighter?Zombies got really repetitive to fight after a while, but the Human enemies were fantastic.Otherwise its a great game, I hope they make a sequel as it definately could use some improvements and be even better.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
18, 2015
												I want to like this game.  I want to play this game.  Unfortunately, the game has different plans.There's a mid-game mission where your small team raids a large biker gang base.The first time through, I was doing well - getting through by the skin of my teeth, coming up with solutions to both biker attacks and zombies, playing them against each other.  Two women in plate mail I'd scavenged from a Medieval Times restaurant were wailing on everyone with swords and explosives while a Vietnam veteran made headshot after headshot and a veterinary student ran around bandaging the wounded.  I'd been at it for two hours without saving - the game doesn't let you save in battle, and isn't great at detecting when you're not in battle, so the whole map is essentially one long slog.  I was almost done but then . . . the game hard crashed.Okay.  Fine.  It happens.  Like fifty zombies and gang members, that's a lot to calculate, I guess I can sympathize.  Second time through, let's try this again.This time, I was betrayed by the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way the game handles stairs.  The second half of this battle is arranged in such a way that, unless you are extremely lucky, one person gets stuck in the tiny space between the bottom stair landing and a nearby enemy.  The rest of the team, rifles in hand, sits around at the top of the stairs and picks their noses, unable to come down the stairs or affect anything on the first floor until a space is cleared - which it won't be, because the one person able to go down the stairway will, within a turn, be gunned down.  So your other three party members sit, helpless, as their friend slowly bleeds to death, because she's blocking the tiny space allotted to stairway movement with her heavily armored unconscious body.  This is after forty-five minutes of pitched, unsave-able battle, mind you.This last I allow was my fault tactics wise, but, my god.  I had, essentially, a sniper at the top of the stairs, unable to help his friend six vertical feet away.That said, rage aside, I can't bring myself to not recommend this game.  It's one of the best-written RPGs I've played in a while, and hits just the right combination of despair and hope with its mechanics.I mean, I'm extremely ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off.  I feel cheated of more than one long-fought victory.  But once I've cooled down, I know I'll try that battle again, and cross my fingers that nothing breaks this time, because I really do want to bring my little group of survivors through the zombie apocalypse to better times.

content:
17, 2015
												Full disclosure: I backed this game on Kickstarter.  What is Dead State?  It's a game that does a similar premise to State of Decay, but in a different way.  Instead of a 3D action game, this is an Isometric X-Com-a-like with traditional turn-based combat.  It is not an easy game early on, with difficulty decreasing as better equipment is found.  I *cough* resorted to some save scumming (reload and come back with more firepower) if I misread who the foes would be or wandered into a place that ended up having unusually tough enemies.   I managed to beat the game after 79 hours of play, but managed to defeat it on my first try.  There is a bit of grind-y nature to discovery, looting and zombie-battling.All in all, though, I enjoyed the game enough to play through it entirely to see it through.  I did lose interest around Day 70 and more or less had to power through the next 20 or so.  I don't know if I'll play it again since I was sucessful.  I can see if someone doesn't manage to beat it wanting to try it again, though.

number of helpful: 8 of 15 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2015
												So far, the game is LONG and HARD. Straight off the bat, you'll be hit with a minus ## in morale - don't worry, just keep going out and try your BEST not to get your guys KO'ed. If you see a red skull show up next to a character, HIGHLY SUGGEST that you reload (game autosaves everytime you enter and leave an area) - red skull means infected and will NEVER go away.Love the tactics that can be used in the game, tons of loot EVERYWHERE, there's quite a bit of realism, like the hacking mechanic in the game, and though annoying, panic and horror does make battles harder or easier (depends on which side gets hit by those "run for your life!!" character freak outs).Pros: - Dead State uses a REAL map from Texas (the only area that seems made up is "Splendid") for the game map. - Lots of different types of enemies. - Sound alerting the undead/infected is a plus for realism. - Large number of built upgrades (as well as equipment modifications). - Unlike a lot of zombie games, there are TONS of recruit-able allies. - There's a vote system (once Vic gets back). - Can pick lock doors, disarm security alarms, or simply kick the door in. - And a powerful yet unstable psycho character can join you (sad when I lost him).Cons: (a lot need correcting and fixing)- Typos and spelling errors EVERYWHERE! - Tutorial mentions that you can sneak up on enemies (FALSE).- Animals and Crawling infected are far more likely to KO player than those standing up! (WTF?)- Feeling of being forced to build places (allies want it, don't get it done by #day, they leave).- Boyfriend infuriated you didn't tell him about girlfriend (not spoiling) even though you are NEVER given the option TO TELL HIM (add the option, makes zero sense to not be able to tell him an him getting infuriated cause you didn't say anything!!).- Turn Order (top right of screen) - Understand when the enemies you're fighting are in the turn order display, but SERIOUSLY cycling through EVERY SINGLE ENEMY ON THE LEVEL? (Big Con!)- Characters in Panic/Horror can make losing pretty easy (both pro and con).- Areas do not respawn loot & enemies (realism is a pro) but expects player to remember if area is cleared completely or not (# of times visited and days since last visit is ok, but having to remember what is cleared an what isn't can get annoying and wasteful since Time isn't on our side).- Allies' Moods feel broke - It gets frustrating & annoying when despite your efforts, the "moods" don't ever seem to change (Morale is oddly separate from this).- Cannot pick skill & stat point use for Allies. Though it adds to challenge, it still blows that the skill & stat points for allies is out of the player's control, this just forces a player to not bother with the pathetic allies, keep the important ones at home, and pray the allies that go out with you don't focus on a skill you don't favor (more of a con than pro).- And Todd. He prays while we act. He thanks god instead of us. Seriously tempted to commit Wrath on him....Despite all the cons in the game, frankly Dead State is STILL a good game. There's a lot of stories in this game based on the characters you befriend, and those you just outright want to body slam through a wall. Feels like Final Fantasy Tactics meets The Walking Dead - both very good games, and Dead State feels like a mix of the two.Yeah there's a lot of cons that I listed, and not many pros - but most of the cons are personally (my opinion) what needs to be fixed, changed, and corrected by the developer of Dead State. Once those are taken care of, the pros will undoubtedly outnumber the cons.The game's graphics aren't spectacular, but the visuals matter little when the gameplay is experienced. To the Game Developer of Dead State - Please take note of the listed Cons, most are errors, typos, bugs, and others are simply game mechanics that need adjustments. This game could be awesome, COULD BE (has the potential), but right now its just a good game. I've barely explored the map, gotten many tough battles, and made quite a number of interesting allies. Honest Opinion of the game: 7.5/10. If most of the listed cons are fixed, changed, or adjusted, it could easily become 9/10.

												What a piece of garbage, is what I seriously feel towards this game and the attitude the game devs put into this game. I really don't mind if a game stays indie for a long time. But seriously?, when you have games so abandoned you get the same wasted potential that you get from Day Z. I actually backed this game out for Kickstarters, because I felt as though this game was going to be worked hard on.What did I get a 6/10 burnt out trash, with broken gameplay that supported you retrying a level dozens of times, just HOPING that the game doesn't crash on you. Sneaking and Combat are both lackluster in this game. You always feel like your getting no where in this game.Music is 7/10, It's mediocre nothing memorable but not god awful as well.Gameplay is 4/10 Complete garbage, rarely works and when it does it still always encourages luck wayy to much compared to strategic planning.Maps is 5/10 some of the maps are reasonably large for the character and diverse but the chances that you would enjoy them is horrendously wasted due to lack luster gameplay and incredibly repetetive routines.Seriously there are far better Zombie Survival games out there, I can't believe I'm saying this but EVEN DEAD STATE WAS BETTER THAN THIS.

								Such potential.....Thing is it looks and plays like a N64 game, the animation are laughable but yet it still could be fun.BUT there are no difficulty settings, yes weird i know, im only on my third mission i think it is and they tear my team apart, leaving 2 or 3 of them standing full health with guns and even shotguns, the balance is pathetic tbh.Oh and i have hardly seen any Zeds, every enemy is a Human Looter, sheesh.If you want TBC then go for Xcom, Wasteland 2 and The Banner Saga, all of these are far far superior and polished than this, as they would be as this one is early Release, but you can see the style etc they are going for.Its just the little effort in things i notice, but the graphics are terrible, the animations are from the 80's, all forgiveable if the gameplay was addictive, and it is not, as mentioned the difficulty is very very hard and there is NO difficulty settings at all, combined with the poor, even terrible unbalance makes it a hell to play.I wont reccomend it till its further down the line , but keep a eye on this one it ccould be good in the end, but with the unbalance its just infuriating to play, its certainly not fun.

												I recommend this game. It is fun, it is challenging, it has good gameplay value. You will enjoy it for 40+ hours, you get ok value for your money. ry 5, 2016
												I tried the demo and it seemed interesting. So I bought it for $8 bucks on sale. That's what I feel this game is worth. The combat is rather simple once you figure it out. Z's will attack the closet person for the most part and if you have a fire ax/sledge it's game over for them. Guns are pointless because they alert everything in the area (which is realistic). You can "add" stuff to your shelter by saving up enough parts and working on it for a number of ingame days. This adds a slight bonus and takes away from the monotony slightly.So basically every day you go out and do the same thing, search for food, fuel, and luxery items to make your people happy. With combat rather simple it's a rinse and repeat grind waitng for the next addition to fisnih so you can  start buidling the next "addition"  that will add another slight (and I mean Slight) bonus to your base. And then wait as your people make weapons/grenades for you. I wish steam had an meh okay button instead of recoomend or not. It's not a bad game but it's not an amazing game either. It kept me interested for 18+ hours but seeing as there is no real story line beyond just collecting loot I don't think I'll put much more into it.

number of helpful: 45 of 90 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2014
												I was lured to back the kickstarter by a promise of good, mature writing. Then I woke the other guy from the crash...I have rarely seen such a badly written character, the first thing he did after waking was demanding us all to work for him, because he told us that he was a genius. He even used the words: "chop chop!" At first I put it down to him being delirious and gave him the benefit of the doubt, but in my other conversations with him it became clear that he only accepted the survivors not listening to his demands of being leader straight away begrudgingly. The other topics he would speak about was his frustration at the lack of internet, his expertise with computers and some "hilarious" references to him being a nerd.  You'd expect in a serious rpg about an apocalypse that the main characters actually take what's happening seriously or if they don't, that you get the option to give them the boot straight away.My immersion was killed so badly by this, and the cutscenes that transition so fast you get disoriented, that I lost all interest in the gameplay, which was marginal at best. Still considering asking steam to delete this from my library.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2015
												I recommend this game. It is fun, it is challenging, it has good gameplay value. You will enjoy it for 40+ hours, you get ok value for your money.  It's not particulary buggy, it plays well and is balanced. So that's all the good bits.Unfortunately, the game, even the reanimated game, seems like it was never really finished. Unless your not very good at playing these type of games, you will probably level out your base and fully kit out your team a long time before you get close to actually finishing the story line.I never finished the story line, towards the end of the game, it just became a grind, all my people were sitting in the base playing video games, it got boring, even the story got a bit boring, like they had used all their inspiration in the 1st 20+ hours of gameplay.So overall, this is a good game, but it makes you kind of sad, as with a little more work to pace the story line with the skills and gear progression, this would have been an amazing game.Enjoy.

												I waited to buy this game for awhile.  I didn't want to get it in its alpha state, because there are about 100 zombie survival games out there right now in alpha.  I see lots of negative reviews for this game and while it does have some bugs, I only experienced a few.  Storyline is pretty good for a zombie game.  Survivor management, resources, and even crafting are pretty good.  Talking to your survivors could use a little polish, but I think its definitely worth 20-30 bucks.  If you like zombie games and you like turn based games like fallout 1 and 2 this is a good game.  I was a little leary of the turned based combat but its really not to bad.

content:
ry 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dead State (Demo)Story: 6/10Gameplay: 6/10UI: 4/10Multiplayer: NADifficulty: ModeratePrice: Not Worth ItPros-Giving your survivors jobs to perform at your base adds a nice simulation aspect to the normal action zombie shlog-Exploring and scavenging abandon areas is fun-Attacks have a bit of variance depending on the weapon you're using-Environments are well designed and have personality to themCons-Very buggy, prone to crash or have the screen go all black-Actual combat with zombies can be frustrating when it happens in enclosed areas (allies can't move past or through each other)-UI is very unintuitive, you can even attack your own party members if you click on them to select them-Actual zombies aren't much of a threat when compared to insane scavengers-You'll never encounter more than a few zombies, and as long as you engage them wisely, they are never really a threat-Turn based play doesn't feel right for a zombie game, at least not for this gameI really wanted to like this game, I have been excited about it for years as more and more news of it's release came to light.  It seemed like the people making it were really into zombie culture and were promising a well made zombie simulation game.  Unfortunatly, I don't think they were too experienced when it came to designing actual gameplay.  The story is pretty generic zombie-survival fare.  You wake up after surviving a plane crash surrounded by a bunch of people who saved your life when they brought you to their safehouse and patched you up.  From there, you are basically given jobs to strengthen the safehouse and you try to survive your first week in zombie land.The actual gameplay is little more than making sure all your people are in the right position when you start a fight with a zombie.  If you do it right, you'll kill the zombie almost every time without it even noticing you.  If you do happen to be noticed as you approach the zombie, it will get a free attack on you and possibly beat you down pretty badly just in a few hits.  If you have a group with you, sneaking up on a zombie is a crapshoot unless all your party members are stealthy.  Once combat begins, you basically hit the zombie with debuff attacks then hit it with power attacks until it's dead.  (Blunt weapon for zombies, edged weapons/guns for humans usually works well)  If you're fighting humans, then there is a bit more of a challenge as they often have at least one pistol guy in their group.  (And, unlike most games, getting shot really hurts.)  Also, their gunshots may bring more zombies, but I've never had them bring an amount that worried me, (2 or 3 tops) which was a bit of a disappointment.I think the feel of the game is the most disappointing thing.  The zombies in this game don't seem like a threat that should have brought down society.  Most areas in the demo only really have a few zombies to deal with and they just aren't that scary. There should be the danger of hordes, being overwhelmed, and getting tired from too much combat.  None of that really comes into play.That said, this is just a demo so it's possible the final product will be much better.  However, this game is not worth the $20 price tag they are asking.  Wait for the final product or until they lower the price tag to something more reasonable.

content:
ber 3, 2015
												Based on the latest release of - Dead State: Reanimated.Progress through Dead State proved reminiscent of pre-millennial RPGs such as Fallout 1/2, Baldurs Gate and to a lesser extent, Vampire: Bloodlines. I'd consider this the highest praise I can bestow a game. The creative minds at Double Bear were involved in the creation of such cult games and have succeeded in achieving the sense of wonderment I found absent both in Pillars of Eternity and Wasteland 2, both of which attempted the same trick of capturing the essence of these earlier titles. Personally, I found both PoE and WL2 shallow interpretations, with story, immersiveness and game mechanics triaged for improved graphics. I suspect both titles will be forgotten while the legacy of their predecessors will continue. Given the teams behinds those particular titles were also involved in the creation of what I consider the "golden-age" era of cRPGs, I'd just about given up hope of finding another immersive isometric RPG. Maybe the real minds behind the greatest RPGs had left the business, died, or transcended to a higher plane of existence. Maybe, like myself, they were tired of the excreta being squirted out and trotted about as the "greatest RPG of all time" every few months. Maybe it was time to find a different hobby.Thankfully, at least one of the minds involved in the creation of cult classic RPGs is still among us.  The sense of an expansive and hostile world awaiting exploration, the advancement of both your character and relationships within the base alongside combat that retains old-school strategy but boosted with modern animations is unique among modern RPGs.The personal interactions are significant, with extensive dialogue trees that vary depending on your own actions and the emotions and morale within the base. Plus, there are a huge number of friendly NPCs, with 90% being unique and memorable. As an example, you can negotiate with a Vietnam veteran to kill his infected wife and join your base. You can either encourage his martial mentality, or relegate him to the kitchen. He can end up drunk and you can either admonish, mock him or give him time to recuperate. You can improve his mood with cigars and bourbon. You can encourage him to recover his old combat skills or serve the base more domestically. He can confront and threaten you if your leadership suffers, and you can either regain his support through negotiation or shoot him in the back as he leaves your room and insult him as he bleeds to death. Such extensive interactions are present with the majority of the NPCs within your base. This isn't Dragon Age type fluff, you aren't bored with slowly voiced over descriptions of the sexual preferences of Quinari princesses in the lands of make-believe. The topics of discussion are life and death, the answers are realistic, sometimes grim, and darkly humorous or a distraction used prior to a sneak-attack.Yes, the zombie premise has been overdone. Yes, there are bugs (Fallout 2 and Bloodlines were also released in such a state). Yes, it can be hard to maintain morale and food in your first game. Yes, you may found the graphics not the greatest. If the screenshots are repulsive to you, this won't be your preferred game type. This game has depth and complexity, not 4D-quantum-parralax-10.1 reflective sunbeams accentuating the convexed-v-synced-bump mapped textures of the player characters rear end, each bun modelled with a 6-point physics skeleton for life-like jiggle as you waddle around. This isn't style over substance.The Easter Eggs, such as the Friggin Chikin scratch card and bill-board signs, plus Dougs nerdy advice about attacking those crazed meth addicts with critical hits to their eyes is appreciated fan-service to those of us who immersed ourselves in such iconic RPGs almost two decades old. Dead State may seem out of place in the current horde modern RPGs, however it restores my faith that future RPGs can retain the same complexity, intrigue and challenge that made their predecessors so renowned.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
r 17, 2015
												Looters and Zombies Oh My!  Think Project Zomboid with a Tactical Battle System!Dead State: Reanimated is all about survival, you start off with a small group of people in a shelter and you can choose how you want to expand, when you want to expand, or who you want to expend.  The game comes with some critical choices that you might need to actually read a guide about if you're working on achievements.  Overall the game deserves at least a 7.5/10 from me and I recommend picking it up, below are some of the key reasons why or why not to!Pros:Rather Unique (in what I've played) noise system in which you fire a gun or shoot off a firecracker and things hear it and go to the location.  Makes for more strategic gameplay, can't always be a firefight, sometimes you want to make noise to attract zombies to enemy locations.  Rather cool system.HUGE fan of Tactical Battle systems that are similar Final Fantasy Tactics and Fire Emblem games, mix in just enough looting, inventory management and rpg elements and you have yourself a solid game.If you're a fan of the Zombie Genre, or being able to Control what happens to your "followers", like say take them to a random location and stab them to death.  Then this is the game for you.Cons:Bugs - In multiple playthroughs I ended up with a character laying flat on his face in the infirmary.  Not sure what this was about.  There was also an endless encounter between Zombies and Enemy NPCs where I did nothing but press spacebar for a few hours and they fought the whole time (eventually I had to restart the encounter).  Mind you, this game is an indie dev and I'm all about supporting smaller companies, so I assume that these bugs will be fixed at a later date even though that later date may be a while away.Price - This is kind of a big one believe it or not, I got the game when it was a bit cheaper so it doesn't affect me as much.  When there are awesome games like Shadowrun out there and many others in this tactical genre at the 15$ price point it makes me question why this game is double the price.  I could understand 20$, I just think anything more than that for this game is a little much.  It's a good game, sure the dev spent a lot of time on it and all.  I'll wait for Dead State's sister game Age of Decadence to be Bundled or go on sale below the 20$ price point before I purchase it.

content:
28, 2015
												Awesome, I like this game a lot.  It reminds me a lot of the original Fallout games.  It's part RPG and part turn based squad level strategy - both game styles I enjoy.  There's enough content and areas to explore to keep you happy for a long time.  It really does feel like 'The walking dead' in many regards, I think the developers have accurately captured the look and feel of a zombie apocolypse.  I'd go as far as to say it's the best game I've played in the last year, and the best zombie game I've seen.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2015
												The definition of the success, to me, is how addicted I am to this game. This game totally got me addicted! It is a successful rendering of Fallout 1 and Tactics. My wife was like, "what the hell are you doing? Why are you glued to the computer day and night." I haven't experienced that since the original days of Fallout.Indie games rarely draw me in. But I must applaud this game's success. Some reviews complain about picture quality and easy level of the game. It is exactly what I am looking for. This game is for those who miss the old days of Fallout 1 and Tactics. I am enjoying this game very much. It caters to a specific group looking for a specific kind of game. It is not for everyone. If you dislike action, open world/crafting/multi-players, RTS and prefer old fashioned turn-by-turn, RPG games. Then this game will be for you.

I'll wait for Dead State's sister game Age of Decadence to be Bundled or go on sale below the 20$ price point before I purchase it.

number of helpful: 52 of 105 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												Now that I've put in a few hours (12) in the game, I can make a pretty comprehensive review on this title.First off- Dead State has rough edges, surely, but overall, it's an enticing zombie survival game, with emphasis on squad and shelter management, improving your abode while trying to weather out the apocalypse. You'll set up your base in a school in a fictional Texas town, trying to make ends meet without succumbing to the horrors of the zombie apocalypse, which is not limited to the shambling dead. The game makes good use of the setting, providing a few differing factions and splinter groups set up in the ruins of the world, each striving to survive- sometimes at the expense of others. You won't be getting many warm welcomes, and most of these will turn out to be ambushes, so that the thugs in question can loot those canned pineapples from your carcass.Thankfully, not all of Texas is going to meet you with guns blazing- sometimes, diplomacy is the way to go, and investing in the skill trees can net you surprising results, varying from avoiding armed confrontation with hostile groups, to negotiating new location information, talking depressed survivors into fighting for another day or even recruiting some of the tough-as-nails survivors to join your growing community. Naturally, characters of nominal importance are the only ones you can actually recruit- you can pretty safely discern hostile troops from their lack of name, and the ubiquitous looter gear they're armed with.After 12 hours, I can safely say that I am glad I backed Dead State- it's proving itself to be pretty much all it boasted, albeit with a few rough edges. I find myself playing 'just one more day', trying to meet up daily demands and the missions on the To-Do list. You're free to explore the end of the world, utilizing your own judgement and goals, although it does pay to placate and bribe your growing group of survivors every now and then, just to keep everybody happy, healthy and ready to eke out a meager existence in a world filled with ravenous undead, trigger-happy looters, gun-toting militias, renegade cops, mercenaries and just ordinary people trying to survive at all costs.Pros:- Solid tactical gameplay. Aside a few odd glitches in the 1.0 (multiple enemies occupying single tile, some impr. weapons losing their ammo charges- pepper sprays, nail guns and the like), you can pretty much plan, and execute raids on the many locations in the game, sometimes taking an active part in offense, sometimes defense, and every once in a while, just playing both hostile survivors and the zombies against each other.- Stealth versus guns-blazing approaches- you're free to use your own judgement in how to deal with each location, but the game will most likely toss a zombie or two on maps where you announce your presence by three rounds rapid.- Varied locations that, although using same buildings from time to time, are still distinguishable from each other.- Emphasis on Survival, instead of shooting one thousand zombies. Stealth, planning and a bit of cloak and dagger can get you in and out of many situations where most games would provide you with one option- violence. In Dead State, violence is usually the last, least desireable option.- Different characters with various backgrounds, motivations, likes and dislikes, which are factored in the daily business of your Shelter. Some are nearly joke characters, while others have to cope with the tragedies arising from losing their loved ones to the zombie plague.- Good range of skills, weapons and choices for improvements on the home base- Great concept art, character portraitsCONS:- Still a bit buggy. Expect they will sort 'em out in the future patches, but be ready for clipping foes, misplaced pepper spray and nail gun magazines, one or two zones where Turn-Based-Combat trigger is broken and the fight will continue, despite no active hostilities. One shut-in recruitable survivor dialogue which should end up in violence, does not.- The game really doesn't give you a heads up that initiating hostilities towards obviously hostile survivor groups first can lead to a MASSIVE negative morale in home base. You see a crazed shooter, you better have them initiate combat, or suffer the consequences.- Static game zones: Sadly, once you've cleared out a game zone, there's nothing left to do there. And you can't mark these looted areas off your map, but have to rely on your own memory.- No way to mark vital resources on the map, like discovering and making note of a sack of concrete mix you'll need later for HQ upgrades.- Some of the menus are still a bit difficult to navigate/ too small to read on higher resolutions.- Survivor inventory management in the HQ is a bit tricky to locate, but once you pick up on the drop-down menu on the upper left corner, you're set. Also, ammo dividing can be achieved with the CTRL-click on ammo stack, after which the portion allocated can be moved to the HQ stockpile, and distributed to your survivors.- No real soundtrack or voices, sound effects that stick to mind.

number of helpful: 33 of 67 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Update: I still haven't beaten the game, but there are a few things I'd like to add to my 10-hour first impressions. The positive recommendation didn't change though. Characters still feel bland. The dialog is, for the most part, very generic and there are many characters in my shelter that I barely know, and didn't even bother to get to know their names. Part of the problem here is that, what makes them special (eventually), comes by way of them taking the initiative to talk to the player about their problems or ideas. Those events trigger at different times, and not very often, which means that most will probably remain forgetable for a long time. This system is fine as it is, but I believe there's much room for improvement there.As I found more people, and as I invited them to the shelter, the game became significantly more interesting and I became much more immersed in it. In the morning of each new day people will talk to the player making requests (like not working today), suggestions and other stuff. There are also crisis events that trigger rarely and result in a meeting between the main characters forming a makeshift, small council to discuss an issue. The role of the player is as the leader of this shelter, so he's expected to have the final word in these matters. There will be some moral dilemmas along the way which at times made me really feel responsible for these people well being.As for the difficulty, I described it as escalating quickly in my first impressions, but after getting good equipment and weapons, along with leveling my character with a focus in combat, that difficulty curve quickly peaked and now is taking a big dive. Combat is way too easy now, especially against zombies. Apparently the main character can't get infected, which, along with the fact that they can no longer do any damage even if they hit me, makes them just an annoyance. Other humans still pose some challenge from time to time, but it's rare. I expect another spike in difficulty soon, otherwise I'd have to say this game has severe balancing issues. In terms of shelter management, even with a character build not meant to excel at that, it has become easier lately as well, though not as much. Raising morale, getting enough antibiotics to keep infected survivors alive, and getting fuel are the main causes of tension. It became incredibly easier after getting a horse, and I expect it to become even easier with a car, so again, I expect events to trigger that will put more strain on resources soon.As for bugs, I found quite a few. I recon many are supposed to be fixed soon, but at the time of writing, there will be some glaring small issues that indicate lack of polish. The only really bad ones were crashes, which only started happening recently, but twice in two days, in which I lost some significant progress. It's my fault for not saving, but an auto-save feature would have been very welcome.One thing I'd like to test is its replayability. I want to create a new character that is all about running a shelter, managing people, leading them in combat, but not being a good combatant himself. That should make the game harder, and I like the idea from a roleplaying perspective, although I don't know if a second playthrough can be different enough for that to be fun. On the other hand, I'd like to beat the game first, but I have no idea if I'm close or not. So there, my opinion of the game improved dramatically because I got totally hooked as time went by. I recognize how hard it must be to balance the tension between the combat and shelter management parts of the game, and for the most part, it does a very good job at it. The text below was written much earlier into the game.---This "review" was written at around 10 hours of gameplay (so pretty early in the context of this game). Up to this point, my experience with the game has been positive. Here's a quick rundown of my experience with it. I've seen many comparisons with other games, so I'm going to frame this in comparison with them. - Unlike TWOM and XCOM, this one plays from the point of view of a specific character that you create in the beginning.- The character creation is fairly simple, but allows for many different playstyles. From looking at the options available, I see that you could play the main character as ranged, melee, shelter manager/leader, or a mixture. I don't see options that would allow secialization on a stealthy gameplay though, which is disappointing. There's 4 general stats (analogue to Fallout's attributes) and around 10 skills with perk choices built into the skill progression system that allows for even more customization.- There's a shelter stage, and a combat stage that would be familiar to XCOM fans, although unlike XCOM, they play the same. In the shelter stage you walk around the shelter talking to people, assigning jobs / upgrading facilities / creating items by interacting with an object, getting or storing items by interacting with a container.- Just like State of Decay, you have to manage the resources of the shelter, in the forms of food, morale, antibiotics, fuel and the mood the specific characters.- When you leave the shelter, you'll see a map whose mechanics will be familiar to anyone that played the original Fallout games, with random encounters and all.- The gameplay in the remote locations you find is close to the original Fallout, with the difference that you control your party members as well during combat. There are many little new mechanics that I like, for instance, if an ally is blocking your way to an enemy, you can swap positions with him by spending two Action Points (also useful if you want a character to shield another). I found the combat part to be very unforgiving and difficulty ramps up quickly while you'll be scrounging for bullets and other stuff.- I found many issues with the text, sometimes being cut off or being hard to read due to lack of contrast with the background, but those instances aren't too bothersome and not game breaking in any way.- The narrative and cast of characters up to this point seems bland. Little of it made me care for them, which I think is a failure in this department, as I think this is important for this game to truly shine. This is one thing I don't want to judge so early into the game, but I would expect to be more immersed in the narrative by now.SummaryI'm having a lot of fun with it. It's fairly nostalgic if you played Fallout, and the mechanics seem to be well designed. Graphically is not very polished, and doesn't seem very unique from an artistic perspective (like TWOM is) which makes it look very generic, but the mixtures of RPG, turn-based tactical combat and resource management mechanics of the game are its greatest assets. I'll update this later on, but this is my first impression of the game. I'd recomend it for anyone that played the original Fallouts and XCOMs, but I doubt this would grab the attention of less patient gamers.

number of helpful: 23 of 47 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2014
												Great old school rpg fun. With all the baggage that entails.Zombies are boring but the conflicts that all disasters create between people are interesting. Dead State understands this, and that's why it manages to remain captivating despite the overdone subject material. It's a turn-based rpg and you travel the post-zombie-apocalypse wasteland in search of loot to bring back to your shelter. There's loads of combat, base building, and managing the personalities in your base. The combat isn't anything to write home about, but it's on par with Fallout 1 & 2. The writing is really great, and one of the best parts of the game is reading through the dialogue you have with the people at your shelter. There's tons of opportunities to be a truly disgusting person without being stereotypically evil.Like all great old school rpgs, however, it's got its fair share of bugs. Don't get me wrong though, it's very playable - there's nothing game breaking - but slight annoyances can add up if you're sensitive to that sort of thing, you little babby. Save often and keep multiple saves to avoid headaches. Graphics are fairly dated, too - although the character portraits are quite pretty.I've played about 26 hours of it and it's definitely super impressive, coming from a small indie studio. More like this please. Maybe with a robot apocalypse next time.

number of helpful: 18 of 37 people (49%) found this review helpful
content:
er 12, 2014
												A combination of old-school (some would say antiquated) turn-based RPG mechanics and survivalist simulation. All over the map in terms of balance and characterization, and the UI is shameful across the board. Over the long haul, however, Dead State's charms begin to manifest. It will take awhile before the game starts to get going. A safe bet for the first-time player is that you'll be about 10-12 hours in before the first character conflicts kick in and you start exploring places more spectacular and atmospheric than deserted small-town main streets and suburbs. Story content is gated by in-game days and it takes about a week (each day an hour or more of gameplay, depending) before things start to really happen. If you can't devote that kind of time or don't have the patience (and not everyone does!) then it's a take-or-leave game. It squeezes surprisingly little from its premise otherwise (there is SO MUCH you could get from a hardcore RPG set in a zombie apocalypse), and clearly marks itself as an earnestly made first game from a new developer. I would say that if you're into 90's Interplay classics, have time on your hands and really, really love zombie fiction, it's worth the $30. Otherwise? Wait for a few patches or get it on sale. But it's worth the look if you're into turn-based RPGs.

								It would help tremendously if this game was actually functional.I am getting sick of Steam allowing games that are not even remotely ready for a public eye to judge it yet, to get a simple 'early access' sticker smacked on it, and go nuts, it irritates the heck out of me.I got this game cause I have a passion for Zombie games. I even have a 'Zombie' category on my library...You could say I really do collect them, and this one's no different. I've followed it for a while, and I like where its going!I got it for my birthday, somebody buying it for me on Steam, but the moment I pushed play, the game flickered from Desktop to black screen several times before the game claims that some 3rd party engine system is not working due to Directx9.0 being required(Well I have 11.0....). Still, the game refuses to play, and there are no functioning fixes on the internet yet(trust me, I tried). Instead the fact that the game crashes to desktop, made Steam **** a brick too. It claimed that I was in Dead State when I wasn't, and showed it as "In-Game: Dead State" several hours after I quit trying...I tried to exit steam but it demanded I 'shut down Dead State' first, which wasn't running, not even in my Task manager. I decided to CTRL+Alt+Del and end Steam's task, then restart it, but even that didn't remove the in-game tag :\I played Mount & Blade Warband for over 6 hours afterwards, and watched Netflix and chatted with friends for 5 hours after that before shutting down for bed, and Steam now claims I have 11 hours invested in this game, which isn't true...The game's just buggy and made Steam angry. :\I recommend 'NOT' buying this game, as it is no where near ready for release, and will 'not' work until they fix the issue, which is apparently because the game doesn't have a 'set to fullscreen' mode yet...

content:
er 11, 2014
												I am not normally the type to write reviews, but I feel that Dead State is worth a break from the ordinary.I have been playing since early access (First Seven Days release) and gone back for multiple playthroughs with each patch release right up until full release.End result, over 300 hours played on this game and I dont feel I have wasted any of them.YES, there are bugs, some of them are immersion breaking, some are annoying, but nothing OVERLY game breaking. The Devs are incredibly quick to respond to any new bugs found and are continually consulting the player base to find and eliminate bugs as they happen. To me, this is incredibly satisfying as I know my opinion as a consumer is valued.As to the game itself?If you are looking for a pulse-pounding thrill ride as you slaughter increasingly tough and varied monsters in graphic ways with an assortment of zany and idiosincratic weapons....Look somewhere else.Dead State is a htoughtful game that encourages you to plan ahead, from catering to the needs and wants of your fellow survivors to deciding when, where and how you and your team will fight.Sometimes it is better to sneak through an area, get what you can and get out quietly.I found I was investing into the fellow survivors, thinking outside the game to better understand thier motives and how best to make them work. A sure sign of good writing (Although you may not believe it simply from appearances)Finally, if like me, you have played more than your fair share of RPG's (especially from the 90's and 00's) the isometric viewpoint, the turn based combat and even the JRPGesque base and NPC collection will tickle all the nostalgia bones and keep you coming back for more.tl:dr?A great game that may still seem a little rough around the edges, but a must have for any RPG and/or Zombie Survival fan

												HelloI finish game at 25.12.2014 and when time I played it there were still some problems with it (expecially with  two level condigantions occasional wall passing trought) but this not change one single thing: this game is absolutly amazing and is this what I was looking for time when last good fallout game ( what was fallout 2) was finished by me.This game is not only about visiting locations one by one and pick up every item You found (but is also liked by me part) but also about human relations, tensions, cooperation and leadership. Some times there is no good deicion to take but You must too. You always upset some one and as more people will be with You that more part of upset will be.(From mechanical look: we got something like crisis event when our little democracy (where You have last voice) make meeting and take decision.).Ofcourse in game are also bad guys, neutral guys and guys who You can just make hate You. So enemies are not really zombie. I will not spoiler story here how ever :-) Only I can say it can be bit more build up of lines with each of group.What else we can found are little stories in locations (some one mention this before me but I found it same way). We got little hut in the forest, with table, blood... some psycho live there? Or some situations moved from culture/games/books - for example You visit bar meeting Mike and Mallory KnoxGame need some fixes but there is nothing what make it not playble. I really really enjoy it.

number of helpful: 14 of 29 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2014
												I would recommend this game if you enjoy the genre or RPGs in general. Although the combat is lacking a bit in depth, it is enjoyable for the most part, and the exploration is interesting. Yes, there are bugs, but with each patch it gets better, and the current build has been extremely stable for me, although ymmv depending on your system config.One of the best parts, in my opinion, is the character stories that play out between days, and the different characters you meet while exploring which include several famous names from movies & past games.Being a story driven game there is good bit of reading involved, so if you're not into that you may not enjoy it as much.The writing is excellent, and is quite funny at times as well as dark & somewhat disturbing at others. As it is right now, I'd give it 7/10 because of the technical drawbacks, but with continued support, patches & polishing, as well as future DLC, it could easily rise to a  10/10 game. (In my opinion)

content:
er 7, 2014
												HUGE Potential, HUGE let down!Being a XCOM veteran I was full of excitement at the thoughts of this game and everytrhing it was supposed to offer, however on starting the game it was a massive dissapointment. The fight engine has left too much to luck and odds "how hard is it to hit a zombie from the front with a sledge hammer?" well according to the programmers its 5 times more likely to land a hit from behind than in front. This being so it takes four team members two rounds with two to three hits each to take out one enemy. I could understand odds being used on XCOM but why with melee weapons and why such appaling odds. And to make things even worse a gun reload takes a full turn. Add to this multiple enemies and you're in for anal decimation. All in all a great idea destroyed by mismanagement of game dynamics.If you're looking for a great zombie apocalypse RPG than buy State Of Decay. A lot better and more fun it has better graphics, game engine, playability, costs less and more lifespan.
