content:
y 10, 2015
												A very good idea which unfortunately wasnt executed well enough. therefore I can not recommend it to others.The game was released before it is ready, probably due to sales season.In an early access you expect bugs, but in the (finished!!) version the amount of bugs were immense. I am not going to list all, as there are forums for these. but I will go through some bugs that ruined my experience below.Good sides,Turn based, tactical combat (not great as there is not cover system etc, but decent)Survival (in the first few weeks you really have to fight for each chocolate bar and manage parts and morale) later on they become irrelevant.open world and a big map.GraphicsGraphics are old but i like it anyway, I am not after shiny textures. Gameplay matters for me.AudioAudio is unfortunately quite poor as music variety is quite limited and static, and there is almost no voice in the game. Characters on levels communicate with subtitles over their heads, which you can easily miss if you are looking elsewhere. There is no message log (like in fallout). There is a combat log which could use some improvement. Sounds effects are below decent.Gameplay.Pathfinding and AI in general is terrible. My characters kept sliding to their destination often through walls. Enemies can also sometimes shoot through obstacles. Enemies can knock down your entire squad without a direct line of sight, using a single granade. (maybe they have thermal vision, which isnt implemented in the game :)  )Interface could really use some polish. there is almost no info on statuses, just an icon which doesnt tell you if that character has reduced strength or perception, etc... Armor in late game is too strong both for you and your enemies. Assault rifles can have problems without critical hits. Zombies are only a threat during first weeks, later on they become a joke, which destroys the mood for a zombie game. Minor bugs are somewhat ok. However, after hours of battling 10+ soldiers/mercs with full armor and assault rifles (to combat is slow, which I like as it is expected in such a genre), to crash to desktop on the last soldier is not fun. dont know about others but I have had so many CTDs. (dont tell me to update my graphics driver, or restart my computer)The quests are also quite poorly made in the sense that the choice you make earlier is not reflected to the next day and people in the shelter complain (or are sick) as if you made the other choice in the crisis event a few days ago. quests dont get ticked off, or people in shelter keep saying the same things over and over.The game is based Looting and keeping your people safe/well fed/ healthy. However in order to loot large maps I had to return to them 10 times.I dont want to sound so harsh (although I probably did with all the critism). it is  a small company and I appreciate that they try to bring old turn /squad based RPG back to life.  it was just an unfinished product with a lot of bugs released earlier than it should have been. if they lack manpower, they should have waited a bit more to polish the game.

content:
er 8, 2014
												A really good turn-based, zombie RPG from DoubleBear with base management and pretty good writing.  There is a lot to explore and a good variety of items.  Interesting art style and great variety of NPC's.  The noise mechanic is also cool.  Enjoyed attracting zombies to a fight with scavengers to pit them against each other.The game has a pretty steep learning curve if you don't read the manual.  A lot of things are not obvious nor intuitive.  The UI is a little clunky and there are still some glitches in the release version, though these are not really game-breaking nor take away from the overall experience.  Mostly some weird moving animations or inability to access containers the first time they are clicked on.Overall, a pretty solid game and fun to explore.  Hopefully some future patches will clean up the bugs and they do some work on the UI stuff.

number of helpful: 9 of 19 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
y 8, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game, but in the end I can't recommend buying it in its current state even after multiple patches.+ Combat can be tense in the early game before you get good weapons/armor because you don't want to attract too many zombies or human enemies all at once. Note emphasis on "early," see below.+ Base management can be fun, especially once you get lots of survivors who then start interacting with each other which can lead to interesting crisis events. Probably the best part of the game.Seems to clearly draw from Suikoden, what with being able to recruit lots of characters to your home base who have vignettes and even being able to build a suggestion box to read often humorous suggestions from them.  Until you get a lot of survivors the base is pretty dead though.+ Can scratch that loot tick before you get tired of looting. Nothing like opening a single container and seeing a ton of nice loot.- The game still has a lot of bugs including ones patches claim to have fixed (see: certain stairs in the hotel only working after rejiggering your whole party position so you can use them, enemies especially zombies clipping into each other while moving and merging into one tile, etc) which can make playing a chore.- Combat breaks very quickly after the early game. You start finding armor that lets you ignore damage, quickly making zombies irrelevant and humans who don't have guns higher tier than the armor you're wearing irrelevant until eventually you have such good armor there are no longer enemies that can threaten you without critting. This cuts both ways and eventually the only significant way you can damage certain enemies is on crits, especially the really annoying ones with riot shields who you should basically not bother with if you aren't critting them with weapon types they're least resistant to. You can find and craft various gas grenades that trivialize combat against human enemies who aren't resistant to gas, which is like 90% of them including the top tier ones since you just blind or even knock them out and then pummel them while they're helpless. A zombie game where zombies quickly become irrelevant because your armor is so good they do nothing to you and humans become almost irrelevant soon after has serious issues.-The interface is one of the worst I've encountered in a long while. You spend a lot of time looking at inventory screens, and because of that what might be minor problems in another game or taken alone quickly add up to become frustrating. There is physically no way to drop an item you realize you don't even care enough about to recycle (see below), you have to dump it into a container somewhere on the map. If you want to move things from the car to your base's stash that don't auto stock, you have to first move it to your main character and then move it into your stash (hope you invested in strength!). You have to move things one by one from character inventories to the trunk in the field because you can't move things from multiple characters inventories like when you trade between characters (another interface issue because you have to actually select it as an action on the field by right click cycling through other options instead of just pressing "I" when you're not in base). I can go on. Again, these might be minor issues in other games or taken alone, but since by this games nature you spend so much time messing with inventories it adds up very quickly. The idea of getting loot in a game with a large emphasis on looting actually became a chore that I began dreading.- You can recycle things you don't want into "parts," one of the resources in base management once you build a building. This is just completely ridiculous. First of all, once you build a recycler, you no longer have to care about parts because you can recycle trash items into more parts than you will ever need. This is a game partially about resource management where you can build an easily accessible building that lets you ignore one of the resources. Let that sink in. The other issue is it encourages you to pick up every piece of garbage you encounter so you can turn them into parts encouraging the most base loot hording behavior. This is already annoying if you're a lootaholic in games like Elder Scrolls series, but compound it with unfun messing with inventories and you can see why I never wanted to see another inventory screen in this game again. They nerfed this building at some point in beta and its still ridiculous. Guys you don't need to try to make every bad idea you come up with work, just delete it and move on.- There isn't really any story until extremely late in the game. I'm talking like 80+ days in. That might appeal to some people, but by like day 30 I had my base pretty much set up and no longer had resource issues. That left 50+ days of basically going through the motions for the sake of it. Resources quickly become irrelevant when you get good transportation so you can bring home hundreds of pounds of materials home in a single day from no longer challenging maps. Lets not even talk about recycling.- I don't care about graphics in RPGs but if you do... play another game. Not much going on in the audio department either.I don't want to keep going because again, I really wanted to like this game. I think they have made an admirable effort considering their situation and resources. But that the people behind it made an admirable effort doesn't mean you should buy a game, and in its current state after beta and multiple patches I can can only recommend this game to extreme fans of the genre who are also extremely forgiving. I like to think I am in that category most of the time, but this game in particular soured me.

content:
r 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								When this game initially came onto early access, I ignored it amidst all the other Z-type games that came out during the same period.  I finally picked up Dead State at a whim and I have to say that I should never have bothered with the other titles.  This game is surprisingly good and interesting to play and makes for an interesting mix of building up your base, finding supplies and trying not to get your teams killed.  No XP for killing stuff, encouraging players to be a little more clever about how they explore and hunt for supplies.  The devs are active and each patch brings about new and tangible enhancements.  This game is definately worth supporting.

ry 25, 2016
												This is a pretty awesome game for a while-- but the story flat out stops around half way though. By 30 game days in, I'd upgraded everything, acquired everything and had enough materials to just skip whole weeks at a time without paying attention. There was no end goal and no indication that I should be doing anything.After looking it up online, I'd found out that the game just --ends-- at around day 90. Day 90?! I finished all of the content by 30! And without spoilers I'd add that the endings to the game offer no closure or sense of accomplishment- they're just events that stop the game.So avoid. This is a game that could have been good, if the last half had been finished.

Early Access Review
								Dead state is a survival Turn based Rpg. It is free roam in the area until u come into combat which then turns to turn based combat with the traditonal grid system, and spend Ap points to move and use actions. The searching and raiding houses for weapons,supplies, and other goodies is a thrill, especially when u get caught off guard in a unfavourable battle. Although still in alpha and still quite a few bugs and not to much content, this game has very good potential to be a great turn based strategy thats not the traditonal swords and shields. I recommend picking this up if you like survival horror (zombies) as well as a good turn based battle system

content:
er 7, 2014
												As far as indie releases go, these guys got it as smooth as anyone on release day. There are bugs, which are getting squashed. So far none of them have really bothered me or my game and im really diving it this game. One bad patch came out and was quickly rectified, which happens to the AAA devolepers too. I wouldnt really hold it against doublebear.The game itself hits my sweet spot of gaming. Turn based, rpg, strategy gaming with base building. The closet analogy game released recently would be Wasteland 2. So its easiest to compare them and would be relevant to most gamers too:Dead State (DS) has base building which i love. Wasteland 2 (WS) doesn't have this, and the way that game was made makes it seem like it SHOULD have been in there. The way the second half of WS was written it seems like it should have been included and it to me it felt like a great chance to extend that game was ignored.WS was too campy in my opinion. It made far too many referential jokes and nods and what not to the previous game and the genre in general. I felt that was a mistake. DS tries and succeeds in maintaining a better immersion in the zombie filled world and takes itself seriously. So over all DS beats WS in its game world.On the negative side DS needs to be balanced still. Combat goes from wildly hard to wildly easy. Not long into the game only a few characters can mow down a battalion of zombies with little effort. That being said, the inclusion of so much fighting other humans can be tricky. You will find in the long run, its the living humans that are truely the real enemy in the game. But im sure as the patches come, feed back is gathered, and balance is achieved, this won't be a negative for long. Graphics are passable for the game, but they bog my machine down way more then should. If you have a low end machine you might run into problems with graphics on anything other then lowest settings. My machine is middle of the road and i have to run middle of the road graphics. While comparative games generally run much better. This is probably an optimazation issue, which of course, tends to get taken care of in patches. From the already released patches it seems like they are trying to get this ironed out. There plenty of stuff to find and loot in the game. Much of it though is not anyting more then having the words FOOD and LUXURY ITEMS written on a holder card and given different names. While they may be 1000 items inthe game, 900 of them are functionally identical, but the fact i can horde up toilet paper and candy bars makes the game feel more immersive then it really is as far as loot is concerned. I almost wish the game made a distinction though between toilet paper and tooth paste and it didnt just all end up as one pool when you bring it back. But that would probably have made the game turn into a consumables stockpile sim, which i might like, but i bet most gamers wouldnt. So I accept the way it is, and be happy enough with it.I would have liked more base building features. Base defense battles (which may or may not be included but i have yet to see one). More weapon and armor types (though honestly there already a lot, but i just would like more). My biggest gripe is the lack of documention of some things. I find data items before I am told how they could can used, so i spent a long time trying to figure out why i couldnt access them in the library. I also got confused when unlocking blueprints inthe workshop had the same icon as the actual item construction. So i did blueprints and couldnt tell know could build the item, i thought it just made more blueprints. But fortunately the devolpers watch the forums and answered in minutes (literally minutes) and i got it sorted out. But its a good sign the game is complex enough to not be instantly figured out, but i would have liked better tutorials/documentation. If you read this whole review, you will know i am whole heartedly recommending this game. This game had me up til the sun rose the day of release playing it. Its probably been 2 or 3 years since a game did that to me. Thank you to the devolpers for making this game!

Also you apparently have to have some peircing, tattoo, or hair style fetishes because thats what's offered. character progress either as a preprogrammed set of improvements, or the main character can select where the points go. However, there is no xp bar or knowledge of when or where those improvments are coming from. you just check character screen every so often and go - yay!Inventory screen is severely lacking. When you return to base, only main chacter is accessible. Meaning he/she has to have all property on self in order to go through it. There is an auto remover for community items, but the items npcs are carrying are unaccessible at this point. Game was feeling linear in beginning; approaching a more sandbox like environment? I like that now your ( upto four man) team can now move somewhat independent by hitting j-key. It appears that game is leading us to the point where we can possibly recruit human survivors. Will all people be possible to talk to? or just a few scripted ones? Will a dialogue option be added to support this? My current experience is to visit local park, be attacked and win then be told back at base that I am a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ for killing an innocent!?!  No control over that so I assume it's in fix mode. content:
er 9, 2014
												You can get a review of the features from different places. These are my impresisons.Is the game perfect? No. Is the game very good? No.Is the game good? Maybe.Is the game fun? Maybe.Let's get the elephant out of the way early. Dead State has a host of issues. Combat is simplistic. The zombies aren't really a threat. There are numerous bugs and I have experienced numerous crashes. Certain game concepts are poorly explained. The UI can be rough in places, especially dealing with inventory. You can't eject people from the shelter. Areas don't get monster respawn. Enemies are always in the same place on every game, limiting replayability. The list goes on. So there are many legitimate reasons why some people may not like it. Yet I enjoyed it for a while. The game feels old-school, almost in an original Fallout sense. It plays slowly and methodically and you have a chance to really get to know the world. Issues and situations are thrown at you, sometimes with no easy answer. It has that "one more day, one more turn" feel that most good games have. I always have something to do, explore, build and always a new situation to handle. The person who is bit - do I get them out of the shelter because they're using up all my antibiotics? Or do I do the merciful thing and keep them here? How do I handle an abortion issue?Does a woman's right to choose outweigh the necessity of repopulating the human race? Do I go fishing for food or do I try to scout that new camp to find supplies to reinforce our wall? Combat at times is difficult and after a fierce fire fight you can feel tired, not elated, but it's always nice to get the spoils of your victory. This is one of the first Kickstarter games I backed and I don't regret it because I wanted to see a game like this made. I had some fun playing it and it piques my imagination. There are many areas where the game could be improved and maybe that will happen and maybe that won't. If it does, Dead State may become a very good game. If it doesn't, I still got some enjoyment for my time spent with it. So why the negative review? The game is just simply too poorly balanced and too buggy to recommend. Combat is horribly unbalanced - you'll want one type of weapon and one type only because it's so vastly superior to everything else. Zombies are so easy to beat that they present no challenge whatsoever. A zombie game where you aren't afraid of the zombies is not a good thing. Bugs abound everywhere, including some show stoppers that won't let you finish the game. The NPCs that you meet aren't really interesting and their stories don't really go anywhere. The only threats are other humans and most of those interactions are exceptionally simplistic and almost all end in firefights. So between the balance, the bugs, the dull NPCs and the simplistic combat, after the first few hours you've seen everything the game has to offer. Simplistic combat + unscary zombies + few tactical options + bugs + simplistic NPC interactions  = unhappy Blackadar. It's too bad too because this game was close to being very good. It just needed another 6 months of real polish before release. It didn't get it. Long story short, you MIGHT have some fun with this if you're old school like me. But eventually you will probably tire of the bugs, balance an bad NPCs and you'll toss it away. I stuck with it to the bitter end, including an ending that required console commands to get past game stopping bugs, but that's because I'm a glutton for punishment. So I have to give it a thumbs' down. Go give your money to the Shadowrun games instead - better stories, better settings, better combat and better balance.

												The is nothing in gaming history that I find more tedious, more unrewarding, than rolling a miss in a rpg.  Despite that, crpg's have been a staple of my game purchases for years.  For me, it's a "good outweights the bad" trade off.  That is not the case for Dead State.   Layered on top of tedious combat is Dead State's painfully plodding pace, slow performance and lackluster features.  This makes for a totally unrecommendable game. I liked the concept of the game and I do supprt the resurgance of crpg's.  That's why I contributed to this game and others like it on Kickstarter.  Unfortunately there is nothing classic about this game.  It is a shame, really.  Just from the amount of dialog you know they put a lot of work into the game.  They do continue to patch the bugs and promise more content.  But ultimately I don't find it worth the time.

content:
r 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I remember reading about this game months ago, and then kind of forgetting about it. After completing a game of Wasteland 2, the turn based RPG bug bit me again.. totally reminding me of FO,FO2, and Jagged Alliance of days past. I searched steam for some more, and rememberd Dead State.Ive put some decent hours into Beta Patch #2 so far and I really like where this is going. Its got all the elements of past turn based RPG's (ie. combat, micromanaging, strategy, building) and more. You wake up as part of a group in a school, which becomes your "base". You have to stock that base with food, weapons, etc.. from surrounding areas, all while looking out for zombies and bad guys. Along the way, more can join your group and you have access to all the group for job tasks or scavenging. You dont level up by killing anything, you level up by completing "shelter goals". Some of the goals include gathering so much food, med supplies, luxuries, etc.. I thought this was a neat way to gain more skills for your characters, totally away from the norm of killing for skill. I like it.Im on day 25 or so on beta patch #2, and I'm coming to the point where I may have taken in too many people at once, so each day ends up being a search for food more than anything, luckily there are "fishing spots" to walk to and test your luck harvesting fish. In fact, I see the potential to have hundreds, if not thousands of locations on the map along with encounters because of the way the map scren and travel works.. this could be a pretty content loaded game moving forward.My Jagged Alliance heart wants to see more specialized firearm variants, as right now, they seem to have one firearm per ammo type. This may be wishful thinking, but would be pretty cool moving forward. I know its the zombie apocalypse, but cant that dead soldier just be carrying a MK17 SD variant or something ;)I'm sure others will complain about the "graphics" in some cases, but for me, they dont matter as much.. these games are about the adventure, the open world, the choose your own tasks, the story.. you make it what you want to survive. The true turn based RPG thrives non-linearly, and this game certainly has that potential.All in all, the game is well worth the purchase, even at this early access stage. I think we are in the middle of a turn based RPG game renaissance, and I couldnt be happier about it.  If you like this sort of game, micro managing little pixel squads of people, and, well, the zombie apocalypse.. get Dead State now, you wont regret it.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								The First Seven Days of Dead State's Zombie Apocalypse Tactical Survival Game   The game as it is just a glimse into the final product, call it as an early access, demo or whatever, it is just the first seven days of the storyline with limited access to some of the features. Still, I am very impressed and excited by the game.   First of all it is a very traditional old school roleplaying game, the combat is great turn-based, very similar to Jagged Alliance 1 or 2, or Fallout 1 and 2, even to UFO series (the old ones especially). There is character sheets and stats to improve which have some effect in game. Obviously in the end game we might see better how these skills and attributes (and even perks that is not yet in the game but planned) will influence the game and give a boost to replay value.   The theme is from the Romero's zombie movies mostly. Zombies are slow, dead bodies, no mutations and freak abilities, differs mostly by the state of corpse. If you are fan of Romero's movies you would like this. If you are expecting a huge range of monsters then you will be disappointed. But if you can get along with it you might have a nice experience. The true enemy is the conditions, the lack of resources, other human beigns who compete for what left, ad your own group. There is a good amount of social dynamism even in such early state of the game and this will be just better. You influence your group morals by what kind of job you assign to them, who are you taking out to the dangerous scavenging missions, how much you listen to their advices and who do you listen to, and so on. There is a hint that there will be some power struggle among the group in later in game.   The tactical combat is good enough, if you learn the tricks it is not very hard, but honestly sometimes it can be difficult if you are not careful and the game can punish you very much if you are not careful or do a mistake. That is good in fact and makes the game just more interesting. If you are fan of turn based tactical combat, this game is for you. Weapons do have some special attributes, like cutting weapons can cause bleeding to living beigns, crushing weapons can cause disorientation, with some weapons you can knock your enemy prone and so on. Also there are some psychological conditions in effect, like panic when you are overrunned by zombies (a sure way to die quick).    There is penty of improvement to be made of course, and I list some which I think would make the game even in early access better. 1) Inventory screen: at this point I could not be able to reach the other survivors inventory at the base, and as you only able to command your main character in the area you have only a very ineffective way to equip your companions. A screen where your in-party companions could be equipped from the base storage would be great). Also it would be nice to be able to drop items to ground or just simply to exchange with others in the tactical maps. At the moment I only found one solution to trade items with companions, and that is to utilize the 'containers' already placed in game, put the items there and then change the control to other character and get those.2) It would be nice to see some notes or hints in the maps you have. You encounter empty houses, or places with some corpses and you wonder what's happened there. It would add to the horror if either you might able to collect clues what happened or youhave your companions comment on the situation.And finally I want to praise the music. It is great, melancholic, sad, but also in a way calming. It gives back something of the theme wandering in a city emptied of life. Well done and thanks fr th experience. I am looking forward to the final game and any updates.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2015
												I really, really wanted to like this game.I’ve been watching it for a long while and started playing around Halloween. I am a big fan of turn-based games, base-builders and the zombie apocalypse-survival genre. Dead State is mature in theme and has a lot of different luxury goods to try and keep your group happyDead State is a graphically good looking game, but unfortunately one rife with bugs.There are typos, and floating inventory items – but these minor issues which can be over looked. A big problem in the game for me was when I had started building the well for my base. My project leader became sick and had to take a day off from working on it. When she returned to work the next day, the game refused to recognize that any of my characters possessed a crowbar, which was deemed a requirement for the task. I equipped her with three, in every imaginable slot. Nothing seemed to appease the game. While I was frustrated, I was determined to play on.The Coyotes are a violent, enemy group of rival survivors and they are VERY powerful in the early game. After several attempts to defeat them (there were no diplomatic options) I decided that you had to run from them. The Coyotes fire their weapons discriminately in combat and the sounds draws wave after wave of undead reinforcements down upon you.  Added to this, there are situations where, in combat, your move options are limited by fallen companions, KO’ed foes, terrain and areas of control of standing combatants, effectively trapping your characters so that they cannot fight enemies, while your foes continue to pump you full of lead. In tight spaces this can be lethal for your group.I finally quit in frustration. I really wished that this game could have been more polished.

												Pros:- Combat- Base building- Dialogue options that yield different results (cause NPCs to attack you, gain an ally, etc.)- Overworld map and various travel methods- Interesting random encounters and eventsCons:- Base building, job board, character menu, daily results, and inventory UIs- Looting and inventory management- Random game crashes (10 crashes in 66 hours of game play)- Lose an ally's items if they permanently leave your roster- Limited camera angles- On certain levels, the corpses of your enemies may disappear along with their lootPlayed through once just to see to the end. It was fun for the first 30 hours. Would not replay on harder difficulties due to the tedious looting and inventory management.

content:
er 4, 2015
												I purchased this game with high hopes from reading other reviews, but was ultimately disappointed. After a few hours of play I don't feel the game is really as described in its marketing.It seems that Dead State is mostly about crafting and shelter maintenance, with some exploration and combat (and some other negative reviews have described the awful combat system already). These are things I have zero interest in. I was hoping for the "social management" and "narrative" parts to be stressed more. Instead, there appears to be no story at all, no narrative, nothing driving the game save for the shelter.While this may be realistic in a zombie apocalypse survival scenario, I just hoped for more in the way of RPG and less in the way of "scavenge small items and make something out of them." This would have saved it from being as slow and boring as it turned out to be.As an aside, there are also numerous bugs with the tutorial text appearing to give you tips about things you did 5 minutes ago, or are no longer in the room for, etc. More care needs to have been taken with editing and overall experience by the player.Totally disappointed, although someone else more interested in crafting a shelter could find this game fun.

content:

												Attention!I previously wrote a review NOT reccomending this game but I changed my mind.Yes the game had issues that forced me to stop playing after say 8 hours. Yes it is still buggy and sometimes feel unfinished, but this is a game that rewards patience. It has a steep difficulty curve and has some dodgy gameplay mechanics at times, but it gets better.I have now spent around 15 hours and I come back for more.What I like:* Varied locations with a lot of attention to details.* Subplot told through collectibles that has suprising depth. Yes you can miss it and that is the lack of handholding rarely seen today.* A truly believable story of what it means to be a leader of what could be the last of humanity.* A cynical undertone of contemporary politics.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								After almost 17 hours of play, I can see the game has a lot of potential.  This version allows you to play the first seven game days of Dead State.  It gives you plenty to do and see.  I have played through twice.  There seems to be a solid framework starting to take shape concerning the characters and their personalities in the shelter.  Each seem to have their own needs and desires and balancing these while trying to be productive and survive will be a factor.  The combat is reminiscent of X com, with action points required to move and to perform different attacks (based on the weapon equipped). The Shelter, your base of operations, can be improved with different structures providing additional benefits (only "the well" upgrade is available in this version) . Different characters have certain skill sets that allow them to perform task at the Shelter as well , some based on materials on hand, others based on what improvements you have constructed.You must decide when you venture forth if your going to leave a person behind at the shelter to work on a task or an improvement , or, to bring them along as part of the scavenging party.  The more people left at the shelter, the faster improvements get built, but the weaker the scavenger party is which could be catastrophic if you run into trouble.I enjoyed my time playing, even in this products current state, bugs and all (and there are bugs, but I expected that).  I can see the potential and I am optimistic about the final release.  I already pre purchased through doublebears website shortly after the kickstarter sign up ended.  The product description and early info was enough to convince me it would be a game I would enjoy.  If your on the fence about purchasing the game, $24 might be a steep price to pay to try it out.  Waiting for the demo might be a better bet.  I on the other hand view the current state as a bonus.  The devs have opened up their product early to the community and are very receptive to comments and feedback, and will be updating the build as time goes by.  I can't wait for the final release!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 10, 2015
												I was pretty shocked to see that my original review of this game seems to have vanished -- it wasn't very flattering.  I can only assume it's MIA because now this is Dead State: Reanimated.So let me begin by saying that I was an original backer for this game, and I have followed it's development closely.  It showed great promise and intrigue, and there appeared to be a great dynamic between the devs and community.  That was, until Christmas 2014.In what was the most apparent and appalling cash-grab I have ever seen by any professional entity, Double Bear Studios knowingly and willingly released this game in an unfinished, buggy, crash-ridden state.  The flame war which ensued between the community and devs is the stuff that legends are made of.  I've hopped back to this game from time-to-time, in the hopes that it was finally completed in a halfway competent matter (again, great premise for a game and I love to support indie studios), but it looks like the project is finally been abandoned by the devs in a semi-working state.  It's still a POS final product, just not as big and stinky of a POS as when it was first released.Pros:Great premise of a game --  Walking Dead meets Jagged AllianceConsEverything Else!Game is still buggy as hell.  Don't even think about trying to play it on Windows 10.Graphics and music are just okayCombat is slow, slow, slooooooooooowwwwwww ... and equally boring.Almost non-existent base building.  Some upgrades are available ... but .... meh.Scripted locations and drops from scripted enemies.  Zero replay value because of this.  Almost zero percent random.A few different endings ... but nothing really that special.  Nothing that would make a player want to go back, retrace his/her almost exact steps again while dealing with the bugs and crashes.$30.00!!!!??  $30.00 for this POS buggy, game!??  Someone is seriously smoking crack if they think that's gonna fly.In Conclusion:I would suggest you don't buy this game.  Instead, spend a few hours reading through the forums starting at Christmas time, 2014.  The evolution of the flame war and the devs self-destruction of this game is far more entertaining and engrossing than the game itself -- and it's free.

												This game is out of keeping with my general purchases, but as it was on sale I felt it was worth a go.In many ways this game feels like it could be mission-based content for one of the "Rebuild" games, which I certainly mean as a compliment.Theaspects that let this game down mainly revolve around combat. In combat the game feels like a clunkier version of X-COM. The pace is slower than X-COM's, too slow in fact due the difficulty level of game and this leads to the game being less desirable to play for long periods and, conversely, impossible to play for just short periods.However outside of combat; the plot line is compelling, more so than "Sheltered" or "This War of Mine" which are, conceptually, very similar games to this, albeit in the 2D format. The characters are very varied, particularly when you consider the large number of them and the dynamics between them are intruiging and quite realistic,htis adds greatlyto the hames playability.Overall I wouldn't spend full price on it and due to pacing I may never finish a game to completion, but in generalI think it will provide an enjoyable distraction fromt he real world.

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Potential, potential, potential.While there's not that much content yet (at least not released to public) and the updates are a bit slower than what I'd like... if you are fan of the zombie genre, this game is for you. It's not the ultimate zombie game, but it's a different take from all the other similar themed products out there.If you are into the more psychological aspect of the zombie survival, buy buy buy. That's not to say there isn't combat, but that's not the reason why this game shines.<< 09/26/14 UPDATE >>So the game has hit BETA state and the first patch has been released. I've also become a bit more active in the game's forums and learnt a couple things that I'd like to share with potential buyers.First, the game is meant to be SHORT. In game time is estimated to be about 3 or 4 months. This is worrysome when you consider that it'll probably take you less than 2 months to kill and loot EVERYTHING in the rather small area map you get to explore. This would mean that you'd spend a substantial amount of time either idle or simply dealing with repetitive task like assigning jobs or going to auto-gather locations.Talking about locations, a lot are on the small size. In most cases, you get to explore an area with only a couple of enterable buildings, which further decreases game time.Combat is still pretty straight forward and rather easy. My biggest worry hasn't been zombies or hostile survivors, but loot capacity. Once you know where you can find a good armor and a decent weapon (usually melee), you can go there almost straight away and get kitted out. Unless they substantially change how combat behaves (specially remove the player's ability to run behind an enemy and begin combat, thus always getting the first shot), I can't see it become challenging. Even big groups can be split appart by causing noise, which usually leads one or two members straight into your ambush just around the corner.Can't really comment much on the game's story as of yet because a lot of the script and dialogues have not been implemented or are currently not working, but even though it does seem to be shaping up to be an interesting zombie survival story, the presumed lenght of the campaign worries me greatly.I'd still recommend the game to any zombie fanatics out there, but be sure to know what kind of game you are getting into.All in all, I would recommend you go check out Project Zomboid before you buy this one, because even though the graphics are worse, it's got the survival aspect nailed down MUCH better than Dead State, and survivor AI is also in the works there.PD: There's no plans of allowing modding to the game either, at least from what I've seen and read.<< 14/03/15 UPDATE >>Well, after waiting for a good while for some kind of patch or content update I find myself abandoned by the developers. There hasn't been any major changes since December and from what I've seen, the Devs already said that the planned "expansions" have been called off because the game didn't sell well enough. What does that mean? You'll get a few more patches that fix what should have been functional on release day and perhaps a few more game mechanics that also should have been there on release day. Then, it's game over for Dead State.I am angry at myself for thinking that this could be any good. I've been following this since Alpha and I should have known that this team could not pull off such an ambitious project. Ambitious because it was something new, not because it was something hard to do. Honestly, with dated graphics and game mechanics that seem out of the 90s, how could this game take them two years to make? And don't get me started on the ending and the plot holes and so much other stuff.Bottom line, Dead State brings nothing new to the party. Combat hasn't been improved. Its boring, repetitive and cumbersome (when it doesn't bug out). The story is lame and the characters - while they have a few moments - are blanks that say their lines (the very few they have) and stand around in your shelter doing absolutely nothing. Music is nothing to be remembered. The rest of the game mechanics - specially the survival aspect - are badly implemented, break immersion or simply make no sense.What more can I say? I've been warning the devs about these faults for a long time on their forums and I was always met with blind optimism or simple denial. Now we are 3 months after release and it's exactly what I thought was going to happen: A disaster.To any possible customer:You want Combat? > H1Z1 / DayZ Standalone / DayZ ModYou want Survival? > Project ZomboidYou want story? > The Walkind Dead by Telltale Games, S1 and S2Changing my recommendation to a thumb down. Sorry, but you truly earned it DoubleBear.

content:
ber 24, 2015
												I played it when it was just released unfinished in Dec 2014. Then  I finished it once as Reanimated. And then again. So yea, I liked it. I think i have 200+ hours in it.I can only recommend to play it on hard difficulty and iron-man. Then you have to absolutely manage the noise, or you will get swarmed by zeds. Of course AI doesn't care about noise, so you have to plan accordingly.I do agree that combat is kind of lackluster, but I've seen worse. And you have to love looting and screwing around with inventory. Tons of items: weapons, luxury items, food etc. If you decode the messages and then read them in order, you will get some backstory.Game has some balance issues depending on your skill choices. For example if you go for the Lab ASAP (using your character) and take perk double antibiotics, on the long run it is very beneficial (you will end up with all skills maxed out +29 unused). But it will be hard first 10 days. Especially encounters with coyotes biker gang. Min-maxing makes game easier too, balanced chars are usually harder to play.Playing "good" hippy type is easier than complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (much harder as you will not recruit as many followers).I never had a crash in reanimated. Shelter inventory window sometimes gets a minor bug which goes away after restart. My last play-through i haven't found Galaxy Wars limited edition, but it is not crucial (just a mood boost for ally).Juts try the demo and decide for yourself. It's so far the best turn based Zed-RPG IMO.

content:
er 6, 2014
												X-com in a Zombie holocaust.You're either completely sold on that premise or don't know what Im talking about. If you're in the same group as I am, and hearing those words makes you go "OMGOMGOMGOMGOMGOMG", then the game was made specifically for you in mind.This is and indie labor of love devoted to a very specific game mechanics that lots of old school gamers like myself find lacking in todays "PEW PEW" marketplace. People in that group probably know who they are and can accept the quibbles of low budget games like this so long as the broad strokes work, and they do for the most part.Like many criticisms have likely pointed out, the game is definitely unintuitive in certain areas, inventory management being the one that immediately springs to mind. However, in fairness, many of the criticisms I see people saying certain things aren't in game when in fact they are, such as Group inventory management at base, attacking diagonally (must have a two handed weapon). However these features can be lost in the somewhat clunky interface.Basically, the idea of an old school base management turn based RPG in a zombie holocaust either sells you on it's own, or it doesn't. If that premise whets your whistle, you'll likely be able to look past some of the quibbles of indie game design in favor what they did right, which is quite a lot. You'd also be able to look past the unfortunate release timing of the game which puts in smack dab in the middle of zombie mania in pop culture, when in fact at it's inception that would have made it a much more original concept.

												UPDATE:With the new "Reanimated" release I felt like bumping this game again.Many of the bugs/issues that were present in previous iterations are now fixed, bear in mind I managed to complete the game before this update encountering only a couple of major issues, but some players encountered more, well...If you haven't tried Dead State yet, I highly suggest to do it now.*****You can craft, you have to interact with a lot of npcs, you have to scavenge for food and other resources, build and fortify your shelter, explore a vast map, you have to fight for those resources against gangs, other survivors and random crazy dudes and you do it in a very good turn-based way, your choices matter, but is not like this world is frozen in time, waiting for you to take a decision.Oh and of course there are zombies, zombies at your door, zombies on the streets, in the stores, in the houses, in the forest...So if this is what you are looking for in a game, well you just found the perfect game: an open world, turn based zombie apocalipse survival RPG.

												I've enjoyed it.  This last patch is kinda buggy, which is unfortunate that it's the release patch and so many people are getting down on the game.  More than my money's worth in entertainment, but like I said, the release patch is kinda buggy and crashy, but it will be patched up.As an example, in my best run, I had about 40 survivors with me, each with their own abilities that level up, we travelled by horse everywhere and did our best to survive by picking fruit, fishing fish, and killing zombies. content:
er 4, 2014
												A great indie title by veteran AAA game developer talent (formerly of Troika and Obsidian). The Zombie Apocalypse meets the narrative-driven styling (and structure) of the classic Infinity Engine games. If you like strategy RPGs, choice-driven narrative, and/or the setting, then this game is well-worth your time.Update 06/10/15: I spent a lot time with the game in beta and a bit at launch, but held off playing the game all the way thorugh because every crowdfunded game needs a while to work out the kinks. The wait was well worth it. Double Bear released a "Reanimated" edition with a slew of new content to go along with their latest patch. The game I played was a mix between a "Tactics" game, Suikoden, and your standard zombie apocalypse fare. What Dead State offers which is unique is the chance to take on the zombie apocalypse on a large scale. It is not a tightly narrative experience like The Walking Dead or an action/survival horror game like Resident Evil. Here, you get to do the stuff they do in the movies or on TV - gather survivors, build a safe place, manage your society, and explore out into the world in order to scavenge, find out what's going on, and find something that lets you hope for a better tomorrow. The game plays out on a large canvas.If you are a RPG fan and/or like zombie stories, then this is a "must" purchase for you. It is also a *very* long game with different ending conditions depending on how you traverse the storyline. There are various modes (difficulty, infection levels, etc.) that offer solid replay value. You get your money's worth with this one.

content:
er 13, 2014
												Day 9. Didn't sleep a wink, Elaine was on the stairwell sobbing again setting everyone on edge. Doug's been needling me to take her on a scavenge and leave her gutshot out by the old church. He figures it will draw them out as we slip in the back, given it was an emergency shelter before it was overrun. A lot of provisions in there Doug says, and with Elaine gone, one less mouth to feed means one more meal for me. But I doubt Davis would buy it, that wily cripple likes to remind us of how he took us in. And now the bleeding heart's handing over the last of our antibiotics to some Mexican kid with the bite. I swear to the God that abandoned us, I'd walk down the halls putting a bullet in each of them as they slept if it weren't for the fact that the fence has a hole you could fit a bus through and the noise would bring them in from three counties. Now isn't the time for division. No one survives out here on their own; looters, the dead, or Coyotes, one of them will find you. Make enough noise like the Sheriff did, and maybe it'll be all three.So I hunker down, listen to Elaine bleat and I earn my keep... bushwhacking and scavenging, two or three times more than most. And for what? Another week of waiting to die chewing half rations of Mr Munchie bars and mouldy fruit. I guess it ain't all bad. The new guy that showed up just gave me some chilli sauce and some rechargeable batteries. With all that's wrong in this messed up world, I have to admit, my mood's better already.

content:
er 7, 2014
												Dead State stands alone as a Zombie TBS Rpg, mostly because there aren't any others. The game's core is great, the concept is spot on, and Turned based strategy is, in my opinion, the best mechanical base for a zombie game. The final product isn't as good as I hoped it would be when I first read about it two years ago. But I still think the released game is enjoyable, if short of the potential the setting and style could have provided. IssuesDead State uses the Torque engine just like Age of Decadence, its not that pretty. Better than 2d pixels but it also lacks the "retro charm" some pixel games capture. There is very little scripted content like what is found in Age of Decadence, I enjoyed that content in AOD and wish some of these engine utilizations made it into Dead State. Its psuedo open world, you really have no choice in where you go or stay only in the order of actions. This is the biggest issue I have with game. There is very little emergent content, and NPC interactions are very limited. Its either friendly will join you, or shoot first ask questions later. If you shoot first you make everyone sad though.UI is clunky and this is a title you should read the manual for, otherwise you will be complaining about follower item management in the forums. The goodIts a zombie tbs RPG!Classic zombies, ie walking dead style. No sci-fi exploding, mutuant jumping zombies. Could use more of them on screen at once IMO. All the classic themes are present. Gather supplies, fix up your shelter, defend against zombies and bandits, or be a bandit. Good selection of weapons, items, skills, upgrades, etc. You can build a self sustaining fortress, but you can't leave and live in a house of your choosing. This is a great base and I'm excited to see what/when mods get ahold of it.

number of helpful: 26 of 54 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												I'll try to write this review as objectively as I can, but this is my dream game.  I have been waiting for a turnbased zombie rpg with base building most of my life.  Overall the game fulfills this dream.  All it needs to be perfect is a sandbox mode for after you've played through the story several times and seen all the endings.  The devs have stated they may add that some day.The writing and characters are the best I have seen in a long time.  This is due to the writing talent and experience the devs bring.  The head dev is Brian Mitsoda, the head writer for Vampire: Bloodlines.  His wife, Annie VanderMeer Mitsoda of Neverwinter Nights 2: Storm of Zehir, also contributed her writing talent.Some may find the combat simplistic, but this game is an rpg, not a strategy game and the combat is no simpler than a classic rpg like Baldur's Gate.  There is enough variety in weapons, armor, and special gear to keep combat interesting and allow for a variety of tactics.  Especially with the inclusion of the noise mechanic that attracts zombies.Other reviews may mention bugs, and when it was first released it had a few major ones.  However they have been resolved and the remaining ones can sometimes be annoying but there is nothing game stopping.  The devs work hard to fix them and have released several patches since release.Considering they raised just over 300,000 on kickstarter, I think it is amazing what they pulled off.  I can only imagine what they could have done with the millions other rpgs had raised on kickstarter.So in summary, if you like classic turn based rpgs with some base building added in, you should like Dead State.

Dead State has been coming out for quite some time now and just recently got released under early access on Steam, if you aren't a HUGE fan of it please do not buy it or you will be disappointed with the length. number of helpful: 20 of 42 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
er 24, 2014
												I've played this game for over a year now, starting way back when it was limited to a 7 day run.  In that time, it has grown and evolved immensely.  If you've played games such as Fallout 1-2. Brotherhood of Steel, or the Final Fantasy Tactics games, or even any of the X-COM franchise, new or old, the isometric view and turn based combat will be familiar and nostalgic.  The game is not a graphical powerhouse, and was never intended as such, it is much more focused on the story, on the myriad and drastically varied group of people thrust together into a desperate survival situation.Every one of the more then 40 characters is unique, from the first handful you start out with to the dozens more you can find and recruit over time, they each have their own desires, demands, and (in some cases) psychosis.The zombies, while an ever present obstacle, aren't the real threat, but then, they really never are.  From as far back as the first forays into the genre, (Night of the Living Dead, Dawn of the Dead, etc,) the zombies are a foe, but not the major threat.  The major threat is, as always, other people.  The dead are easy to predict, simple and direct.  Your living foes, the duplicitious, under handed, cruel, desperate or just good old fashioned bat crap crazy other survivors of this world of central Texas are where the real challenge lays.  They are, by their very nature, completely unpredictable, and profoundly deadly.Over all, this game, while it certainly does have its rough spots, is absolutely worth the money.  The dedication and detail that the development team has put into this title shows through any of the realtively minor remaining bugs, and will likely provide many hours of enjoyment.UPDATE:The Reanimated rerelease, update, add-on, what ever you want to call it, adds a lot more polish and even a small amount of new content for no additional price.  While it was a game worth picking up a year ago, it still is, remaining a rare gem of the early access system.

number of helpful: 18 of 38 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
er 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I am not a big fan of RTS games (I'm old and slow) so I tend to really gravitate towards turn based games.  So naturally I was very interested in Dead State and followed its development for some time (seems like a really long time).  I didn't actually buy it and begin playing until update 3. I really wanted to wait until release but curiosity got the best of me.There aren't a whole lot of games that do turn based isometric combat really well.  Dead State doesn't do anything new in that regard either, in fact the combat, even though it can be quite a challenge until you get decent armor, weapons and skills it is really very simple. There is no cover, crouch, stealth or very many combat options at all. But it still manages to be very engaging and fun.  With that said it really isn’t the combat that make this game so engrossing.Dead State does a great job of drawing you into the world it’s created.  You need to struggle to survive. You need to struggle to keep your base running. You need to struggle to get along with your ever growing group of personalities, oops I meant fellow survivors.  You’re in charge but you’re challenged to stay in charge.  You have to choose whether to allow in, or to keep some useful troublemakers.  Word of warning some people might not be what they seem to be!  As the game has developed through various updates; it’s now on update 5.5, the dialog has gotten a little more polish. It is fairly deep as it is but it could be deeper, just a slight knock in that department. The stories are compelling but a little shallow. There is plenty to do at the base, but also not much to do at the base at the same time. I know that’s confusing let me explain. The game progresses at the close of each day, sort of a big "end of turn".  Every day you set up your job assignments and go out into the word to scavenge. Back at base after you talk to your fellow survivors, there a few lines of dialog and dialog choices and that’s pretty much it. So even though you begin to care about some of your survivors and your base there really isn’t any way to satisfyingly interact with your base or fellow survivors.In closing what you have here is a very solid good time playing in a zombie apocalypse.  It isn’t very deep but it is still very satisfying and it will eat up a big chunk of your time as you get into that, "well let me just see what happens tomorrow" (or the just one more turn) mindsetOverall I’d rate it a solid 7.5 out of 10, it loses points because its combat is somewhat primitive and the stories inside your home community are a little shallow. This game is well worth the cost and well worth your time if you are at all interested it this genre, in other words, BUY IT! PLAY IT! I doubt you’ll regret it!

content:
r 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Great game, Easy to get into, hard to master. Still some rough patches as it being Early Access, such as uncompleted locations, and certain bugs BUT this game has been updated more than regularly since I've purchased it. Unlike most games THE DEVS ACTUALLY LISTEN IN THE FORUMS!!!!!!!!People post about a certain bug, or certain things they'd like in-game (IE: ability to unload guns and stack ammo). Fun Turn-based strategy concept of the zombie apocalypse genre. If you are a Turn-based strategy junkie this game is a no brainer for you to pick up. Those of you that want that COD: Nazi Zombie ....thing....lol well this game won't be your cup of tea.

content:
er 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I personally think this is a gem in it's genre. If you never played a turn based tactical rpg before, just try it. What is there to lose? If you already did, great!When it comes to turn based tactical rpg's, I have played a lot of them. We all agree we loved Jagged alliance 2, but all others have been received with mixed feelings. Not many of them could break out of the standard formula of a squad of six, besides silent storm, the setting was always more or less the same.This game doesn't feel like jagged alliance at all and that makes it so great! The setting is very, very well chosen. In a post apocalyptic world money becomes unimportant, so you have to start building yourself. The combat system is primitive, but handles very nicely.Also, living people and zombies live side by side. Every now and then that makes for interesting combat situations. Don't let knocked out foes lie around when zombies still roam the combat area!On top of that, a lot of what you will be doing is managing. Your team will consume food, gasoline, antibiotics and so on. They will not all like eachother and you will sometimes fail.Personally, I think the game has a lot of potential of becoming a new benchmark and making the genre surpass its never found glory. I am pretty happy that I helped the makers a few euro's closer to keeping up the good job.

content:
er 22, 2014
												First of all, I love this game. (8/10)It has right the amount of progress to keep you playing, looting and dealing with moral choices...But it has some major issues too:1) You can stalk up to enemies in realtime and most of the time make the first blow. BUT the pathfinding Ai is really bad for your team (not the selected player that one is good). (especially with 4 ppl in the party) So you end up with one to two ppl next to the enemy and 2 ppl more than one round away.You can't do that in Turn based mode, cause the enemy instantly knows you are sneaking up to them even if they didnt see you comming.2) You can not pause the game to make changes or give orders. That wouldn't be bad, if the turn based mode would not just end after no one is close by. (You see someone is comming, hit Space Key and want to reload before the actual combat begins. Yea.. right.. damn picked the wronge Character, Space again.. realtime continues.. bam they see you.. combat starts... all weapons shot empty -.- )Having a complete Party movement without going to realtime would be great. (or a Pause mode with beeing able to give orders)3) Loads. Having loot that has weight is a nice game mechanic and (Warning potential Spoiler:) later when you get to use a car, you can load stuff into it. All nice, but im missing the possibility to have additional Horses or a Trailer for your car (cause it can only hold 200pnds of loot... even a Fiat 500 can pack more Stuff)And you must unload the car by hand. (every Character has the option to choose the whole inventory and move it to the shelter stash. But the car is no Character so you have to unload the car into your player char inventory and after that you can move it into the stash.4) Sorting of the Task Board.... it just does what it wants, after you have changed one task.Sorty by Job... Change Char XY from No Job to Guard Duty... and complete chaos. (if its a problem with the code.. just don't sort after a change)5) Science Skill... i played now for 30+h and I only got one char in my group with science above 6... but he has NO mechanics skill.. so i can't build armor -.- (because it needs Science to research in the workshop but you need atleast 1 point in Mechanics to unlock the Workshopmenue in wich you can resarch it)If there are coming more Patches and new content, this game will be awsome.Until then its great, and if you see it in a sale.. buy it.(Maybee you noticed, im no native speaker, so please forgive me my mistakes)

content:
er 22, 2014
												The world ended and I got to loot a Twinkie Snack Cake factory.  Best Christmas ever.  10/10 Would apocalypse again.  Some crashing, but generally speaking just hitting quick save before changing zones made it a minor irritation.  Had the same trouble in Fallout back in the day.  It's almost nostalgic crashing, in a way.  Other than that, no major bugs for me to date.  For a more serious review, I give it a solid 7-8/10.  Graphics are reasonable, challenge level is reasonable so far, and the premise and execution are interesting.  No major UI irritations.   Story and character interactions are decent.  All in all it's a phenomenal concept that I can't believe hadn't been done in this form before.  If you like X-Com type turn based combat, it's a great entry in that genre.  If that's not really your bag, it's probably more of the 7/10 I gave it above.  Still well worth playing.

number of helpful: 14 of 30 people (47%) found this review helpful
content:
r 16, 2014
												The game's released. It's been a rocky launch technically.They probably rushed it a bit too fast, but it's pretty solid. If you have the patience to put up with bugs and glitches you will find a good game here. The developer seems intent on stabilizing the game in that regard. It's an interesting mix of survivalist group management and turn based tactical resolution. The combat AI is fairly linear (You aggro zombies and looters and they attack), but that works fine for this genre. My biggest complaint is that gun combat mechanics are VERY weak once you start fighting militia and rogue soldiers. It's the exact same run-n-gun AI from the early game except these guys have assault rifles, body armor, grenades, and a firm desire to expend all that in killing you.  Consider carefully before starting a campaign in Ironman mode.  The game keeps you on rails to start with limited options, but that opens up as you go. For me the game's become more rewarding the longer I've played. I like it a lot.

content:
er 26, 2014
												Despite the lack of polish, glitches, crashes, character clipping, erratic character movement, minimal sound, frustrating dialogue options with seeminlgy no results and constantly moody NPCs, Dead State has really got it's hooks into me. At it's heart, it's a fantastic game idea which I can't put down. Trying to coordinate the daily run(s) to grab supplies and, more than likely, get hurt a lot by both the undead and the living whilst trying to unearth valuable supplies, antibiotics and gas in particular, whilst also ensuring that you've got the right people doing the right jobs to upgrade your base is highly engaging. Finding the two antibiotics that you desperately need on the last looter that you down really gives you that excitement that all good games provide.Is it finished? No, not by a long shot. But can I work with that? Yes. That being said, I also cannot wait for the final, polished version. For someone who has had a 15 year hiatus from old school PC gaming, I was lured back by Wasteland 2 and have been well and truly sucked in since. If the devs can get Dead State up to the same level of quality that the guys behind Wasteland 2 achieved, that would make me a very, very happy man.Double Bear, please keep the work going. You've got the bare bones of a fantastic game. It just needs a really good wax on the top coat.

												Awful. Was suckered into this by almost all positive reviews; seems peculiar that those ones popped up early, and most reviews since have been damning (and rightly so). Would be surprised if those positive ones were legit, based on their claims and timing.-This game has basically non existent sound design. Barely any music to speak of and no voiced characters (which I sometimes see as appropriate, but this game needs anything to liven up the dull repetitive dialog it has).- Combat is supposedly like X Com or similar. But then it decides to have inconsistent rules, unclear directions, and a ridiculous scarcity of options or depth.- It's suggested that the Base building mechanic might function like that in State of Decay. No. The big empty building you're given remains as such.- I will readily accept that games needn't look good. But this one has a complete lack of polish, and plays like it's still an Early Access game. Very disappointing.I can't recommend this mess in any way, and hope other people aren't misled into getting this.

content:
er 25, 2014
												This game should be much more fun than it is. All the pieces are there, but the fun seems just out of reach. Interface awkwardness is one of the biggest hindrances in the game. The story and the feel of the game are great and there is massive potential here, but the devs really need to make a few improvements to make the game more accessable and therefore more fun. I almost didn't want to recommend this, because that's like giving the devs permission to leave this game in what I have to say is an unfinished state, despite the fact that it's been 'released'. I want so much to immerse myself in the game, but frustrating bugs and poorly designed mechanics keep pulling me back out. In short, this game really lacks the refinement needed to call it 'released'. To be clear, I am NOT comparing this to modern AAA titles, in fact I play mostly indie games, but this game still needs some love to be not held back by design issues.You can expect a classic Fallout-esque RPG experience, with sadly few interface improvements over those older generations of games. The biggest dissapointment is that the crafting and base improvement mechanics seem so thus far to be completely on-rails and thus much less engaging or fun than they could be. This style of combat system has also come very far since those days, yet this game encorporates none of those advances.If this was a base 100 rating system and not yes/no, I'd probably give it 72/100.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Before purchasing this game, you have to realise this is an INDIE title made by a small team with a small budget. It cuts some corners, it's not as polished as the bigger titles. Can you live with that? If yes, then it's a little gem of a game.It's a turn-based zombie apocalypse fallout-esque "loot the world" RPG. Like scavenging? Like old-school "dumb slow" zombies? Like exploring stuff and building up your home camp? This is it.At the moment of this writting, be aware that there are still quite a few bugs in the game, but most of them are minor or can be overlooked and the game is still enjoyable. However, the devs have been very visible and present and it's obvious they are working on those right now; expect many patches in the weeks to come.It's not a tactical combat game; the combat is not as integrated as some dedicated game like X-Com. Don't go in expecting a ton of tactical combat options, as almost everything is organic, and battle is closer to chess than an actual firefight. Movement and positioning are as important as the type of equipment you bring to the table, and personally I like it that way; there's no artificial game effects, everything is part of the way you handle your squad. Getting swarmed by zombies? Pull back and use a choke point. Getting mowed down by human enemies with guns? Move behind cover and force them to come into melee range, or pull them into the nearby pack of zombies, etc.The rest of the game contains a lot of dialogue and decision-making. Dealing with your ever-growing pack of survivors keeps you on edge, as you never know what kind of event is going to pop up each day, which keeps the world interesting. Exploring the map and finding a new zone full of goodies to bring back to your base camp is an awesome feeling, like finding a treasure room each time, and random encounters run the gamut from new allies to just a few random zombies to bandit ambushes.The maps were nicely crafted, and have this sense of "events past", you can almost read the story of what transpired at the location you are visiting, with the crashed cars and the blood streaks left by the zombies that must have dragged the screaming occupants out, etc.All in all, a nice game that will only get better as the devs fix the bugs. Its premise is also quite unique, and I'm giving this 100% of my support, as I want more games of this type to exist.

												I picked this game up because it seemed like a decent zombie RPG, which very few seem to exist except for some crap subscription ones. I was pleasantly surprised to find Dead State to have very interesting and varied gameplay. If you like RPGs like fallout, you'll find hours of fun in this game. The graphics are far from amazing, but they're not horrible either for an Indie game. When you play this game do keep in mind this isn't some AAA title from Ubisoft, this is is a game built by people who truly love what they do. I found the price a bit steep, but I believe eventually with more content (multiplayer even?) this game has real potential to be the next Dayz. Overall I'd give this game an 8.5/10, it's far from perfect but pretty damn fun and unique.

number of helpful: 10 of 22 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2014
												Before purchasing this game, you have to realise this is an INDIE title made by a small team with a small budget. It cuts some corners, it's not as polished as the bigger titles. Can you live with that? If yes, then it's a little gem of a game.It's a turn-based zombie apocalypse fallout-esque "loot the world" RPG. Like scavenging? Like old-school "dumb slow" zombies? Like exploring stuff and building up your home camp? This is it.At the moment of this writting, be aware that there are still quite a few bugs in the game, but most of them are minor or can be overlooked and the game is still enjoyable. However, the devs have been very visible and present and it's obvious they are working on those right now; expect many patches in the weeks to come.It's not a tactical combat game; the combat is not as integrated as some dedicated game like X-Com. Don't go in expecting a ton of tactical combat options, as almost everything is organic, and battle is closer to chess than an actual firefight. Movement and positioning are as important as the type of equipment you bring to the table, and personally I like it that way; there's no artificial game effects, everything is part of the way you handle your squad. Getting swarmed by zombies? Pull back and use a choke point. Getting mowed down by human enemies with guns? Move behind cover and force them to come into melee range, or pull them into the nearby pack of zombies, etc.The rest of the game contains a lot of dialogue and decision-making. Dealing with your ever-growing pack of survivors keeps you on edge, as you never know what kind of event is going to pop up each day, which keeps the world interesting. Exploring the map and finding a new zone full of goodies to bring back to your base camp is an awesome feeling, like finding a treasure room each time, and random encounters run the gamut from new allies to just a few random zombies to bandit ambushes.The maps were nicely crafted, and have this sense of "events past", you can almost read the story of what transpired at the location you are visiting, with the crashed cars and the blood streaks left by the zombies that must have dragged the screaming occupants out, etc.All in all, a nice game that will only get better as the devs fix the bugs. Its premise is also quite unique, and I'm giving this 100% of my support, as I want more games of this type to exist.

content:
er 7, 2014
												You've probably played a lot of zombie games over the past few years, the market is flooded with them, but trust me when I say Dead State is worth your time. Taking the idea of old-school turn-based RPGs and giving them an undead twist, DoubleBear has created a game that insanly fun and just the right level of challenging. If you are in any way a fan of either zombies or surivial games, then DS is going to have something to keep you interested. Instead of being rewarded for mowing down hoards of zombies with impossible weapons, you gain your experience by improving your shelter, helping survivors, and picking up whatever small creature-comforts you can while you walk across a large and dangerous landscape looking for food, weapons, and any friendly faces you can come across.Dead State is by no means a perfect game, but it's one that I find myself coming back to quite a lot. Even now, bugs are being fixed, features are being added, and everything about the game is improving. I can not urge you enough to give this game a try, even if your taste in zombie games has gone a bit stale.

content:
er 9, 2014
												I rarely bother to write reviews, even for games that I enjoy, so understand that for me to bother putting pen to paper (so to speak) means that I am blown away. Dead State is an incredible RPG; it's everything that I want and look for in a roleplaying game. This indie title blows contemporary AAA RPGs out of the water. The turn-based combat offers lots of options and tactics. The map roaming with spontaneous Point of Interest discovery harkens back to Fallout 1 & 2. The decibel system, which shows you how much noise you're making, encourages you to be creative instead of running in to every fight with guns blazing; the last thing you want is to attract more zombies. The stronghold improvements that you can make, and managing the morale of the people you lead, makes this game about more than just killing. Take a hike, Bioware. DoubleBear just showed you who's the RPG master.
