content:
ry 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I backed this on Kickstarter.  The idea of a turn based ZRPG with survival and base building and management elements really intrigued me!  Think UFO: Enemy Unknown with zombies!Please be aware - you are NOT buying a demo!  This EA release was a promise by Doublebear to it's backers that an early access demo\beta would be released.  I guess that it makes  business sense to put it up for preorder at the same time!   Please ignore the stupid "devs cashing in" comments on the Steam forums - IMO, they are most certainly not!  The project lead (Brian Mitsoda) has a long history in game development (my favourite being Vampire: Bloodlines).  My impression of these guys?  They're in it for the love of making the game, not to rip their customers off!  Please note - I'm definitely not a fanboy!There are some issues with this build.  Combat is grid based, and sometimes (more often that not, let's be honest), it's impossible to attack a mob on a diagonal.  Also, due to the early nature of the build, most of the base building features have been disabled.  There are also some enhancements that should be implemented (e.g. being able to put your party into "overwatch" mode, and and the ability to look through windows!).All that aside though, would I recommend this game?  Yes!   Even this early build shows a lot of promise.  But if you're the impatient sort, then I'd suggest waiting a while until the game's been cooked a bit longer.  You could probably derive a few hours play out of the current build, but it'll leave you wanting more!  However, if you're a fan of the obscure genre of turn based combat, then what are you waiting for?

Graphics are not bad for an indie game.3. I like the way survival is managed. You need to keep scavenging, manage morale, etc. I find this original.Overall... I still can't recommend this at full price. I would say this is a good $15-20 game. Not $29.99! I am sure the bugs will get fixed, but there are major flaws in gameplay.

content:
ber 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I admit to being a sucker for almost any game with zombies in it, and not all of them are great. But this title has a lot of originality and potential. The foremost I'd like to point out is the leveling system. The food and resources you bring into your shelter count as experience gained. So leveling is dependant on your ability to obtain what the shelter needs to survive instead of just grinding XP on zombies and looters which is very refreshing after years of playing rpg's. The characters you can interact with feel alive and well written. Which makes me excited for when we start to see more dialogue interaction added to the game.I preordered this game well over a year ago, and while this game has taken a long time to get to beta; In my own opinion it was well worth the wait. Not all of the shelter upgrades work yet, and I've only run into one bug that has caused trouble during gameplay which is when the camera gets stuck outside of the border of an area. The game seems to run remarkably stable, as I've had only one crash after 14 hours of play. My only real gripe isn't a bug, but a current feature in the game. If you don't return to the shelter before midnight, the survivors will supposedly give up on you and it's an instant game over. This doesn't feel very realistic, and should be changed.That said, this game is hardly feature complete. This is an early beta so if you buy, that's what you should expect. I have had a blast playing so far. I like the combat; I like the leveling system, and the writing is good in my own opinion. I expect a lot from this game in the future, and I'll keep on playing it as updates come out.

content:
r 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Warning: At the moment of this review the game is still in beta, we are aware that several features may be missing/broken/incomplete and will not take this into consideration for the current review. It may be updated once a full release is made. Dead State ... Me... And then there is you, reading and asking yourself : Should I purchase this or not? Let me start with the facts: Dead State is a survival RPG where civilization has collapsed due to a pendemic turning people into zombies. There are still other humans out there but most of them are hostile. If you don't like zombies, survival and exploration then this game ain't for you. For those still with us and asking what's the game?, let's elaborate with the following key points : -The game is set in 3rd person and most if not all actions are issued with the mouse. So no random shooting, gun blazing, taking shots -NO- -But there is combat of course. Combat is turn based and relies on characters stats as well as probabilities (luck). -RPG elements are not classic : You won't get points for how many you slaughter but for the objectives you accomplish. Therefore you shall focus on survival objectives rather than bloodbath. -Combats are not meant for lenghty bloodbath and encounters for several reason 1. The noise meter limits greatly the use of firearm, to the point where it becomes a last resort kind of option 2. Injuries are common and healing will take valuable equipment and action points (AP) 3. You will rarely encounter a horde or group unless you bust the noise meter (hitting 200 will spawn zombie in the sector) 4. Combats are not exactly thrilling and are often not at your advantage. For all those reasons it is best to avoid combat. -The map is divided in sectors. To leave a sector you must access the entry points (usualy on the corners of the sector). Once you do that you can select the travel option and open the large map where you can travel to various areas, idly wonder randomly or go back to your shelter (a public high school ... ugh school of all the places in an apocalypse really?). -Speaking of the shelter it is a microsociety with a struggle for power, where everyone has needs and where you can eventually assign tasks to members. Shall they join you on the field or repair something or clean around etc... You will have to set a daily objective. This society has needs as mentionned, the first one being food. You will often find yourself packing every piece of food you will find on your trip. You also want luxury items to bring up morale. Finding building material is also a priority since there are many things to build and repair.  Other loots include weapons, ammos, protection, fuel, tools and medical gear. Quick mention to antibiotic : A member of the group who becomes plagued with zombie infection cannot be cured with antibiotic, he can be preserved as human. Therefore each contaminated member will consume 1 antibiotic a day. Since antibiotic are rare, you might have to end up asking some of them to leave. Ugh sad. -Last word about the shelter: You won't have much to decide about the building location or else. It is that building, end of the topic. -Save often is a precious advice. Loots can be somewhat random but opponents too. Running into a troop of bikers armed to the teeth will often lead to all of your characters death and if you main character (you) die, it's game over. It's time for What's the Game pro's and con's Pro's : -Rich variety of weapons and gears-Decisions have an impact-Real feeling of crisis and survival-Good ambiance-Open-world style game with good replayability-Interesting concept-Loots don't respawn, feeling realisticCon's : -Combat system can be frustrating and dull -Graphics could be re-worked (Feels like 2001 graphics) -Limited party size (4 members) -No real sneaking/crawling/stealth modeOur final verdict: Is it worth buying ? Wait for the full version unless you get it from a bundle (Humble bundle or else). For those of you willing to put the cash in, it's a good game that will cost you a movie ticket but offer you many many more hours of fun. Decent game but not a hit.

Early Access Review
								This game is very much still in early access. They released the game far too early in order to grab a slice of the Christmas sales.The game is playable in it's current state, but it still feels a lot like playing a beta. Lots of graphical glitches, lots of UI anomolies (even during character creation), maps that involve stairs are still very buggy.The game itself sees you as a survivor joining a survivors commune and attempting to...well...survive. You can upgrade various rooms in your base to provide medical facilities etc, but they haven't bothered to create a seperate graphic for the room before and after the facilities creation. So on day one the base looks exactly the same as it will once you've fully upgraded it.The game is limited in that there are a finite number of areas, and once you've fully looted an area there is no reason to go back to it. Zombies don't respawn and while there are some random encounters they are still very buggy, areas are reused and once you've visited one area type and looted it, any subsequent encounters that use that area type spawn fully looted so are pointless (you get no "XP" for kills).I've played through this game 4 times now, and have always hit a game breaking bug and stopped. Why do I recommend this game then? I'm still holding on to hope that they keep working on it and get it properly release ready, it has a lot of potential.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game gets better and better with every update. It can be tough and stressful. Requires patience and strategizing. There are a few features that can be annoying but only really add to the strategy, such as the movement squares in confined spaces. Be prepared to have your allies in the right position or lose them. Quicksave will be your best friend. It would be nice if they added another few or even another 7 days to the early access, but it's good to play through here and there to see what's changed with the updates. Will take about 4-5 hours to beat in its current state (doing everything right) but it used to take a bit more as some areas have been consolidated and / or removed. There are now customizable characters and random encounters that can vary the game time depending on how you roll your character. You'll probably wanna play through again just to perfect your interactions with characters to reach that kind of game time.Some of what I've said will only be relevant for now, the next update could change a few more things, but the core of the game is damn solid and I can't wait until it's finished.

content:
er 14, 2014
												Dead State seems to be an unfinished product. I really started out _wanting_ to like this game; feeling the need to play a good RTS game for quite some time and was left disappointed.The Interface is, on its surface, intuitive-looking but is in reality quite difficult to use. As an example, when your main character is fatigued, it is not recommended they be used for 12 hours due to a 25% penalty to dodge and accuracy. There is no way for you to use a different survivor to go on a mission for supplies, etc. The game's "passing time" (fast-forwarding time whilst in the shelter) doesn't seem to affect this. Combat is awkward, clumsy and frustrating. Reloading takes too many action points on the occasion where you're desperate enough to use a gun and as for melee combat: good luck. 80% of the time your character fails to connect with your victim leaving you swinging wildly at your attacker/victim and burning up precious action points which could have been spent healing yourself/party member if you're lucky enough to find bandages. On the opposite end of combat, your attacker/victim is almost guaranteed to hit you. You'll spend much of your time on a losing battle regardless of what weapon you're carrying. I do like the fact the melee weapons need to be at an adjacent square in order to attack but getting within range early on is difficult due to no armour, limited action points for attacking and not really having faith your attack effort will pay out at all. I once was in a combat situation where I was attacking 3 or 4 times a turn and ended up missing 100% of the time for *5 turns!* Needless to say I loaded from an earlier save and avoided the area all together.Party member's stand idly whilst attackers approach you without so much as mentioning you're about to be attacked.Random encounters are a literal roll of the dice. You might find yourself equally matched (yet still using the awkward combat system) or completely outnumbered/overpowered and may as well load from an earlier save. I've gotten into the habit of saving just prior to venturing out into the world due to the complete randomness of the encounters.The games manual touts not being able to gain experience by simply killing zombies or using any other skills directly. The way you actually level up your characters is by assigning them tasks on the job board or picking up enough of X item to meet the needs of the various types of goals. While this might seem like a good idea in theory (an interesting way to make the player level up and gain skill) it falls short due to the items being discovered are left to random change when your "zone" seed is generated. This makes gaining skill points feel like a long-dragging chore instead of a rewarding experience. Doubly so if you cannot guarantee your party members are going to be in fighting shape for their randomness that is the combat system.Overall DoubleBear has done a pretty good job but there are some things that indeed need tweaking. The combat system is fun when you're able to actually affect the outcome of the situation but for the time being it seems to be completely random and demoralizing.

content:
2, 2015
												This game could be good or even great, but unfortunately it is overall only meh, and that at most.Small part of  what I have written here: steamcommunity.com/app/239840/discussions/0/35222218616416894/#p42 unfortunally I ran out of charters for this review.Read post for full review & summeryI will tell you why this game get these bad results if it could do so much better.Mostly but not only because it is so bug ridden. It is so buggy that the Iron Man mode seem impossible to me.I have plenty of examples:You leave the map ... crash. You open inventory ... crash. You are going into bed ... crash. Opening trunk? ... crash. Not every time, though. But as longer the game is running as higher the chances are. ... And unfortunately it seems as sooner you are in the game the more often it crashes. It crashed the first time I went to bed, and now I am playing on hours without end.And the bad thing is the game save it options to disk not when they are made or applied but when it is shut down ... means I had to set it up 3 times. (2nd time I should have know better but still didn't know that it crashes that often... so I set it up the 3rd time and shut down the game immediately)The walking sound is also bugged. If too many characters are walking or even less (party of 4 is enough) are running not all step sounds are played back. The playback is interrupted by the next causing something that sounds like  small bird shaking off water after a bath ... it happens so often (every 10 seconds or so) it annoys the **** out of me.Crafting is sometimes buggy ... having all requirements but still not be able to craft items.The very limiting sorting of the inventory sometimes breaks (indicated by having more than one category highlighted) leaving you unable to find stuff in later game. Only restarting the game fixes it.Sometimes some inventory parts using up the same slot or are at least displayed in the same, so that one of them isn't reachable. Mostly involving ammo. Moving stuff around, reloading (I think), or restarting (90% sure since I never had it in a fresh started) the game fixes it.Character animations in shelter are sometimes broken, making the NPC look like he is KO or dying (had even a blood puddle one time) only for it to stand up a few seconds later. In that time you can't talk to it. (Error: Not Reachable) Except if you manage to walk close in the right spot.Some text warns you that enemy can hide behind shelves and stuff.... but trees and buildings do the same ... even if not intended to. Means character (/party) can see it but I can't ... because trees are blocking view anyway ... and sometimes roves are not removed when they should ... so you can't look inside even if you avatar can.[irony]But at least sometimes ... as adjustment ... you can see inside buildings through walls.[/irony]Weapon stacking ... that is totally broken ... some weapon stack, some not at all. Some stack somehow but create new stacks without reasons ...Like the .38 Snubnose revolvers I had ... 1 stack with 2, 1 stack with 3, one stack with 10 ... at same time and all in same storage (shelter storage)Got the survival specialist guy after I was almost done with shelter upgrades. He told be that it was good but would recommend the mushroom farm. Which I had build relative early. ... also direct after building it the crap in the room was gone (beds) but came back sometimes later and till now clipping though the mushroom farm equipment.And from the last kind ... not really game breaking but annoying as heck bugs are a lot more. (edit: while writing this text passages were moved stuff around a lot, and don't remember which bug this was related to ... originally I started at game breaking ones and worked down to annoying).E.g. sometimes you can throw a grenade on a spot where an enemy stands ... but if you need it most you can't .. often if  several zombs occupy same square (which should be impossible anyway). Or only one zomb per square is affected from a grenade. More zombs per square also making aiming at them to matter of patience and constant clicking.Fighting is also buggy. When having enemies in fighting range even though you have attacked them already the game sometimes decides to end the fighting mode. End all effects (from fire grenades or buffs or so) letting become enemies aggro and giving them also 2 extra turns ... just to screw you and your tactics over.That and even more bugs ... there are so many that I start to forget some of them.And there are those questionable game play decisions. Some of them feel like remains of a whole more complex system which was scrapped last minute.There are a few of them that annoy me:
First of all why is this game in FU*KING imperial? Never learned proper units in school?Then there is e.g. the 200 pound limit of the trunk ... ok that much would make sense for horses ... but for a car? ... where is it from? Some east-European communist country ... build in the 80th ... and held together only by duckt-tape?Also some of those object weights making no sense at all... I bet the developer at some point said: "Screw it, deadline is rushing in, we are rolling dice".Map can't be viewed unless you are scavenger team.POI on map can't be marked for further planning.Map filled up already but planned to come back later to one point since it is still full of goodies ... but something more important is to be done before? ... Fat chance .. or more like no chance ... especially if you have to put the game away for some time ... you probably won't remember.No F*CKING sorting for the inventories. (aside from categories, which aren't even working fully, or even available [see trunk]) If the shelter storage fills up looking for something becomes a nightmare.Not sure if bad game play decision or a bug: Some medical equipment isn't showing up in the Medical tab.To name them: All drugs: as ...FlashbackSoothinumAdrenaline ShotStuporaxI might have forgotten someor Medical SatchelThe game does not often communicate clearly ... some decisions are pure guesswork.For dialogs you might argue that in RL you would also not have those hints I am asking for, but I say you would have others like facial expression and the way people talk ... e.g. you can say the same sentence but the way you say it can make your opponent know that it  meant serious, or as joke, or you annoyed as ****. And in RL you would have a lot more interaction and therefore know those ppl a whole lot better.Game also failed to tell me if I need to equip every NPC in my group or if I just can trash the stuff.Also after building the correlated rooms. Do I still the the parts? In meanwhile I also got my hands on spare parts of those ... Do they do something? (e.g. 5 dumbbells)Tasks... duration as well as requirements seem complete arbitrary .. you also can't look what a character could do without interrupting his work. Only way to make this save is at 8:00 AM.Warning that a bonus is not given is showing up when reassigning tasks at 8:00 AM ... when it shouldn't.I understand how the noise system works in this game, but calling it dB is driving me nuts.PLEASE DEVELOPER: If you have not clue at least take a short look into wikipedia. The dB unit has a logarithmic scale. Means 20 dB is not twice but ten times as loud as 10 dB, and 30 dB is hundred times as loud.Doubtful decision to make people run around the whole time ... probably to make it more "lively".IF YOU WANT FU*KING TALK TO ONE PERSON ... WHICH IS NOT EVEN POSSIBLE FROM THE GOALS SCREEN .... YOU HAVE TO RUN AROUND FOR HOURS TILL YOU FINALLY FIND THEM.If I could I would knife everyone and put them into the infirmary ... just because then I know where they are.

content:
9, 2014
												Updated 1/24/2015:TL;DR: Dead State remains quite combat focused, and while there is a lot of interaction to be had much of it may not be seen in a single play through the game. For a strategy RPG created on such a limited budget by a small team I consider it to be an entertaining experience that was well worth my time and money, and look forward to seeing what Doublebear does in the future.Dead State remains an entertaining experience, but although it is released it still has some balance issues. Late game there is practically no reason to use the apocalypse armor over the Advanced Tactical Vest, which is a required component of the apocalypse armor. Combat can be rather enjoyable, but for experienced players it may be too easy. That being said, I've seen numerous complaints on the forums that it was too difficult, so I suppose they've struck a reasonable balance. I'm looking forward to the release of Iron Man modes, and although the game has passed the 1.0 mark Doublebear continues to flesh out the experience and address issues in the game itself.If you're new to the strategy RPG genre and are looking for an experience that can be completed without a lot of combat this is probably not that title. Conversely, if you're adept at playing Strategy RPGs and want consistent end game challenges, this is also not that title. Doublebear has managed to create a fairly engaging game that revolves around both combat and crisis events and ally management. Unfortunately for the experienced player, they may never lose any ally and therefore won't have a problem getting so much morale that they never experience the darker aspects of the title. Meanwhile those who aren't able to manage the combat portion of the game may well lose so many allies that they have a hard time keeping allies.I enjoy Brian Mitsoda's writing style, and overall I found Dead State to be a very entertaining experience. That being saidDead State is shaping up to be a really enjoyable zombie survival RPG, and while it has tactical combat, the primary emphasis is going to be on the survivors and their personalities. Making sure that everyone has some semblance of normalcy in their otherwise upended lives and navigating the perils of the post-disaster world will eventually entail a lot of the experience. As the game stands, a lot of it is about the combat. It makes sense that they would want to expose the most replayable aspect of the game and get users opinions on it, and while it does strongly resemble the Age of Decadence on which the game has been built AoD has varied enough options for tactical combat that Dead State has a solid foundation on which to build in that regard.As of right now (6/29/2014), the first seven days is all that is open to players for exploration and testing, but in the not so distant future plans are to open up more content for eager fans who want more. While I have only played through the first seven days twice I am likely to wait on that update before I dive back into Dead State. While the combat and potential choices in the first seven days is appealing, I'm rather more interested in how the game unfolds with regards to various factions and additional allies. At the end of the day, the first seven days is a fun tactical experience released to acquire feedback on aspects of the game that are still able to be changed. The game will revolve largely around the shelter and keeping your survivors from killing one another or hating your leadership enough to fracture your group into factions that each pursue their own agendas.If everything unfolds in the direction it seems to be heading, you could potentially apply a variety of the shelter aspects to another type of disaster and the transition from zombie apocalypse to plague or famine or the destabilization of the magnetic poles and ensuing havoc EM radiation would have on unshielded electronics and minus the scavanging expeditions where you had to bludgeon people to death with a baseball bat things could feasibly progress in a similar fashion.

content:
ry 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very enjoyable, considering the game is currently in early access, looking forward to the full release!  I finished this 7-day version of the game in about 7 hours, but I haven't explored a couple of locations yet, so I guess it could take somewhere around 10 hours to complete this if you do everything. People claiming to have finished it in 40 minutes are either lying, or just rested or rushed through content every day without exploring anything. A single combat can last for 10 minutes or more.The game is not finished yet, being early access, and it does have some bugs. I had about 5-6 crashes, and got stuck in combat once. It also lacks a lot of functions, that will be implemented later, like character creation.The game puts you in a situation, where you, after surviving a plane-crash, becomes the leader of a small group of people, trying to survive during a zombie-apocalypse. You have a homebase that can be upgraded (but a lot of this is not available yet, I could only fix the fence and the well in this version of the game), and in order to get building materials, food, weapons, and other stuff essential for survival, you have to explore locations like a shopping mall, a church, a camping site and other places in your surroundings.There's a lot of tension when exploring, death can be waiting around every corner, in the form of zombies, or armed and hostile looters. A careful approach is required, sneaking up on zombies, taking them out one by one, or avoiding them. It's also important to be quiet, guns are very effective, but the sound will attract more undead.There are interesting things to discover (when exploring), and the world doesn't feel copy-pasted. Maybe you encounter a man who has barricaded himself inside his house, writing warnings "trespassers will get shot" on the wall, or maybe in a bathroom, you find a woman who's commided siucide. Little things perhaps, but it makes exploration much more rewarding.  Combat is turnbased and works well, it's challenging, and your decisions is usually what determines how well you perform, not blind luck. Most weapons have different types of attacks, and can cause status effects like bleeding or dizzyness. If someone dies they stay dead (or gets up as a zombie if bitten), this is not the kind of game where everyone gets up after every battle and regenerates their health instantly.In your homebase, you can assign different jobs for the other people in your group (like repairing something, or making molotov coctails).You can also have dialogues with them, and depending on how you treat them (will you be kind, threatening, or sarcastic for example) you will build different relationships with them, that will have consequences later on, according to the developers. How well this will work is impossible to tell from the EA-version though. Writing is good for the most part, except a few awkward lines here and there.There isn't much handholding in this game, I personally like this, but some people will no doubt get frustrated, you do however get some directions, about where to go and what to do, when you talk to the other survivors.   I also strongly recommend everyone to read the manual before playing (there is a link to it on the Steam-forums),this way, a lot of frustration will be avoided. It's often difficult to figure out how to do stuff (like trading items between characters, or leaving a location) due to lack of tooltips, and a UI where some information can be difficult to spot, like when the travel button lights up.The visuals are good enough for me, but, of course, can't compete with AAA-titles. Animations and character models are not very good, but environments looks better. Music is great however, and enhances the mood of the game. I really liked this early version of the game, it does have the potential to become a great survival-rpg, if the full release lives up to this remains to be seen, but so far so good. Recommended to people who likes challenging old-school rpgs, where a careful and tactical approach is required, not recommended to people who require non-stop action, AAA-graphics, and quest-arrows.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game impresses me more and more each time I play it, with the amount of content and play through that is avaiable. With the final release set for next month if you are thinking about buying it I would definitely get it come release.This game sat on my wishlist for 3 months before I brought it because I was unsure about spending $30 on an early access game. When I finally brought it I did not regret it in the slightest and think it is well worth the $30.There are so many aspects to the game, you have your main character with abilites and stats management and then the array of weapons you can use and the different attacks available for each weapon. then you can have specaility items, armour and your inventory management. This also crosses over into your party, managaing 3 more characters weapons, armour and inventory.Travelling round the map you have a wide range of locations to visit, with different layouts and a wide variety of loot to find. Intially i was not sure if i would like the turn based combat but quickly found this to not be an issue. You not only have to fight zombies, but wild dogs, and enemy npcs each brining there own separate style of combat. You also have travel options on the map running, horse riding and driving a car.Base management is a whole differnt aspect in itself, building upgrades, assigning jobs, managinging moods keep you occupied while you are not out smashing heads!This game combines all my favourite aspects of zombie/survival games and has so far provided me with hours of entertainment and I look forward to a whole lot more. (ps my steam hours do not cover my complete hours on this game).

content:
er 30, 2015
												Short Version: 3/5.  Turn based version of "State of Decay".Long version: This game is good, but not great.  If you haven't played State of Decay, get that instead. If you've played SOD into the floor  (I've played 1000+ hours on it) and want something in the same wheel house, then the turned based combat aspect of this game can be a nice change of pace.  The combat system feels more like old-school AD&D games, like think back to 90's RPG games where you take a group of adventurers out - that's not bad, it's just kind of dated - and where SOD makes you feel on the edge of your seat at high levels, this just kind of annoys you if you start losing (which won't be often if you take out a healer and make your character a melee warrior). Still, I enjoyed it and considering the amount of truely terrible zombie games there are out there, this stands above a lot of the trash on Steam.

content:
0, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game. I've actually had in since it was in Alpha and just a one week demo. It's gotten considerably more content from then, but not much real polish. I like the idea of this game, but the execution of the design is rather clunky. First off, as people mentioned before, the interface leaves much to be desired. It's quite easy in the heat of combat to try to click on the HUD and accidentally move that character too far away to do anything useful in a single click. You are able to walk over dead bodies, but you're going to have a real hard time finding a spot that doesn't highlight the body to loot rather than the space below it to move on. Rotating the camera is necessary a lot of the time, especially when searching for hot spots where you can loot items, but a lot of the time it's in vain actually because there are usually very few places you can loot things from, although you do need to scour the whole map to find them. The turn-based/real time aspect is kind of weird in cases like where you're trying to break down a locked door. It goes into turn based for a second, makes noise, and the zombies in the area come to your location rather quickly. Like I appreciate trying to jump into combat faster but zombies aren't THAT quick. Another aspect that leaves much to be desired is the real time movement before combat. You can have up to 4 members of your team and they don't run that close together, they run sort of in a staggered formation that when you go into combat mode there's 1 person in the front that can attack and the rest are usually too far to do anything the first turn.

content:
6, 2016
												Enjoyed this game. If you like Squad-focused turn-based combat in your games (like Xcom or more similarly Silent Storm) this will fit the bill. It also does a pretty fine job of delivering on what so many zombie games fail to -- a convincing simulation of what running a post-zombie apocalypse might be like. Crisis events, managing jobs/morale/resources and really getting to know your survivors, their skills, and how best to use the people you come across. The cons? I wish inventory management was more streamlined -- opaque at first it is easy enough to pick up, but there is still an issue of needing to move hundreds of pounds of stuff around -- (I appreciate how much a person can carry is an important element of a game where deciding what to loot and what to leave behind is key, but after you get a CAR the idea of repeat trips for piles of items just seemed silly.) -- There were a couple of bugs, but nothing I couldn't navigate by using the forums. Solid title that is a bid of a tarnished gem -- while it's a GREAT game, it falls in a couple of ways just short of being an AWESOME game. Still, for an Indie game it cannot be denied the game deserves MASSIVE praise. I especially liked how truly diversity and differences were made a part of this game regarding how survivors interacted -- Not just the obvious questions of sanity or racism in an apocalypse scenario -- but ideas of Sexuality, Mental and physical disabilities, religion, criminal tendencies, classism, language barriers -- by the end of the game I felt like practically any quirk I could think of was somehow represented, which was also a nice touch. Glad I played,

number of helpful: 23 of 49 people (47%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 17, 2014
												Anyone who read my previous review of this will notice that I have changed my opinion. This is simply because the last post full release patch has fixed many issues and the developers continue to improve this product (the next big patch is due mid-late January). In my opinion it should have stayed Early Access until this latest patch.This is a deep game that rewards patience in the early stages. You start out with just a handful of allies and very few options but as you venture further from your base, discover more locations, and find more survivors (who come with their own individual traits and problems) then things begin to get interesting. You can develop your base far more quickly and new options for addittional facilities start to appear as new survivors bring their unique skills to the table. Plot events progress in a similar manner with most being specifically linked to certain characters and your enjoyment of Dead State will snowball as you gain momentum.Dead State is not an easy game to quantify in terms of genre; being a combination of man-management and resource allocation, Sims-like character appeasement, building development, open world exploration, and story-driven role play elements. But the CORE of the game is none of these things but rather an XCOM-like, turn based, tactical combat. And this last, despite being highly enjoyable when taken in context with everything else, still has a few rough edges. Regardless of its flaws (which are becoming increasingly less significant as the developers continue to listen to the community and improve the game) Dead State has finally flowered into something unique and satisfying IF you can push through its slow start. With the promise of further improvement in both game mechanics and extra content it has been turned from something best waited on to something you shouldn't really be without.Previous score 67%, current score 82%, expected to finish in the high 90's.

number of helpful: 87 of 180 people (48%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Game delivers exactly what it promised: Team-based, 3/4 tactical zombie survival / base management in open world environment. There's a lot to sink your teeth into with this one. Basically you lead this bunch of survivors and every morning you get a quick briefing of things / place to explore before setting them to work and you and your scavenging party set out to find some resources to survive another day.Throughout your travels you'll come across other survivors, some good, some not so much. But its you against the zeds so every live body helps. There's lots to explore and different modes of travel, and the shelter will requires lots of upgrades to turn it into a haven amongst all the chaos around you. There are items you need to collect to improve survivor's morale throughout your travels, in turn they will give you advice and mark locations on your map for you to explore. The overland map presents lots of random encounters during your travels, some good, some bad.The shelter is what it's all about. You are constantly struggling with the other survivors to turn this little elementary school into a bonafide ZA haven. And it has all the ability to do it, with 2 floors and multiple rooms you will have everything you and your survivors will need to survive the nights of Splendid if you plan accordingly.Combat starts off appearing simple but as you get more followers and more weapons you can then start to have very tactical battles, with different status effects and AOE biological weapons to help keep the battle in your favor, making impossible-looking battles into 3-round wipe ups if you're careful. Both ranged and melee are viable (I stick to melee, this is a ZA)The maps run from classic overrun parks and hospitals, to dark scenes of lost hope, to some really...unique scenarios that I wouldnt have expected. Games like these are what makes all the risk of joining an EA worthwhile. Would highly recommend.

content:
er 6, 2014
												This is a great turn based strategy game set during a zombie apocalypse. It plays very much like fallout 1 / 2 with an added twist of also developing a base filled with NPC characters. While the zombie plague leaves your members forced to scramble for supplies you will encounter human adversaries who are often much more dangerous foes.The game also uses an interesting sound mechanic where to much noise can attract attention of zombies or looters. Break down a door with a sledge hammer and you can bring down a wailing horde of zombies... or a looter double barrel.The game has been polished up nicely since early access. You may still get a bug here and there or a crash... but my experience has been very good.I am happy to say I kickstarted this project and the game came out great. If you are a fan of old school turned based games and into CRPG this game is great. A refreshing setting for an RPG while also having great strategy and downtime while in your base. Easy 9/10 from me.

The reason i cant recommend the game is because ead state feels unfinished, and seems to follow the same path as alot of other unfinished and rushed games lately. For example alot of characters will ask you to do certain tasks, when you do so though they wont acknowledge that theyve been completed.  At times this caused a drop in relationships for some characters such as Vic or Paul.  *SPOILER ALERT*    What broke the camels back for me was that  There is a character that you can rescue who has the possibility to produce a cure, now in a open world zombie game where alot of stories can be done or ignored, producing a cure is the closest thing as you can get to an end game for the most part and having such a major story aspect of the game broken when it is supposedly finished is unacceptable  *SPOILER ALERT END* .  Overall teh game functions solidly , barring the bugs, but it feels like a betrayal of trust when the developers tout the game as complete when it is only partially so.  Edit 1: Flag was removed but the rest of the review still standsEdit 2: I just want to add in that , most major story scripts are bugged.  An event will happen that should , say make an area destroyed, but if you go to this area everything and everyone there is the same.  This effectively destroys the end game, I spent about 30 in-game days just skipping doing anything waiting for story elemnts to occur on and off.  STAY AWAY from this game till the price drops, or the Devs own up and properly take care of things that should have been done when it was declared "FINISHED".

content:
er 27, 2014
												When i first started playing this game I was caught hook line and sinker. I love the 3 genre it combines (zombie survival, classic rpg and non-linear) and thought that this was going to be one of my favorite games. However as you progress through the game you quickly realize how many flaws there are not only in coding, but also game mechanics. As for positives about the game...really nothing. The only reason why I was able to tolerate it for 20 hours is like I said, I am a sucker for the genre but as for the game in and of itself there is nothing that it brings to the table that can't be fulfilled from dozens of other games without all the bugs and hassle. Cons-Player Character has 1 line of backstory...don't get me wrong, I love customization, but backstory for the main character is vital in an RPG. The only succesfull rpg series I can think of with limited backstory is the elder scrolls series, but those games use the prologue to shape the character's development. This game on the other hand has one of the most limited and useless prologues I have ever played.The most repetitive turn based combat I have ever seen. All of the zombies are the same, the human npc have terrible AI with nothing intruiging about their movements, and the biggest baddest npcs in the game are a joke since they have such high armor class, if the player goes into a fight in the same armor its practically just flailing at each other for a few turns doing nothing strategic...sort of like a failed rpg hack and slash comboThe game uses a failed view system called "fog of war" which basically means that if you aren't in line of sight of an enemy then you can't see them and they can't see you, but it does not work for this game. In a turn based rpg if you can't find an NPC that you accidently aggroed you might be running around tiles with limited action points just wasting away your life.Horrible shelter morale system- some of the NPC express themselves almost like they are in an emotional polarity shift, they can do stupid things (don't want to give spoiler) even with a large morale rating and everyone being above average moodDroll upgrades- The shelter upgrades barely change the looks of the base at all, aside from this small garden plot on the veranda and a car showing up to put fuel in, everything looks the same from start to finish- some visual recognition of progress would be niceThere is loads more to list like technical glitches, location issues etc but that pretty much sums it up.Rating 3/10Like a lot of other reviewers I would say to wait until it's at least 66% off, since the 30$ price tage is not so steep

content:
er 18, 2014
												Dead State has gone a bit under the radar of most people, and that is a shame, because even though I got wind of it too late to Kickstarter-back it, I bought it the moment it was fully released and I haven't regretted it for one minute, except for the fact that it's eating up virtually all of my free time.Simply put, Dead State is an amazing game. Granted, it's not bug-free (though no real game-breaking bugs so far) and the interface can be a chore (as well as an enigma at times), but once you're used to its quirks, Dead State becomes an incredibly addictive and involving experience.Yes, we're all tired of zombie games, but I will gladly make an exception for Dead State, and I promise, so will you. If I describe it as an interesting cross between Fallout, State of Decay and X-Com: Enemy Unknown, then it should probably be enough to make the hairs of any serious gamer stand on end. And rightly so, because the game pulls off all its aspects perfectly. And it even has a well implemented 'timer' mechanism: you're pressed for time since morale decays and food supplies dwindle daily, but on the other hand, you don't feel like you're being rushed all the time. There's no clock counting down, no constant reminders. You set your own pace, and as long as you don't waste your days doing nothing, you should usually be fine. I scavenged every day, trying to take on at least two locations per run, which is as far as you can stretch your daytime (and your characters' backpacks!), but I am currently sitting on a comfortable stockpile, so there's no need to micromanage and fuss over every single hour of every single day. But you know damn well that you can't sit still either.During your travels, you'll meet other survivors. Some you'll just stumble across, others will even knock on your door of their own accord. While you can turn them away, it's ill-advised to do so. Sure, every survivor you take in means another mouth to feed, but they pay off their food consumption by working for you. You can give them jobs yourself, like putting them in the scavenger party, making them construct shelter upgrades, guard the fence, and all other kinds of work. And as the days go on, the needs of your shelter grow as well, making it critical to recruit every survivor you can find. Every survivor has his or her own backstory, dialogue, demands and specializations, making for a diverse and lifelike feel of the shelter, where you have to assign jobs based on their capabilities.The shelter itself can be upgraded, X-COM: EU style, to provide benefits and make new things possible. You can construct facilities like a workshop, a garage, a rooftop garden and even a chicken coop and a recreation room. All of these upgrades, however, take time and parts, and you'll find yourself strapped for the latter very often, so don't think you'll be able to just build everything from the get-go, it requires careful decision making, especially since unexpected events will also require manpower and parts, so you need to keep some in reserve. This makes for a paced game experience, where you'll constantly have things to strive for, instead of falling into the "build-everything-then-be-stuck-with-idle-workers-and-no-real-goal"-trap many similar games have perished in.The scavenging party, which is always led by your characters, consists of up to four people, and their exploits will be the bulk of the game experience. You lead your team out there, in the lands around the shelter, and collect everything you can, ranging from food over luxury items, to weapons and shelter upgrade parts. Every scavenging run is a shot in the dark, since you'll never know what, or who, you'll come across, and while the zombies are dangerous enough in their own right, human enemies are so much more so. Sometimes you'll have no choice but to pass by a location because you know you're simply not strong enough (yet) to take its residents on. Which of course makes it all the more satisfying when you then come back to give them a good walloping.If you do decide to do battle, you'll do it in classic isometric turn-based style. This gives you more tactical possibilities than you'd expect, since every weapon has its own range, requirements, and statistics. The battle system is most reminiscent of the 'real' Fallout Games (the Interplay ones), except, sadly, no groin shots. In battle, the first and most important decision to make is whether or not to break out the guns. They're powerful, but come with one massive drawback, and I don't mean ammo consumption (although that certainly counts too). Because guns, as you probably know, are loud. And loud things, as you probably know, bring all sorts of nasty things. But whether or not you'll resort to the powder burners, combat means tactical decision making, and some faith in the random number god. Which is exactly how a turn-based RPG battle should go.There are a few minor flaws. It's not an entirely bug-free experience, but most bugs range from aesthetical (sometimes characters moonwalk), to only mildly frustrating (enemies clipping into each other, characters not following the leader correctly). Some are even kinda beneficial (being able to access the car trunk if you haven't brought the car, for instance). I have not encountered any game-breaking or truly frustrating bug yet. The interface can be a bit irritating at first, but once you get the hang of its quirks and unwieldy design, this becomes nothing but a minor inconvenience.All in all, Dead State offers an interesting, involving, and even downright addictive role-playing experience with base-building elements. Like the Civ games make you go "just... one... more... turn!", Dead State will make you go "just... one... more... day!". This game, like Divinity: Original Sin and Shadowrun Returns, is proof that Kickstarter can, and does, produce absolute jewels, and in turn, proof that game makers make the best games when they make what they want to make.Final verdict: if you like Role-Playing Games, Turn-Based Strategy and/or base building, you owe it to yourself to get this game. It's easily one of the best games of the year. Buy it, even if it's not on sale.

content:
er 21, 2014
												This is my second review for Dead State.  My first review was written almost immediately after release and was highly negative.I started playing the day of release, but it still had quite a few issues back then. I'm on my "third" character, but have yet to actually finish the game. I started anew after the recent patch as pretty much all of the ragequit worthy bugs that I had encountered worked themselves out.That being said, I have played many indie titles on steam. This IS A GOOD BUY. My initial opinion was the opposite, but I can't stand by that anymore. The Devs and Mods are a very close knit group and the communication between them as well as the community is amazing. I would not be surprised one bit if they continue adding content over time, which seems pretty common with indie crews that create a game out of PASSION like they did, and not out of a pricepoint.Lot's of peoples main question regarding a SP only game is the replay value and length of the game, I will give you my thoughts on that first.REPLAYAs it stands right now the game is definitely fun for at least one playthrough, and it is a LONG playthrough. There are lots of places to explore and cool things to see, as well as special weapons to hunt down, achievements, special enemies and special recruitable characters as well.  Now I have not reached the end-game.  I have one character around day 55ish right now, another around 45, and my first character is somewhere between 60-70, I believe.  As far as I can tell neither of them are super close to the end of the game.  A lot of it has to do with your playstyle, as well.  I made it a point to maneuver the entire world map on my last character and have found ALL SORTS of stuff I had no idea about, which will elongate my game.  Think Fallout2,  tt could be a 20 hour game, or a 100+ hour game.  While this is not as in depth as Fallout 2, the same principle stands.  IMO, at 30 bucks, even if this game was 30 hours it would be worth it.  A dollar an hour of entertainment?  Ok, deal.This current character is my third to reach roughly day 50 so far.  Even having replayed those fifty days three times now, it was not a complete grind like I thought it would be.  The key to keeping this game interesting for me was varying my character builds.  First character was firearms.  Second, melee.  My current character is a bow character (STR and PER), and is INSANELY fun to play.  Granted, there are those "Oh, great, I have to do THIS part again" feelings, but the majority of those were routed in some bugs from older versions AS WELL as my not fully understanding the game mechanics on previous plays.COMBATCombat is... Well, it is honestly not the best.  It doesn't necessarily detract from your first playthrough, but there are no cover mechanics (xcom) and once you get some decent gear the zombie fights are as tense and nerve wracking as beating up sleeping ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ toddlers with a cricket bat.  But, the devs state several times that zeds are supposed to be easy, and it is the human NPC's that are trouble.AI Much like the original Fallout and Fallout 2, enemies are NOT scaled to your level.  This means if you wander into the wrong spot too early, you are going to have a REAL bad time.  I always enjoyed games that did this, so while I think it's a great perk, some may think it's poor design.Currently, enemies are static unless agro'd by a noise or by seeing you, though I think I saw a dev or mod say they were working on a patrolling AI?  Once again, does not impact your first playthrough much/at all.WEAPONS/ARMORThere is a decent selection of armor available in the game, which all have their pro's and con's and will make the critical gamer think hard.  "Do I want to sacrifice an AP for more defense, or would I rather give myself an extra chance to hit?"  Helmets with visors and masks will affect that characters visual range, which I thought was a very nice touch.  Higher grade armors CAN be hard to find, there may come a point when you think the entire selection is leather jackets and tactical vests.  Not true!The weapons are equally varied, and also have the added spice of unique named weapons.  These are the money makers.  Increased crits, THC, damage, custom look and names, and they usually come with a little backstory.  VERY fun once you get some of them!You also have the ability to create minor upgrades for some of your firearms and armor through the use of a player built workshop.STORYLINESome of it is event driven, some of it is time driven.  It moves along at a fair pace, not so fast that you don't have time to explore the map, and not so slow that you get bored (generally, there are a couple times where I thought my game was bugged because nothing was advancing, then the next day... it did.)You also learn more about the survivors you recruit.  Nearly every one will come to at some point asking you to perform X task for Y reason.  Some are time sensitive, others are not.  They usually ALL give you a little glimpse into their backstory, however.This game puts almost more stress on the aspect of MANAGING a post apocalyptic shelter than it does fighting zombies.  You will get crisis events and your "sub-leaders" (key NPC's in your shelter) will voice their opinions.  I have yet to see one where an answer you give will make EVERYONE happy.  Some of them require you to put a little thought in and weigh risk vs reward, i.e should I spend these supplies to prevent something that MIGHT NOT happen, just to be safe?  Or should they be put to use on a more immediate issue elsewhere?Additionally, certain NPC's react differently to different conversations.  If you have a raging hard ♥♥♥ with a meanstreak that lived a rough life, are you going to coddle them and bend to their whim, or draw a hard line to make them respect your role?There is not a lot of written/spoken backstory for the majority of locations, however I have not come across a single map that didn't leave something to the imagination (assuming someone has one :p ).I would recommend my friends buy this game at full price. The fact that it is on sale would make me buy it for them if they were still on the fence.You can go ahead and look at my previous posts, when I first got here I was HIGHLY critical of the game on release. I have done a complete 180. This group of devs got me, and they got me ♥♥♥♥ing good.

												Very bad game.  Bad controls, cliche characters, repetative and way too much done to add difficulty just to drag the game out.  You need fencing, but you can't salvage the miles and miles of fencing you will see in the cut-and-paste locations you visit.  Need parts to fix a car? Zero chance the missing parts are salvageable from the dozens of cars you will pass.   A book store had three books and two magazines, just to keep resorces scarce, and a town only had two stores in it?  Zombies are attracted to noise, sure, but clearing an area first before you make the noise should mean it's safe.  Instead, zombies appear out of thin air in a town with a population density of 10 people per square mile.  Lazy and cliche game design all the way around coupled with a crappy combat system.

content:
er 7, 2014
												I can definitely see where the positive reviews come from and the brief amount of negetive reviews appear.Dead state looked very very promising when I started playing it. I had various bugs and crashes occur which I thought: "ok this is probably just because this is a game in progress. Then I realize its a fully released game and I start to hope the devs fix the problems. I notice I continually have updates for this game which encourages me to continue playing the game. Overall however I've slowly felt like I'm beating a dead zombie with this game. So here's how the story goes.1st Game Play: Awesome. Loving it. Seems like this is going to occupy a good week to 2 weeks of my time and probably have good replay value. Get somewhat far into the game and it crashes... continuously.2nd Game Play: After an update I load up the game only to find that my previous saved game has been completely corrupted and thought: "oh well, Ill just start over. Its got the official release. Maybe there is a bunch of different additions to the game. NO. NO THERE ISN'T. But I digress.3rd Game Play: I know the 2nd game play didn't really end anywhere other than I just stopped playing it for a couple days. But with the 3rd and final game play (atleast until the bugs are fixed) I get further into the game than I've gotten in the prior 2 game plays. Yet now for some reason the travel by horse has become slower than traveling by foot and for some reason when I add NPCs to my "search party" they don't come with. I don't quite know how to fix this bug (if it is a bug) but its annoyed me to point where I just stopped playing and decided I'll wait it out.So to make a long review short. This game needs some real fixin' And until then. I don't really see the point in playing the game unless you're going to be able to enjoy it the full way through. Please please please fix this game up. I really do enjoy it (for the most that I can play) and would like to see the future potential in it.

er 30, 2014
												I would like to warn anyone who is thinking of buying this game - it is definitelly 100% overpriced.Please do not take me wrong. It is a decent game which would definitelly find it's fans. It has a cool system of interpersonal relashionships management, lots of loot to play with, RPG traits and HQ development. But. The graphics are ridiculosly simple. The characters animation robotic. The choice of choosing a static picture to represent your character without any animation is pathetic. I can not care what is goin to happen to this pictuers who are constantly popping out lots of BS. Also, I came to the point when my character's face in all the dialoges was one of a Caucasian guy but there  was a black guy running in the game itself. So incongruent and off-hand the whole approach to the graphics is in this game. Another big thing, the combat system lacks depth, it is all about getting to the correct distance from the zombies to hit them first. From the variety of weapons the actual choise of combat options is limited. Due to the fact that more powerful weapon requires more action points to spend, it seems that all the weapon differes in the name but pretty much the same effectiveness wise. All in all, Dead State is not a bad game. Moreover, it is still in alfa. However, animation wise as well as the character development wise it falls miles and miles  low from even TellTales Walkind dead. Similar to that, combat wise it has nowhere near to stand to brilliant Xcom enemy series. When you start thinking that there are such games on the market like Alien Isolation, new Dragon Age and even Evil Within which you can buy for roughly the same price Dead State seems to be undoubtedly overpriced. Consider yourself warned.

content:
y 19, 2015
												I like tactical RPGs like X-Com, Jagged Alliance, etc.  So I thought I'd like this game, and I did for a while.  Until the complete lack of polish started to get to me.  I don't FEEL like I'm in a zombie apocalypse.  I feel like an errand boy for a bunch of whiners.  Characters in the game are always the same, they always want the same thing (deoderant, coffee, batteries) which raises their mood level (gotta keep morale high).  However since they are unchanging, it feels like I'm constantly grinding to keep their mood high by bribing them with things I find.  For example, the one cop you start with has a gun but he says he's never used it before.  You can ask him for it but he refuses.  You can continue to ask him for it forever and he will always refuse.  I don't understand why these dialogue options exist if they do nothing.  This game is also quite flat and has very little in the way of randomization.  If you restart the game you'll find all the same loot in all the same places.  I do understand that this is an indie developer, however I don't think they should've undertaken such an ambitious project.I payed full price for this game, but after playing it, I'd say I'd pay about 10$ for it.

content:
y 29, 2015
												Beware of SpoilersI helped fund Dead State through Kickstarter and genuinely wanted to like the game but in the end I have to give it a thumbs down.The combat isn't the worst but I felt it missed some golden opportunities. Specific target locations on enemies' bodies(We are always told to go for the zombie's head, you know...), a better cover system, and overwatch would all have been nice additions.The maps were believable but grew old after a while. Been in one pharmacy, been in them all. There were a few exceptions to this rule but not enough.The crafting system was nicely done, but somewhat hard to gain access to. The science lab in particular required very specific characters or the player aligning his character's skills in a very specific way. I also wanted more items but I understand that may come down the line.Dialogue was spotty in some ways. There is quite a bit of profanity. Some places it is quite believable, like where one character( a D.J.) rants about how depraved mankind has gotten but other places it was overdone. Many of the conversations contained misfires about events that had already occurred. Some of the characters seem more straw than others. I do want to congratulate the writers on the shelter survivor Davis. He was totally believable as a former firefighter injured in the line of duty who won't let a wheelchair slow him down. He was one of my favorites and a an all too rare character with a physical challenge. DoubleBear didn't shy away from emotional or mental challenges either and my hat is off to them for it.I did think the characters were a bit whiny given what all I was bringing in. But hey that might have been just me.The survival aspects were thought out but again I thought more could be done. With so many unburied bodies the diseases that would have been percolating... Zombie bites should not have been the only risk of infection.Don't look for super vivid graphics or ultra cool sound. I personally thought the visuals were okay. Sound... iffy.Again I should stress that this game was made on a Kickstarter budget and had limits but I still feel it could have been so much more.

								Graphically Dead State is on par with the general expectation of a top down turn based game. in it's present release state it should be considered a nothing more than a liner prequel story 7days before the main game play that would come with the main release. Mechanically the game is sound, with exception given to the combat system which has a tendency to lock up the game's global mechanics; this commonly occurs when engaging the Zombies or "those things" as they are commonly referred to within the story line; as the word zombie seems to be taboo with the developers when they were writing the games story line. The use of the word "Demo" within the main menu screen has thus far caused no end of trouble for the developers recently. As this has implied that this present itineration would not be update or replace with a full version upon its release. I would implore the developers clarify in pure and simple terms, what will happen to this release when full version is deployed and to replace the word "demo" in the main menu with "prequel". until the present bugs are fixed and clarification is given in a formal announcement on stream; I cannot in recommend this game to others. despite its obvious potential to be a really decent game.

								Been stalking this game sense before they had a kickstarter and was excited to be able to play some of it. Though I did run out of things to do in the first seven days, the game lived up to everything I have been waiting for. I did however find a handful of bugs that I'm hoping will be resolved by the time the full game is released. Things to notice before purchase:The full game is listed at $30 when released if you know you want it, now is a better time to purchase.Find the manual before running game. It doesn't appear anywhere noticeable after download and is online for anyone curious about how the game runs. I skimmed it at best due to its long length. But might be an insight for someone unsure on this game.This demo only runs the first 7 days with limited things to do. I wouldn't purchase it unless you are sure you want the full version which is still under development. If you can wait for the full version to come out a demo will be free at that time.Be prepared for bugs. Though annoying they didn't manage to ruin my gameplay but could easily become frustrating.Personally I loved being able to control my own group as I loot the surrounding areas for all they're worth and would easily recommend the game to anyone with a love of zombie survival.

content:
ry 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pretty much what it says it is... a demo. Not a whole lot to be done. Will be interesting to see what the final product looks like. As it stands; quite a few freeze-ups/bugs, and fights are so sloooooooooooooooow. (Could really use some faster animations.) Also lacks a few characteristics of favorite RPG's such as character customization/creation and so forth. I'm also hoping it's more open-world than the demo indicates.Edit 6/11: Lot of bugs have been fixed, but still have problems with random crashes. I suspect they will be fixed too as the game is still updated frequently. Some of the stuff such as character customization has now been addressed and the game is pretty open world. My only complaint at this point is how slow fights go. For example if you are fighting two or three zombies on a map with 25+ zombies that you haven't engaged yet... you still have to wait until the game cycles through ALL of the zombies before taking your next turn. I have literally spent more than an hour in one fight, particularly when using weapons and creating noise, more zombies will spawn to cycle through.

content:
er 5, 2014
												Hmm, It's early (almost an hour) and I don't know about it. I only put a thumbs up as steam wouldn't let me just skip the thumbs review. I think others should give a chance.Some thoughts though. Just my experience as a person who enjoys games and as a person who designs games as well. Take them for what they are : opinion.UI - clunky. Should be intuitive, at the beginning of the game it says to go in some directory find some manual that's more in depth. What putting a tab in the game was too much trouble?Reloading a gun - I don't even know how to do this. I thought it would be obvious like drag the correct ammo type on a gun. I have a snubnose .38, it says it takes .38 ammo - I think I should be able to A) right click or whatever and say load ammo B) drag and drop ammo on it C) I don't know, something else. Instead I have no idea. Someone saying "Well you need to read the manual" How about a nice cup of shut the hell up. Reallly. I'm not asking for a hand holding - I hate that. I would at least like some idea of how the hell you are supposed to something basic like that.Combat - clunky. It's trying to be xcom but it's not. The presentation of showing a zombie right next to you, and shows you swinging your axe/club/wrench etc and it goes right through and says "miss" is just poorly presented.  It's not that I know you can miss, like in real life it's the way its presented. Feels not fun.Controls are semi ok, the 3rd person rotating camera I'm actually ok with. I can't say I recommend or not recommend this game.  I don't think a game should be a case of "Well you will get used to it" or "You need to read about this and that" or "Well you are not playing it right" or whatever lame excuse someone wants to cook up. A game should find the fun. Period. If I'm not having fun , all the comments are pointless. It's like concetrating on the person instead of the underlying issue. Does no one any good.I'm still playing, and I plan another hour or two before I decide if I'm jumping ship. There's your review.12/09/14 I tried playing another 30 minutes. Everything above, yea throw that out the window. This game is really bad.

content:
, 2015
												First off, i want to respond to someone that clearly hasn't played the game long enough to know the basic combat mechanics, so people won't avoid this game based on a rather misinformed review: "-can't tank them"You can. Maximize vigor, strength, and put on a heavy armor. ...But that still doesn't mean you should, since dead character will stay dead. Avoid any direct confrontation if possible, whether it's against looters or zombies."-can't kite them"Every type of enemy has a certain vision range. Just make your party hides in a certain spot and *very* carefully send one party member to kite one or two of the zombies."-can't evade them"Put more points towards agility. But this is a survival strategy game in the first place, so what you really want to do is to kill off any threats as carefully and quietly as possible. And to add: positioning is *crucial* in any strategy game, so if you somehow messed up and got a party member surrounded by zombies, then you're the only one to blame for that. "-can't sneak past them"Stealth is a totally viable option, and is the preferred way of doing things in this game. Zombies has a rather small(er) visibility cone, so you CAN evade them and quite easily too compared to sneaking past looters. They do have better sense of hearing though, so if you're planning to do a sneak attack do it quickly. Initiate the attack a few squares away from behind the zombie."-must rely on luck to beat them"Every strategy game that has RNG relies on both skill and luck. I see no problem with this."-if you don't outnumber them 2 or 3 to 1, it has a high probability of a loss."Outnumbering them does indeed kills them more effectively, but that doesn't mean you can't send a party member with high Vigor and Strength/Agility plus a high enough melee skill to face off against a zombie one-on-one.I'm not saying the game is perfect. It's buggy at times, writing is... okay, and the graphics and animations are not exactly what you'd call stellar...But the game still offers exploration in a rather big world map, the strategy part is quite solid, you can recruit and manage survivors who also gives you choices and consequences that matters, and the best aspect i personally love the most: homebase management. I just wish they would offer more base other than the school though, and more interations between each survivors.Overall it's at least a 7/10 game, and is totally worth the price tag.
