content:
r 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								First of all, let me say that I am very impressed with Dead State so far.  I love the concept, and the interface, and I can tell it's destined to become a great zombie/survival game.  It is clearly still a work in progress, but that doesn't bother me.  I wanted to write this review to give the developers some intel on the bugs I've encountered so far during gameplay, so hopefully they can be addressed in future updates.  I love the game, but find that it has gotten a little more glitchy and harder to successfully play since the release of the last update.  Please note that these are notes I have taken since I started playing, and some problems listed here may already have been fixed.  But I just wanted to note everything, just in case.  So here we go...My notes are as follows:(1)  I wish you could split stacks of the same items in your inventory screen, so that you could easily split resources (like ammo) among party members or drop some (but not all) on the ground.  Right now, I feel like I have to load all the guns I have with my main character because I can't figure out how to divvy up ammo among party members, unless they each pick up some ammo for themselves here or there in scavving.  This also becomes an issue when dealing with weight, since some characters can carry more than others, and it could be possible to split heavier items to distribute the weight better among the party members.  (2)  In my game, when there are battle effects to a party member (which appear as small icons to the right of the party member's face on the left of the screen), I cannot hover over those icons to determine what effects they are having, and how to cure them.  Instead, I have to have to open the game manual (or just use my memory) to be able to figure it out.  It would be easier if I could gain info while hovering over these status icons.(3) The stats for weapons in inventory should show how many action points are required to use the weapon (at least for basic attacks).  It's helpful to know, before you equip something, that it takes 7 AP to use, rather than 3.(4)  On the job board, the stats for party members should show their HP, so I can be sure to assign the healthiest members of my group to active party/scouting/scavving/fighting duty.(5)  It would be nice if I could trade/provide equipment to various party members directly from the main storage shelf in the shelter, instead of having to equip them on the field with only items in my main character's inventory.  (Or if I could at least have a way to see the inventory of these other players while stationed in the shelter.)  I find it difficult to know what other party members are carrying, unless I've recently been in the field with them.  (6)  The pike weapon (the pitchfork) doesn't actually attack when "mangle" is selected.  It simply uses 7 AP while nothing happens.(7)  Priscilla's dialogue has some minor grammar errors:  "I barely every left my family's farm" should be "I barely ever left my family's farm" or "I barely even left my family's farm" and "I saw Todd's program and he preaced about tolerence" should be "I saw Todd's program and he preached about tolerence."(8)  When asked to make a decision about whether to engage in water purification system repairs, I was only given the option to side with Vic and refuse to make the repairs.  I don't know if this was a glitch, or something that resulted from my negotiation or leadership skill levels, or maybe my relationships with Vic and Todd, or maybe my lack of appropriate stored resources.  But I thought I'd mention it anyways.(9)  When Max joined the group, I was able to add him to my scavanging/scouting party immediately, even though he was supposed to be recovering after we found him at the gate.  So it was weird when he "woke up" in the game for the first time, since I had already been out fighting and scavving with him an hour before.  To avoid this weirdness, he should be unavailable for work on the job board for one or two days after his arrival at the shelter, until he recouperates.(10) It would be nice if there was a place on the Job Board or somewhere else, where you could easily see what day it is.  I can't easily determine what day it is.  (11)  I encountered two glitches in association with use of the watchtower:  (a) Doug has yelled at me about 10 times for failing to construct a watchtower.  The first time he did this, we were already in the process of building it.  The next times, it was already built, and I had assigned Doug to watchtower duty, so he should have known it was already built.  I think Doug should only yell at you once if you're actually doing what he says to do.  If you don't do it, he can continue to yell at you, but he should stop screaching about it once the tower is built. (b) When I set Doug to watchtower duty (and this only happened once, but it was a major glitch) and then took my party to scavange the truck stop where we picked up three new survivors (the 17 yr-old and Japanese woman being among them), Doug ended up "accidentally" coming with my party as a fifth party member.  You are only allowed to have four party members at a time, so Doug took the place of Joel in the icons on the left of the screen (although Joel was visibly still in the party).  Thus, I couldn't trade with Joel, even though he was fighting with me in my party.  During this time, I couldn't see the blue highlights on the face icons to indicate which party member was selected; doors, walls, and objects like tables and counters were ignored and walked through by party members (leading to unintentional encounters behind walls I didn't expect to pass through); the health of my party members never seemed to decrease, despite being in a significant battle, and despite the fact that when I returned to the shelter, my party members' health was shown to have decreased significantly; the decible system seemed to get stuck in the red, even though we had stopped using guns, and the zombies continued to fill the area until there must have been more than 100 of them.  (Perhaps this is supposed to happen in the game sometimes, but I wanted to note it since it's the first time I've seen the decible system stay maxed in the red for more than 10 turns after gunfire ceased.) (12) After the last major update, I am noticing the following glitches in the game, which I did not notice before (though these glitches seem to come and go, and are not there all the time):  (a) sometimes dead AI players in combat still look alive, even though I can search their supposedly dead bodies and cannot attack them anymore.  Because they look alive, the combat interface seems to believe that combat is still ongoing, so it doesn't release the group from combat until we slowly leave the area; (b) sometimes my healer can't heal my party members in combat when they are K.O.ed, even though my med bag is full.  It won't show the heal option when I hover over the K.O.ed player; and (c) sometimes the game won't let me fully kill an AI enemy who is K.O.ed.Okay...that's it for now.  Thanks for listening and working to create a great game!  If I find anything else during my play, I'll let you know.  Can't wait to see the game in its final form!!

								(the time played indicated doesn't reflect the real hours spent on this game because I only play offline)This game is a MUST HAVe if you are fan of survival zombies + lots of exploration on a quit big map + ressources gathering + team management + strategy (how the ressources should better be used, which PNJ should be let join the team of not (more manpower but also more mouth to feed, and so on), also what should be the short term/long term strategy to adopt) + some crafting + turn based fights + old school look (a bit like Wasteland 2 but slightly less good).If you are not a fan of all that, this game is probably not going to fit your tastes.But if you are fan of all that, you are really going to enjoy this game, even if it's still in Beta so still has a few bugs but nothing major as far as I can tell.Personnaly I love it, so thanks a lot to the small studio that did it ! :-)

content:
ry 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has a REALLY solid foundation to build upon. I Kickstarted this game a while back and have really been looking forward to it. Think Walking Dead (show) with turn based combat or State of Decay (another solid game) with turn based combat. While for the beta you can't create your character, you will in the full game along with the dog(e) companaion. You have to manage a base, resource, moral, and most of all your sanity dealing with other people. If you played the Facebook game, Last Stand: Dead Zone, this is similar to that game minus the Facebook "give us real money for XYZ or bug your buddies". I'm on day 3 in the demo and I'm enjoying what I'm seeing so far. I'm aware it has some jank to it, not all features are activated but I'm liking what I'm seeing so far. The game has a ton of potential and a must for those of use that enjoy turned based combat and "base" building.

content:
ry 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								XCom meets Project Zomboid.  Well, both of those games actually have more features but the game has it's moments.  The worlds / places you travel to are limited to maybe 3 or 4 buildings.  When you gather supplies and bring them back, you are very limited with what to do with what you collected, since the computer seems to take all your loot and sort it for you.  I'd even say State of Decay has more "shelter building" features than this game.  If the shelter had more options, more building, more hands on things rather than a "labor" board, the game would be much funner.  It is very overpriced for what it has to offer.I read from the creators that the game isn't really in alpha, but more of cut short.  If that's the case, there really aren't that many features to keep me interested.   I will continue to play and rate it positive simply because I just enjoy this genre, but there are much better games for the price point.Game play below.  Also tutorials on how to activate missions, use the inventory, heal, reload weapons, and use the UI.

												I really need to say a few things about Dead StateDead State is an amazing concept for fans of not only survival games, zombies, but general story-telling and in-game representation of real people reacting to the chaos of a world falling apart.The game starts out strong, with an interesting storyline, detailed interactions, and interesting exploration of the world around you - not only by physically going out there but hearing and reading about how things came to be this way and what's happening because of it.I frankly adored the first few hours of playing - and then this games seams began to showCharacters that only showed up the day before rebelling, no dialogue options to solve certain problems, and an ending that truly made me wonder why I began playing in the first place.What was the point of playing if - no real spoilers - the game simply fades out after a picture of essentailly "JOB WELL DONE" flashes on the screen.If you read this review before buying - don't buy this game.

er 14, 2014
												How can be a very good idea transformed into a poor game. However, the graphics is not bad -except the characters when moving during fight.- People special need and Base management is a mess...moving character around the building, find stuff, find other characters, find other rooms is something very basic. Other guys are always need the same...cigar, sleeping pills, etc. After a while you are just running around and bringing cigars and spices, etc. like a grocer.- Conversation...simple, boring, flat text options. The same questions and similar answers.- Turn base fight...your guys could not hit the enemy from point range....using "weapons" means nothing, it is the same near-random generator fight. Moving during fight...I was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off when my team was unable to move out and died in a toilet. Nonsense. Cannot attack with meele weapon, just from 90 degree. I have seen similar game on my Commodore 64 when I was teenage.- Music, sounds, noise...the same 5-6 effects are repeating.- Characters can move across walls. Nice. Just the enemy, not your team, of course.- What I can say "positive" is the idea of the game and the base development. This part is the best written code, it is working and nice. You can build things, like mushroom farm and the whole population is living on mushrooms. Broaf....- Unfortuntely base management as I said, very simple. If something is wrong, just assign someone to fix. Cleaning and maintenance is simple...watchtower I have need some people to watch but the oldest guys can do the job. Probably with strong glasses...All in all, the idea of this game is great, the implementation does not worth the price.

number of helpful: 23 of 51 people (45%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												 Despite a few present bugs, and as much as people seem to be ♥♥♥♥♥ing about bugs, I've honestly enjoyed my time spent playing it. It really scratched the 'long term' zombie survival itch, something which is missing from most every zombie game presently.      There seem to be a few weird attempts to shoehorn in issues that are politically charged, like This gay Texas ranger shows up, the guy is really useful, really high stats, but he shrugs off his 'partner' dying in a car crash and just carries on without any problems, I know the guy was in the Army, but jeez. Knowing this 'controversial character' thing, the issue of him being gay will probably come up and you'll have to choose a side. and at one point a lady helicopter pilot wants an abortion and the preacher who was a missionary and worked in foriegn countries wants her to keep it, and you gotta choose a side, and theres more NPC conflict interactions like that, most of which aren't issues if you've got good negotiation and leadership skills.     Maybe its just me understanding that issues like these are inserted into games, not to make a meaningful message, or take a stance, but, added to try and generate 'buzz' or 'controversy' That sort of thing feels a little hamfisted, but npc dialogue isn't that important anyways, and whats present is pretty good, nothing absurd, but, I think the writing is a bit lacking in the overall amount of it, it would be nice to see more circumstantial responses and general dialogue.Now, lets get to the meat of it, the game: Turn based like fallout 2 and a "S.P.E.C.I.A.L"-lite stat system, with actions that use AP in combat with free movement when out of it. It works, its good, I like it very much. There are the occasional out of combat pathfinding bug, but thats not a problem really. Its really enjoyable.     What should be added: The ability to reload a single shot for less AP or something like that on certain weapons, maybe accessories you can find and attach or use with  weapons to change their stats, like speed loaders for revolvers, better recoil pads, scopes, stuff like that, maybe even give the same treatment to melee weapons, maybe wrapping some barbed wire around a bat, etc.I really do hope the developers keep adding content or open the game to being modifiable by the community and stick it on the steam workshop.Its a good game, made by a small developer, and I recommend it.

content:
er 14, 2016
												As much as I want to love this game, I can't give it a passing grade. I love isometric, turn based RPGs... yet Deadstate doesn't scratch the same itch that Fallout 1 & 2 do and I'd reccomend going to those games before going with Deadstate. I did not buy the game, I played it from a friend's library so I'm just sharing my thoughts here.[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ]  [/url][ http://url=store.steampowered.com ]  [/url]The overall combat feels lacking with no real special animations or flash to give it that lasting appeal. There are no brutal fatalities like there are in Fallout, hint go play that game.Scaving feels underhwelming as the end result of your work ends up getting autosorted when you get to base and the amount of things you can do with said supplies are limited. Project Zomboid has a more rewarding Scaving system and I'd also say go with that.[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ]  [/url]It all feels pretty bland and generic. I won't rip on the graphics as I believe in gameplay>graphics. A game that seems like a carbon copy of this, but feels better for the price is a game called Survivalist. Its got worse graphics, but the price is only a dollar or so, trust me its better than it seems... just mute the music when you get in-game.[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ] http://store.steampowered.com/app/340050/ [/url]While it's certainly not the best, its not the worst and could be picked up on sale for >10$ I saw Deadstate a long while back when I was naive to the early access/survival game trend and had foolishly sunk cash into another Zombie early access game  called  The Dead Linger (Which  Surprise! turned out to be a flop, money wasted but lesson learned). After being burned by that I decided to pass up Dead State, which I'm happy I did for its original price. However, I saw how hard the developers worked on this and tried to make it work, but I simply cannot give this game a passing grade for its current price.TL:DR, here are some better options to spend your cash on:FALLOUT 1 & 2[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ] http://store.steampowered.com/app/38400/ [/url][ http://url=store.steampowered.com ] http://store.steampowered.com/app/38410/ [/url]PROJECT ZOMBOID[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ] http://store.steampowered.com/app/108600/ [/url]SURVIVALIST[ http://url=store.steampowered.com ] http://store.steampowered.com/app/340050/ [/url]

content:
er 17, 2014
												I don't play many games apart from my main favourite which is RPGish, so I think it's time to put in my twopennorth. I started to play Dead State about a week ago, and I found it pretty tough, and also frustrating in several ways. Today was patch day, and it plays so much better. Well it does for me. Now it will run in widescreen on my laptop, so that's nice. And there's an autosave, so that's nice. I am currently playing with as much survival emphasis in my character build as is sensible, I include the mom and daughter in the away team, and one other. Apparently I will be able to have 4 companions now...yes, that's also nice. On our shopping trip today we got a load of meds and fuel, and plenty of food (even a few apples), so we had the next day (gametime ofc) off. I am still laughing at the tooltip for Elaine which says "Undamaged". Ha!  I am looking forward to getting a car of some sort, because that will be also nice. So, here I am, now walking softly but carrying a big stick, and not really getting mad at the game anymore. I like it and have now recommended it. it isn't perfect, but it is cheap, and I think it represents very good value.  Happy holidays to you all from England.

content:
ry 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Firstly let me say I'm a KS supporter. I backed this game years ago. I"m pretty satisfied with what I've playe so far (limited as it may be). there are many positives to this game, the story seems like its going to good, the gameplay is compelling. The TB strat aspect is very cool. Hopefully in the final game we will have our base attacked, be able to relocated and be able to farm areas for tools and survivors. I enjoy the fog of war, the difficulty of the game and it seems like many many more things will be available once it launches.Now onto the negative. This is NOT a EA game, this is a DEMO. In EVERY EA game I've played the game will evolve over time, more content will be opened and entire things may change. In this DEMO everything will remain pretty much the same until the game launches. We will get nothing after the first 7 days are done. I understand why they did this, however they lied to us about what we would get. We were promised early access to a beta type game and that we would have the abliity to help mold this game into what it would become. We instead get this.Let me be clear, this is going to be a good game if you enjoy TBS with a dynamic of base and npc interaction. This will be a good game for you if you enjoy zombie survival. But dont be decieved, this game is a DEMO and you can get it for free in a couple of months when it launches. If you don't want to buy a demo just wait in my opinion.

content:
er 18, 2014
												It's a lot of fun.  Turn based combat Fallout-style, scavenging in the zombie apocalypse for food and base upgrades, people management with distinct personalities, keeping morale up is a real part of the mechanic- and each morning there are some choices to make.  There are a lot of aspects and they're all entertaining, and with some nice touches of humor in the background props.  I'm not finished with the game and still the story and goals are evolving.  I feel like the characters progress and have opinions, and actually ended up taking them on scouting missions based on who I "like" better instead of strictly their stats.  Well, once.  It takes a very long time to wait through rounds of medics and salesmen failing to bash zombies, until the big rig driver's turn comes around and she finally lands a staggering killing blow with her sledgehammer.

content:
20, 2016
												I don't understand why all the positive reviews. Maybe I'm just not getting the game like you guys are.I bought this mainly because it looked fun and seemed like a zombie version of Wasteland 2. It is almost alike, but this game isn't very good to me. Below are a list of pros and cons I can think of.Pros:It's addicting and fun.Cons.-The enemies are too strong. You start a game with weak weapons and whatnot. I understand that. But the fact that it takes 3 people to kill 1 zombie is rediculous! It shouldn't take 3 people and 5 turns to kill 1 zombie. Same with humans. 3v1 + turns. That's just really.. Really dumb.-AI are not smarter. Do not believe the description. If an enemy has a gun, they will keep using it until they have no ammo left. So if you're fighting 1 looter and he has a gun, you have 3 people, he's going to cause 150+ noise in the first few turns. By time he runs out of ammo, it's too late. There are a dozen zombies swarming you and the looter. At that point you might as well quickload and avoid the 1 looter altogether and just exit the area. This game kind of forces you to avoid combat or else you're going to suffer heavy damage against 1 enemy.Like I said, the pro was that it was fun and addicting, but the two cons make it unplayable.. If it takes 5 turns to kill 1 zombie with 3 people even with using side and back attacks, imagine the difficulty of fighting 2 zombies with 3 people. At least 1 person will get infected, one person will get heavily wounded, or worse. The fact that using alternate attacks reduces your hit chance considerably makes it all the less enjoyable too. I already have 55% chances to hit on side attacks.. Let's reduce it to 20% chance.All in all, this game is good. I'd recommend playing it and all, but I just can't get in to it because of these stupid AI and super resiliant enemies. It feels like they get 200 health and I get 100 health. If there was a medium when recommending, I'd choose that. However, considering there is only "Yes" and "No," I'd have to say I don't recommend this. This isn't a terrible game - it's very enjoyable, it's just annoying. I'll continue to play it and try new things out and I'll change my review if i can figure out a better gameplan, but as it stands.. This is really hard.

content:
3, 2016
												This game has a LOT to love, but almost as much (maybe more, depending on you and your preferences) to hate. I find that the pros strongly outwiegh the cons, but this is NOT going to be the case for everyone. So, in short order, I present a warning label:WARNING! This game contains bugs, crashes, missing/incorrect tool tips, repetitive gameplay, extreme micromanagement, a somewhat significant RNG element to combat, the desire to see you suffer if you don't you abuse quick save or if you play on Ironman, a decisive and unavoidable "end" (which is somewhat to extremely unsatisfying), little actual replay value, boring loot, extremely repetitive enemies, negative outcomes for events you didn't even know existed/had a time limit on, and other, smaller problems/annoyances.Okay, so, you just read that warning and you're like, "But you're still recommending the game? Did you hit the wrong button?" And the answer is, no, I didn't hit the wrong button. Yes, I am still recommending the game. Why? It's actually really simple: this is the most complete zombie survival game I've ever played. By a good margin to. The only thing that even comes close to this is State of Decay (another fun game), but that had a LOT of things missing from the overall experience that this does NOT leave out.The game is SO much more than "Board up the windows, get food and meds, smash zombies with sticks." You got TONS of complex and interesting survivors to rescue, each with a moderate to extremely detailed backstory, and an well written (if mostly cliche) story with a begining, middle, and end (and the story is REALLY long...expect a full playthru of this game to take 50+ hours if you're rushing, 100+ for a good playthru, and 150+ for a "full clear). There are group dynamics to think of, food issues, morallity issues, morale issues, medical issues, supply issues, factions, gangs, hordes, psychos, pets, carnies, crises, leadership struggles, a search for a cure, a MASSIVE (and somewhat optional) in-world lore database, and so much more. If you've been looking for the ultimate zombie survival simulator, and other games have left you wanting more, left you feeling like something is missing, this is the game for you.There are issues (listed above). Many of said issues can be fixed by reading the (mediocre but not awful) official wiki or Steam guides (there are like 3 of them worth a damn, the other 5 or so are garbage), and occasionally searching in the Steam or official forums. But the big one (IMO), which is the repetitive gameplay with weak instant gratification. If that doesn't bother you (like it doesn't bother me), and you're not quite sick of zombies (which I'll never be), this just might be the game for you. If you've been looking for the ultimate zombie survival sim, this IS the game for you.So yeah, give it a whirl. Hope you enjoy it as much as I have.

ber 28, 2015
												I'm guessing the game got good reviews based on the genre and not the actual game.  As a fan that has been watching and looking forward to the development and release, only to be utterly disappointed.  The writing has the elequence and style of a 15 year old boy (although that is debatable as I think the average teenager might have been able to come up with better writing).  The game touts the decisions you make affecting he outcome of the game.  What that really means is that the dialogue comes to a grinding halt until you figure out what the character needs,  The controls are clunky, I would say the original X-COM has a better interface and flow.  I knew that the game would have graphics on par with what you'd find 15-20 years ago, but that being said I kept an open mind as there are great games that don't necessarily have modern graphics.  Sadly this is not one of them.  I'm a super fan of the zombie genre and would recommend either Left for Dead game or Dead Island would be money better spent,  What I expected was a game on par with say the new X-COM Enemy Unseen or at least close to that level of production and what I got was a 1996 classic, that would have been great 20 years ago, but has as much appeal to me as firing up the old adventure game on the atari 2600.

content:
r 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								Dead in the water. ( An early access review of Dead State(2nd attempt)) by Merit Coba.Imagine you are in a restaurant downtown and you are invited by the waiter to come over to the kitchen to help the cook select the ingredients for your dinner, tell him how much you want and describe how to cook it.  You then return to your table. When the waiter arrives with three plates, he puts one plate down and then tosses the contents of the plates on top of the others. What do you get?On the 31st of October a release date was announced for Dead State: the 4th of December.This means that the game must by now, writing early November, be in a state to be sold after some minor tweaking and polishing.Is that the case? Now on the upside this game has many things to commend it.For one is that they made your character's improvement part of a goal system instead of  the usual experience system. Next to that you can kind of improve you other party members by assigning them jobs and at times influence their progress through dialogs. Also commendable is the way they give the game a kind of flow. At the start even a single zombie is a challenge for your group, let alone a group of them, but after a while zombies are no longer a danger but hostile people, those with guns and armor.  Another great idea is how the zombies can kill your party members and enemy humans and make them zombies to. One of the craziest encounters is  when your party runs into a shootout between two gangs while zombies attack from all sides.At the core there are good ideas but this game is far from finished and beset with many issues. Here is a random list.The game lacks a general story line, it is either not there or just not finished. There is a kind of conflict brewing between the militia at one hand and the military at the other, but  when I tried to talk to either side I was told to get lost.  There were some small incidents, like the military asking me for supplies and a proclamation from the militia, but  this didn't seem to open up more dialog.Storylines are broken. An example is the one of Fiona Parks, a girl who is devoted to you. At some moment I was approached by Davis, one of the survivors, telling me how sorry he was about what Fiona did. I had no clue what he was talking about and Fiona was fine. This went of every morning until at one point it was announced that Fiona had killed someone. She duly got a trial(in which she supported the side that demanded her death), then a minute later she was reported to have killed again, was put on trial again and banned. Since then the Davis conversation happens every morning. (At least it makes sense now.)Most zombies don't roam but just stand around so you can take them out one at a time, mostly by attacking them from behind.Groups of zombies or people stop being a danger because you can kill them one at a time by bashing on a locked door that is out of their view, which will then draw in your enemies one at a time(and the door will be restored to full points when you reload a saved game, so you can repeat this until all the enemies have been taken care of). That way you can gang up on one of them and thus take down stronger enemies that would normally wipe your party out.(One tip: give Vic a shotgun. And if you can get the combat shotgun he becomes an unstoppable force. In fact after a while you are pretty invulnerable.)Unfinished maps, empty maps, maps that don't work, doors that don't work properly, invisible barriers, barriers that you can walk through(the Coleman side entry).  Dogs can only be attacked from the front and the back and sometimes not be shot at. Fifth party members showing up unexpectedly. The chicken and egg issue: to build your chickencoop you need to find a chicken, when you do it gets slaughtered when you take it home because you don't have a chickencoop. Some quests are broken(Aggro asks you to get Alan, but he never shows).There is a quest for swapping food for medicines, but you can't get food from your storage, although you can fish for fish. I did so and took the fish with me to this deal. Then the deal was made, but no exchange happened yet I got a message that the deal went really well.The game doesn't keep a record of the locations that you already visited agains the locations that other survivors tell you about, so you get a message that they marked a  new location on your map, but nothing shows because you already discovered it.When fully upgraded the fence can't be repaired(unless it is completely destroyed I guess).Some upgrades on your shelter are described not to function. Some items have no icons. The storage of your shelter is bugged for sometimes the tabs won't work. This seems to effect mostly the ammunition tab and this might have something to do with creating ammoThe radio you can create to assign jobs doesn't work.Ammo you can create yourself and it only costs you a one time price to give you access to an unlimited supply of them. So in the end you can just bang away as ammo isn't an issue(this might by intendend)On and on goes the list of issues. I was amazed about all these issues for people seem to think well of this game, so I checked the game agains steam several times and even have reinstalled it from scratch. I even tried to see I could download a recent upgrade from the double bear website, but they just point me to steam. Maybe steam is hosting a old game or  perhaps what I describe is the current state of the game.I suspect the latter as I see in the forums many of the issues being mentioned.Maybe the game is remarkably patched by the time it gets released but based on what I experienced above and based on the price I still give it a thumbs down.No doubt someone is going to say that what I say is not true, so what I would suggest is that you just look around on the forums that talk about this game and, if it is available, download a demo.I hope that the game developers finish the game properly.. it certainly has it's merits.I have another review here which shows pictures so you have also visible proof of what I am saying.http://meritcoba.com/2014/11/15/a-game-review-dead-statea-tale-of-errors-a-chicken-a-murderess-and-a-ghost-and-lots-of-zombies-too/Log:22 November: added a header.. corrected some writing mistakes. Removed some sentences.

y 17, 2015
												:Dso.... i was actually banned from the forums for my super negative review of this game during beta... so... disregard every single other review. mine is the only one that matters. this game... is.... ♥♥♥♥ing... zong. i liked it. it took forever for the devs to make it, and it still has some issues with crashing... but if you want a zed survival game, this is the best youre gonna get. you have to feed your entire base, you have to keep them happy with toilet paper and all that jazz, you have to squash your enemies with you tactical awareness.for the stupid people, you know, the ♥♥♥♥ers who failed highschool and all that sharting nonsense.... this game will suck. your survival in this game is directly linked to your IQ. if you are stupid, youre gonna die. miserably. either your own people will kill you, or youll die in combat. for the rest of the world? merry bloody tradalmes, because this game satisfies everything you so desperately crave that only occurs during the apocalypse.the women will worship you if you survive long enough, the USA military will bow down and swear fealty or be squashed by your might, and all those racist prats will beg for mercy when you take control of the only fuel source. this game has everything youd expect to happen during zed apocalypse: criminal factions, MLK factions, Military factions... fighting for food, guns, and toilet paper(id rather wipe my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with the faces of the dead, but thats just me...). the leveling up system is very goal oriented, dont expect to gain 10xp per kill in this game, this is 100% about keeping everyone alive and well fed.i laugh reading the negative comments: omg davis just shot me because i was negative yada yada yada... you obviously suck at survivng the apocalypse. i have a morale of something like 10k, ive never had a negative day... im just smarter than you though, so dont worry. ur bad, im gerd. ive been with doublebear since the absolute beginning. ive had my ups and downs with this game. i wrote an absolute SCATHING review for this game during beta, ripped them a new ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥,... but they listened to me, and fixed the problems i addressed. their end product isnt quite finished, but its still good. they have about another 6 months to finish this game, imho, but in its current form id say it was quite good.

er 5, 2014
												I would not pay $5.00 for this game. Though the graphics are decent and the survival element is there the combat system is horrid to say the least. A choke point between a door? Well lets just say during the (Action/combat) sequence people cannot move out of the way of eachother to get around to the other side to join in combat. Small but with always and I mean always a situation as soon as you dwelve into a new compound. At the start of the game I ordered a police office to shoot his weapon at the zombie approx 2 blocks to his left. I know that a person was between him and the zombie but surely as the zombie literally being 5 feet away and the person 1 foot away the office could aim... Headshot... to my party... Well I knew then that I could'nt recommend this. If say the party was fighting a zombie 50 feet away then he should have a chance to inflict accidental friendly fire but 5 feet away? I think not... SO that makes all ranged weapons very useless as the move action and turn based strategy persists. With movement being clunky and not at all fluid how can You properly raid a building? That is a game breaker. When the most basic mechanic is not instilled in a turn base "stratagy game" I sincerely can not possibly recommend this game.Josh

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
I want everyone to know right here and now that DoubleBear has been exhibiting some very inappropriate business practices, in my opinion. This review is to tell the community of those practices, as well as reviewing the game itself. People, you are basically being lied to by DoubleBear.Before you write a response to my review, please be sure to read my entire review first. I understand if you only want to skim it, and that's fine, but please try not to make an argument until you DO fully read the whole thing. I'd like to not repeat myself, but I do understand that I will be writing a lot and it's hard to read it all. I want to inform all of you that I will not only be reviewing this game, but also the business practices of the developers, DoubleBear. There is some very inappropriate behavior going on on their end and I want the community to know about it. I'm going to tell everyone about it very calmly, and very fairly, but I'm going to be 100% brutally honest. I want the community to know, because they have a right to, and I will be very appropriate about it so there will be no reason to accuse me of being abusive, rude, or anything of the sort. I want to make that very clear.As a disclaimer: If I edit this review, I will always leave everything I originally wrote in this review. I am the sort of person who will admit their mistakes, (unless it's a typo, I'll fix typos without telling you I did that, I mean come on) and who doesn't like to change what was originally there. I will always tell you whatever I am editing (again, unless it's a typo), so that way the integrity of this, and myself, is never compromised.First of all, I want to say that this is a pretty good game. I don't prefer turn-based games, but for a turn-based game, it's not bad at all. A little bit basic, there doesn't feel like there's much meat to it, and maybe that's just because I'm so used to my games having voice acting in them or something, I'm not sure. It's true that it's only essentially a Beta version of a demo, so of course it's not that developed - and I understand that, that makes sense. But that is all you are currently purchasing. A demo. This is not an Early-Access game. It is the first 7 days of the game, and you will never get any more days until the full game is released. That is one of my main problems with this game. You are, essentially, being lied to by the developers. It used to be they had the word "demo" plastered everywhere, all over their game summaries and descriptions and even in the early-access disclaimer thing. Now, you can't find the word "demo" anywhere, and on top of that, the limit of them informing you what you are actually purchasing for $25 are only these two sentences:"Dead State is currently in Early Access - purchasing now will eventually unlock the full game for you at final release, and in the meantime you can playtest the first seven days of the game (ongoing feature updates are planned)."and"Dead State: The First Seven Days is an early, WIP preview of the first week of Dead State's gameplay - an opportunity to prepare your strategy for the full game and help us test and polish the full Dead State experience."To the layman? Who only skims the description because, let's be honest, a good majority of people? Only skim. This looks like it is saying "For now you get the first 7 days, but maybe as we go along until release, we'll be releasing more days." -- Because that is what Early-Access is, or at the very least is supposed to be -- that is what the majority of gamers on the planet AGREE Early-Access means.People, I want to be very clear: When you purchase this game, right now. When you click that green button, go to your cart, and click the green 'purchase for myself' button, you are spending $25 on a 7-day demo of this game. The most that will happen to that demo is small updates to it, like new items, the battle system itself vaguely changing, and maybe some text changing. You will never, ever, ever get past those first 7 days of gameplay. Not until the full game releases. That is a fact. That is a completely indisputable fact.****I have a lot more to add on here, but I can not fit it all on this review page. Please, please, please click the link to Gamespot at the bottom of this review and read the whole thing, at the very least do so before commenting on my review.****Now, to my actual gameplay review:The game is alright. I know it seems like I couldn't have played enough for very long, but believe me, I got enough time to play that I know exactly what the game is about and how it works.In all honesty? It's kind of like a Zombie Apocalypse version of Pokemon Mystery Dungeon. There are some tweaks here or there, obviously, but generally speaking it's very similar. If you're not careful, you could end up inadvertently shoving a character in the middle of like 8 zombies at once, and though that's a true danger in most zombie apocalypse worlds, I have a hard time believing my other characters would take about 8 turns before saving him. That was literally the first thing that happened to me when I went into the game. I literally quit and started over again because the game gave me absolutely NO warning that something like that could happen.Now, maybe it's just me, and maybe it's just because it's been a really long time since I played a turn-based game last, but when I played this game, I got absolutely NO instruction on how to play, whatsoever. And again, maybe it's just because I'm a moron -- I definitely can be, from time to time. But when I first played, I had no idea what was better - was the knife better? Or was the bat better? I had no idea, because I had no idea what the difference (in this game) piercing damage was in comparison to blunt damage. I mean of course most people assume piercing damage DOES more damage, but honestly some basic gamers may not know that, and they're not very clear about it.On top of that, I had absolutely no idea that, when I started, the zombies were all gonna get 2 fighting turns in a row and I was only going to get 1. I also didn't know that even if the screen was clear, they could still appear later, around corners and the like - again, I know that SHOULD be generally common sense, but I've been spoiled by all of the other open-world games out there, and I'm used to a goblin being around a corner before I even get around that corner. I've played so many various games that I NEED to be told the rules in a game like this, I can't just predict them, because I've just played so many other games with so many other rules.Also, for the record, the graphics are pretty bleh. Even for an early version of the game. I mean it's 2014, we expect quite a bit more out of games these days, even top-down turn-based ones.EDIT: THIS IS NOT MY FULL REVIEW. This is only PART of my review. Unfortunately, my full Review cannot fit on this page - so, for the moment, this is all I can give you - I've managed to cut this review down quite a bit, and now you can find the very, very basics in THIS review. However, there is a LOT more that needs to be covered, and it IS covered at the website I have listed at the end of my review.But for now, please read this review with a grain of salt, as it needs some editing and it is not my full review.Please go to the below website to read my full review before commenting below. If you comment below after only reading the very little tidbits I've written above, I will know. You are absolutely welcome to post without reading my full review, but know that I won't be able to take you entirely seriously if you do something like that.EDIT: For now, please read my full review here: http://www.gamespot.com/dead-state/forums/dead-state-review-31359805/?wikiTypeId=5000&wikiId=97268

content:
er 6, 2014
												A banana is an edible fruit, botanically a berry,[1][2] produced by several kinds of large herbaceous flowering plants in the genus Musa.[3] (In some countries, bananas used for cooking may be called plantains.) The fruit is variable in size, color and firmness, but is usually elongated and curved, with soft flesh rich in starch covered with a rind which may be green, yellow, red, purple, or brown when ripe. The fruits grow in clusters hanging from the top of the plant. Almost all modern edible parthenocarpic (seedless) bananas come from two wild species – Musa acuminata and Musa balbisiana. The scientific names of most cultivated bananas are Musa acuminata, Musa balbisiana, and Musa × paradisiaca for the hybrid Musa acuminata × M. balbisiana, depending on their genomic constitution. The old scientific name Musa sapientum is no longer used.Musa species are native to tropical Indomalaya and Australia, and are likely to have been first domesticated in Papua New Guinea.[4][5] They are grown in at least 107 countries,[6] primarily for their fruit, and to a lesser extent to make fiber, banana wine and banana beer and as ornamental plants.

Early Access Review
								This is a review of the first 10 seconds of the game.  During character creation, the default sex for characters is female, which is rapidly becoming a pet peeve of mine.  I'm all for progress and the inclusion of women (and any other demographic that so desires) in games, but "ladies first" is hardly inclusive or progressive.  Putting men first here, while also unfair, is at least traditional -- like "ladies and gentlemen."  Do the devs expect that most players will be female?  Or perhaps that most characters will be?The rest of the game may be really good, but I've stopped supporting developers who are so eager to be seen not to be unfair to women that they never consider that it's possible to be unfair to men.  I'm putting this up for people like me.

												As a fan of turn-based combat: I like this game a lot (as you can see how much hours I already spent on this game).It has the same basic principles as for example state of decay:1. fighting zombies2. scavenge food, medicine, ammo, construction materials and gasoline to survive3. fortify your baseThe difference is that it has turnbased combat instead of being a FPS, there is much more social management, the devs invested more time in portraying the characters, there is more freedom of choices and it is overall a great rpg/strategy game.One of the finer aspects is that you'll meet a lot weird characters and other survivor factions and it's up to you how to deal with them. You can trade with a survivor faction or kill them and take all their stuff. The characters you meet may join your faction or you can kill them or you can leave them to their fate.The atmosphere is very realistic. The people in the game usually don't or didn't behave in a morally correct way in such times of anarchy. The absence of law enforcement always lead to the way of nature: survival of the fittest! In a modern sense.So, yes, I recommend it. And thanks to the devs for this great game!

content:
ry 26, 2015
												"When the final modern human closes his eyes for the last time, a profound sadness and sense of loss will flash before them, and they will feel around their back for the weapon that did them in and remove a dagger made of apathy."To be brief, Dead State is an indie game that delivers a human narrative in the face of a world shattering disaster.  You play one of the few remaining souls willing to attempt to hold things together by running a shelter.  The primary goal as a player is to manage resources, over all morale and moods of individual survivors.  These three facets are mostly achieved by exploring the areas outside of the shelter to retrieve everything from antibiotics to toothpaste.  This task will frequently involve dealing with the less threatening slow moving zombies but the larger threat is from looters and other hostile groups that will shoot you for your shoes.  There are other faces outside of the shelter that will hold conversations, often these are survivors who you can offer a place to call home, but there are others about as well.This game is not a fast paced charge into hoards of the undead.  It is a cautious march forward in the direction of hope.--Reanimated Update--I can no longer recommend this game after the Reanimated update.  They've made the slow moving outdated combat even slower.  The only interesting part about the game is the character writing and how the stories between survivors evolve through the course of the game.  However, getting to these events is now a tiresome chore that sap all replay value out of the game.  According to the dev's forum posts they have no intention of changing this as they have been defeated by the difficult engine they chose to make their game with.  It's just not worth it after Reanimated.

content:
er 5, 2014
												UPDATE -- 6/8/2015:I am writing this as an update to take into account the “Reanimated” version of Dead State.This is finally the version that buyers paid for, and the one that should have been released commercially.  All the bugs I mentioned or encountered have been fixed.  Additionally, the combat has been fixed.  Previously, it was just a matter of running up behind a zombie, pressing space to pause, and then one-shotting the zombie.  Rinse and repeat.  There was no real risk, and it felt fairly tedious.Now, combat starts as soon as you get close to a zombie, so that previous strategy is no longer possible.  I’m finding that change to make combat much more harrowing, much more of a risk vs. reward proposition.The scavenging can get a bit tedious, so make sure to take breaks once in awhile.  Personally, for me, it was the cutscenes every morning (and the somewhat rare group leader meetings) that has kept me going.  I do enjoy those.The Reanimated version has also added Ironman mode, Hardcore mode, and another mode where your own player character can get infected.  I did make sure to turn that last option on when I started my Reanimated playthrough.When I wrote my initial review, I wasn’t expecting a 100% perfect game, but I was expecting a playable one.  Dead State is now playable through its Reanimated version.  Dead State is a very specific type of game, and so while I wouldn’t recommend it universally, if the concept sounds appealing to you and you’re a patient individual, I would recommend a purchase of this Reanimated version.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Original Review:I've been trying to rationalize how anyone could give Dead State a positive review, and the only thing I can think of is they're shills for the developer.  Either that or they regret wasting their money on Dead State and want others to suffer as well.I bought Dead State due to all the glowing reviews, including Lex's lengthy one.  I haven't felt this burned by a game purchase in a long, long time.  Dead State, as of its full release, is a buggy, cheap mess.  The characters are shallow, repeating the same conversation options day after day.  The combat -- such a central part of a game like this -- is crude and simplistic.  There is no cover or no crouching.  Sometimes if you hover your mouse over the ground, it will show the movement cost.  Sometimes not.  There is no option to aim with pistols, and pistols have a maximum range of literally 15 feet.  Past 15 feet, you have a 0% chance to hit.And here's the thing: I love tactical games like XCOM.  I love base-building aspects.  I love RPGs.  I love zombies.  And yet Dead State fails on all accounts.This War of Mine, a survival game just recently released, blows Dead State out of the water, and TWoM costs $20, less than Dead State.  The sheer fact that Dead State is asking for $30 is disgraceful.  There are free flash games that are better and more fulfilling, games like Rebuild or Last Stand.Graphics don't make or break a game for me -- I play rogue-like games like Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup because I care more about gameplay than how a game looks.  However, Dead State is buggy and shallow AND looks atrociously bad.  I mean just absolutely horrible.Pros+ The basic theme had promiseCons- Shallow characters- Massive amount of bugs- Simplistic gameplay- Horrible 1990s UI- Weak narrative- Grating music- Poor camera angles- Ugly graphicsAnd then they slap you in the face with the $30 price.I could go on and on about more specifics, like how putting unique weapons like pepper spray or nailguns in the base inventory removes and destroys all ammo from them.  Or how morale hits rock bottom despite carting back a department store's worth of goods every day.  Or how one NPC gets angry and discusses deserting because he's not in my party enough....  and I've used him 100% of the time.  Or how you have to wait for a heavily armed camp labeled "hostile looters" to open fire on you before you fire back, otherwise your party members accuse you of killing innocent people.There's more.  So much more.  I cannot in good conscience recommend Dead State.  Don't waste your money on this lemon.EDIT UPDATE:  I'm trying it out after the latest patch.  I'll give credit where credit is due:  Most of the bugs, if not all of them, that I mentioned have been fixed by the developer.  I don't think I've ever seen game bugs be fixed that fast before in my entire life.  So at least the developers are on the ball as far as that goes.I've found yet more bugs since trying it out again, and it's still a crazy mess not even close to worth the asking price.  I won't say that the developers are inattentive, however.

9, 2016
												Although even the Reanimated version of the game is still plagued by scripting errors (story events repeating more than 10 times... Karen!), spelling mistakes, glitchy engine behaviour (enemies being able to spot players and hit them through locked doors) and the lack of the cure ending (even though it's heavily hinted at), I still very much enjoyed DS:R. The writing and dialogue are simply great, the story lines for other survivors are fleshed out well for the most part and the various location for scavenging have a lot of atmosphere, are believable and often tell their own little stories. Moreover, the turn-based style of play in conjunction with the usage of active perks can make combat very satisfying if planned right. The shelter gameplay does leave quite a bit to be desired, however. There's no way to view survivor perks through the task board, for instance, which makes the job of optimising morale gain somewhat tedious. The data cracking mini-game could have been a lot less annoying, too. Although I tended to crack the codes the same day I found the items, which generates a steady flow of skill points - especially if combined with daily gift giving -, I can imagine this process being extremely boring when you've neglected them for a while. On the other hand the shelter map does reflect the progression you make, since it's updated when new facilities have been built. All in all, I would definitely recommend this game, if you don't mind the turn-based isometric style, aren't bothered by micromanaging morale and tasks and can overlook some technical and design flaws. The story and dialogue more than make up for it.

er 23, 2016
												There is always been a love for the classic style that indeed is the original X-Com.  Developing a squad, a team, and gradually through smart play and fighting exploring different areas and using the terrain both for and against.Dead State finds a way to combine the style of that classic game into another popular genre, the zombie apocolypse.  And it really is a brilliant game!  Not only do you have to deal with the different Survivors you can rescue, but you have to deal with their demands and your own.  Plus there's a lot of wonderful "self character' development, in that you can choose so many little details for your own character.  And there's a wealth of "background material" inside the game itself that can draw you into ths world and it's history.  And the choices you make throughout the game are remembered, both the good, and the bad.  You set the course.Classic turn style with squad based tactics, just remember the living can be more dangerous.

												Very good turn-based tactical game. Good story and it gives the player a good amount of freedom in choices. I forbid an abortion of one of the survivors, she hates me now but will thank me later when her kid is older (hopefully)...The game has a higher difficulty than usual, you cannot pick every fight at the first days and have to eventually run away when you find yourself in a gunfight while only wielding kitchen knifes and axes... So its not meant for the masses because you might actually have casualties in battles and due to bad choices you made. During the later stages, difficulty drops as you get a hang of the game and much better weapons.Definitely worth buying.Edit: Boy, have I been wrong about that abortion... the game has some interesting plot twists for sure...

er 20, 2016
												Be warned whilst I recommend this game it isn't saying it is the best RPG I have ever played, far from. Whilst it takes the beloved RPG and introduces the zombie survival element, the fact it is the first project for DoubleBear Productions really shows and I mean REALLY shows. That said Brian Mitsoda also worked on "Vampire: The Masquerade – Bloodlines" which was an exceptional game with a few rough edges as well.I had followed the games history since it was announced many years ago and hoped it would see the light of the day as the concept sounded amazing, glad that it did despite its flaws. It could have been a much better game though if produced by a more experienced studio. It is an enjoyable experience and not let down by its short comings provided you are interested in both zombies & cRPGs.Graphically it is "meh", you would think that the game is older than it is. That said cRPG's aren't about their graphics so how does the rest hold up?Well fairly well if a bit formulaic, for example when you are at the school (your base of operations that you upgrade over the course of the game) you can speak with your team mates. After a certain point you become aware of the limited amount of interactions. The combat itself is turnbased like XCOM but done nowhere near with the same amount of polish, it works but could have done with a bit more polish and fine tuning.Upgrading the school and crafting as well as recruiting survivors is quite fun and the events that happen are good. The overal atmosphere and storyline in the game make up for its short comings.If you have run out of good cRPG's to play and understand you are getting a lesser quality game than you are usually used to, then you won't be disapointed. If you haven't run out then get other games first like: Pillars of Eterinity, Planescape Torment, Baulders Gate Series, Divinity Original Sin, Wasteland 2, Fallout 1/2

There are free flash games that are better and more fulfilling, games like Rebuild or Last Stand.Graphics don't make or break a game for me -- I play rogue-like games like Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup because I care more about gameplay than how a game looks.  However, Dead State is buggy and shallow AND looks atrociously bad.  I mean just absolutely horrible.Pros+ The basic theme had promiseCons- Shallow characters- Massive amount of bugs- Simplistic gameplay- Horrible 1990s UI- Weak narrative- Grating music- Poor camera angles- Ugly graphicsAnd then they slap you in the face with the $30 price.I could go on and on about more specifics, like how putting unique weapons like pepper spray or nailguns in the base inventory removes and destroys all ammo from them.  Or how morale hits rock bottom despite carting back a department store's worth of goods every day.  Or how one NPC gets angry and discusses deserting because he's not in my party enough....  and I've used him 100% of the time.  Or how you have to wait for a heavily armed camp labeled "hostile looters" to open fire on you before you fire back, otherwise your party members accuse you of killing innocent people.There's more.  So much more.  I cannot in good conscience recommend Dead State.  Don't waste your money on this lemon.EDIT UPDATE:  I'm trying it out after the latest patch.  I'll give credit where credit is due:  Most of the bugs, if not all of them, that I mentioned have been fixed by the developer.  I don't think I've ever seen game bugs be fixed that fast before in my entire life.  So at least the developers are on the ball as far as that goes.I've found yet more bugs since trying it out again, and it's still a crazy mess not even close to worth the asking price.  I won't say that the developers are inattentive, however.

There is no way that I could find to map controls and to see the controls it constantly reminds you to check the manual in the install directory. There is no way to see what commands are in game. And I just could not get trades between characters to work in the field. Even though it says to right click on the character that did nothing.This game charges 19.99 and I cant justify that cost. I mean this isnt just indie its amatuer. I suppose if I spent several hours fighting the controls and alt tabbing to look back in the manual then I could figure it out. But hey only a two return window. I just dont have time for that.Cool idea just poor execution.
